question: Question 1 Cylindrical workpieces of diameter 60 mm and length 400 mm are machined on a lathe at a cutting speed of 25 [latex]m\; min^{-1}[/latex] and a feed of 0.2 [latex]mm\; rev^{-1}[/latex]. The Taylor's tool life parameters [latex]C[/latex] and [latex]n[/latex] for this setup are 75 and 0.25, respectively. The tool changing time is 3 minutes. With a labor and overhead cost of Rs. 5 per minute, the tool changing cost per piece is Rs. _______ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given: Diameter of workpiece [latex] D = 60 , \text{mm} [/latex] Length of workpiece [latex] L = 400 , \text{mm} [/latex] Cutting speed [latex] V = 25 , \text{m/min} [/latex] Feed [latex] f = 0.2 , \text{mm/rev} [/latex] Taylor's tool life parameters: [latex] C = 75,; n = 0.25 [/latex] Tool changing time [latex] T_c = 3 , \text{min} [/latex] Labor and overhead cost = Rs. 5 per minute Step 1: Calculate tool life using Taylor’s equation Taylor’s equation: [latex] VT^n = C [/latex] [latex] T = \left( \frac{C}{V} \right)^{1/n} = \left( \frac{75}{25} \right)^{1/0.25} = 3^4 = 81 , \text{minutes} [/latex] Step 2: Calculate spindle speed (N) [latex] N = \frac{1000 \cdot V}{\pi D} = \frac{1000 \cdot 25}{\pi \cdot 60} \approx 132.63 , \text{rev/min} [/latex] Step 3: Time to machine one workpiece [latex] t = \frac{L}{f \cdot N} = \frac{400}{0.2 \cdot 132.63} \approx 15.08 , \text{minutes} [/latex] Step 4: Number of pieces per tool [latex] N_p = \frac{\text{Tool life}}{\text{Time per piece}} = \frac{81}{15.08} \approx 5.37 , \text{pieces} [/latex] Step 5: Tool changing cost per piece Tool changing cost = [latex] 3 , \text{min} \times 5 = 15 , \text{Rs} [/latex] Cost per piece = [latex] \frac{15}{5.37} \approx \boxed{2.79 , \text{Rs}} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{2.79 , \text{Rs}} [/latex]

question: Question 2 Two metal parts (a cylinder and a cube) of same volume are cast under identical conditions. The diameter of the cylinder is equal to its height. The ratio of the solidification time of the cube to that of the cylinder is________ (rounded off to 2 decimal places). Assume that solidification time follows Chvorinov’s rule with an exponent of 2.
solution: Given: • A cube and a cylinder have the same volume. • For the cylinder: diameter = height = [latex] d [/latex] • Solidification time follows Chvorinov’s rule: [latex] t_s \propto \left( \frac{V}{A} \right)^2 [/latex] We are to find the ratio: [latex] \frac{t_{\text{cube}}}{t_{\text{cyl}}} = \left( \frac{V/A_{\text{cube}}}{V/A_{\text{cyl}}} \right)^2 = \left( \frac{A_{\text{cyl}}}{A_{\text{cube}}} \right)^2 [/latex] Step 1: Assume side of cube = a Volume of cube: [latex] V = a^3 [/latex] Surface area of cube: [latex] A_{\text{cube}} = 6a^2 [/latex] Step 2: For cylinder of diameter = height = d Volume of cylinder: [latex] V = \frac{\pi}{4}d^2 \cdot d = \frac{\pi d^3}{4} [/latex] Surface area of cylinder: • Top and bottom = [latex] 2 \cdot \frac{\pi d^2}{4} = \frac{\pi d^2}{2} [/latex] • Lateral area = [latex] \pi d \cdot d = \pi d^2 [/latex] So total: [latex] A_{\text{cyl}} = \frac{\pi d^2}{2} + \pi d^2 = \frac{3\pi d^2}{2} [/latex] Step 3: Use volume equality to relate [latex] a [/latex] and [latex] d [/latex] [latex] a^3 = \frac{\pi d^3}{4} \Rightarrow a = \left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right)^{1/3} d [/latex] Step 4: Surface area of cube in terms of [latex] d [/latex] [latex] A_{\text{cube}} = 6a^2 = 6 \left( \left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right)^{1/3} d \right)^2 = 6 \cdot \left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right)^{2/3} d^2 [/latex] Step 5: Ratio of solidification times [latex] \frac{t_{\text{cube}}}{t_{\text{cyl}}} = \left( \frac{A_{\text{cyl}}}{A_{\text{cube}}} \right)^2 = \left( \frac{\frac{3\pi d^2}{2}}{6 \cdot \left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right)^{2/3} d^2} \right)^2 [/latex] Cancel [latex] d^2 [/latex] and simplify: [latex] = \left( \frac{3\pi / 2}{6 \cdot \left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right)^{2/3}} \right)^2 = \left( \frac{\pi}{4 \cdot \left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right)^{2/3}} \right)^2 [/latex] [latex] = \left( \pi^{1 - \frac{2}{3}} \cdot 4^{ -1 + \frac{2}{3}} \right)^2 = \left( \pi^{1/3} \cdot 4^{-1/3} \right)^2 = \left( \left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right)^{1/3} \right)^2 [/latex] So finally: [latex] \frac{t_{\text{cube}}}{t_{\text{cyl}}} = \left( \left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right)^{1/3} \right)^2 = \left( \frac{\pi}{4} \right)^{2/3} [/latex] Step 6: Numerical calculation [latex] \frac{\pi}{4} = 0.7854 [/latex] [latex] \left( 0.7854 \right)^{2/3} \approx \boxed{0.86} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{0.86} [/latex]

question: Question 3 Two plates of thickness 10 mm each are to be joined by a transverse fillet weld on one side and the resulting structure is loaded as shown in the figure below. If the ultimate tensile strength of the weld material is 150 MPa and the factor of safety to be used is 3, the minimum length of the weld required to ensure that the weld does NOT fail is ______ mm (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given: Plate thickness = [latex] 10 , \text{mm} [/latex] Ultimate tensile strength of weld material = [latex] 150 , \text{MPa} [/latex] Factor of safety = [latex] 3 [/latex] Load applied = [latex] 5 , \text{kN} = 5000 , \text{N} [/latex] Step 1: Allowable shear stress in weld Allowable stress = [latex] \frac{\text{Ultimate strength}}{\text{FOS}} = \frac{150}{3} = 50 , \text{MPa} [/latex] Step 2: Throat thickness of fillet weld For a fillet weld of size [latex] s = 10 , \text{mm} [/latex], the throat thickness [latex] t = s \cdot \sin 45^\circ = 10 \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = 7.07 , \text{mm} [/latex] Step 3: Area of weld Let [latex] L [/latex] be the required length of weld. Weld area = [latex] A = t \cdot L = 7.07 \cdot L [/latex] Step 4: Equating force with strength [latex] \text{Force} = \text{Allowable stress} \cdot \text{Area} [/latex] [latex] 5000 = 50 \cdot 7.07 \cdot L [/latex] [latex] L = \frac{5000}{50 \cdot 7.07} = \frac{5000}{353.5} \approx \boxed{14.14 , \text{mm}} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{14.14 , \text{mm}} [/latex]

question:
Question 4 A plate of 30 mm thickness is fed through a rolling mill with two powered rolls.
Each roll has a diameter of 500 mm. The plate thickness is to be reduced to 27 mm
in a single pass. Assume no change in width. The process feasibility and the
maximum draft (in mm) can be represented, respectively, as Use the coefficient of friction as 0.12
solution: Given: Initial thickness, [latex] t_1 = 30 , \text{mm} [/latex] Final thickness, [latex] t_2 = 27 , \text{mm} [/latex] Roll diameter, [latex] D = 500 , \text{mm} \Rightarrow R = \frac{D}{2} = 250 , \text{mm} [/latex] Coefficient of friction, [latex] \mu = 0.12 [/latex] Step 1: Calculate the actual draft [latex] \Delta h = t_1 - t_2 = 30 - 27 = 3 , \text{mm} [/latex] Step 2: Calculate maximum possible draft using friction [latex] \Delta h_{\text{max}} = \mu^2 R = (0.12)^2 \times 250 = 0.0144 \times 250 = 3.6 , \text{mm} [/latex] Step 3: Compare actual draft with maximum draft Since [latex] 3 , \text{mm} < 3.6 , \text{mm} [/latex], the process is feasible. Final Answer: Process is feasible and maximum draft is [latex] 3.6 , \text{mm} [/latex] Correct option: (A)

\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Process} & \textbf{Layer creation technique} & \textbf{Material} \\
\hline
\begin{array}{c|l}
P & \text{Stereolithography} \\
Q & \text{Fused deposition modeling} \\
R & \text{Laminated object manufacturing} \\
S & \text{Laser-engineered net shaping} \\
\end{array}
&
\begin{array}{c|l}
1 & \text{Injection of powder stream} \\
2 & \text{Extrusion of melted polymer} \\
3 & \text{Liquid layer curing} \\
4 & \text{Sheet material deposition} \\
\end{array}
&
\begin{array}{c|l}
I & \text{Paper} \\
II & \text{Epoxy} \\
III & \text{Titanium} \\
IV & \text{Acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS)} \\
\end{array}
\\
\hline
\end{array}

 [/latex]
solution: Given: Matching additive manufacturing processes with their layer creation techniques and materials. Matching: P. Stereolithography → Layer technique: 3. Liquid layer curing → Material: II. Epoxy Q. Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) → Layer technique: 2. Extrusion of melted polymer → Material: IV. Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene (ABS) R. Laminated Object Manufacturing (LOM) → Layer technique: 4. Sheet material deposition → Material: I. Paper S. Laser Engineered Net Shaping (LENS) → Layer technique: 1. Injection of powder stream → Material: III. Titanium Final Answer: P-3-II, Q-2-IV, R-4-I, S-1-III Correct option: (B)

question: Question 6 Wire drawing operation is performed on a perfectly plastic metal without any strain hardening. Assuming no friction and no redundant work, the maximum possible percentage reduction in area in a single pass is closest to
solution: Given: Wire drawing operation on a perfectly plastic metal (no strain hardening), with no friction and no redundant work. We use the formula for maximum possible reduction in area: [latex] r = 1 - \frac{1}{e} [/latex] Where [latex] e [/latex] is Euler’s number (approximately 2.718). Step 1: Calculate maximum possible reduction: [latex] r = 1 - \frac{1}{2.718} = 1 - 0.368 = 0.632 [/latex] Step 2: Convert to percentage: [latex] r = 63.2% [/latex]

question:
Question 7 Match the mold elements in the casting process with the most suitable function [latex]
\begin{array}{|c|c|}
\hline
\textbf{Mold element} & \textbf{Function} \\
\hline
\begin{array}{c|l}
P & \text{Blind riser} \\
Q & \text{Chill} \\
R & \text{Skim bob} \\
S & \text{Core} \\
T & \text{Insulating sleeve} \\
U & \text{Inoculant} \\
\end{array}
&
\begin{array}{c|l}
I & \text{Casting with internal cavity} \\
II & \text{Molten metal reservoir} \\
III & \text{Nucleating agent} \\
IV & \text{Assisting in faster heat removal from melt} \\
V & \text{Removal of impurities} \\
VI & \text{Increasing the solidification time} \\
\end{array}
\\
\hline
\end{array}

 [/latex]
solution: Given: We need to match mold elements with their correct functions in the casting process. Let’s go through each mold element: P. Blind riser: Stores excess molten metal to compensate for shrinkage during solidification. → Function: II. Molten metal reservoir Q. Chill: A metallic object placed in the mold to rapidly extract heat and promote directional solidification. → Function: IV. Assisting in faster heat removal from melt R. Skim bob: Used to remove slag and impurities from the molten metal before it enters the mold cavity. → Function: V. Removal of impurities S. Core: A sand insert used to form internal cavities in the casting. → Function: I. Casting with internal cavity T. Insulating sleeve: Slows down cooling to avoid premature solidification in risers. → Function: VI. Increasing the solidification time U. Inoculant: A nucleating agent added to refine the grain structure. → Function: III. Nucleating agent

options.A: P-II, Q-IV, R-V, S-I, T-VI, U-III
options.B: P-II, Q-V, R-VI, S-I, T-III, U-IV
options.C: P-V, Q-I, R-VI, S-III, T-II, U-IV
options.D: P-II, Q-IV, R-I, S-V, T-VI, U-III

question: Question 8 A liquid metal is poured in a mold cavity of size [latex]200 mm \times 200 mm  \times  200 mm[/latex]. The cooling is uniform in all directions with NO additional compensation for shrinkage. Considering the volumetric shrinkage during solidification and solid contraction as 7% and 8%, respectively, the length of the cube edge after cooling down to the room temperature is _______ mm (rounded off to 1 decimal place).
solution:
Given: Initial size of the cube: [latex]200\ \text{mm} \times 200\ \text{mm} \times 200\ \text{mm}[/latex] Volumetric shrinkage during solidification: [latex]7%[/latex]
Volumetric shrinkage during solid contraction: [latex]8%[/latex] Shrinkage occurs in volume, but we are asked about the final edge length assuming uniform cooling in all directions. Step 1: Total volumetric shrinkage
[latex]V_{\text{initial}} = 200^3 = 8,000,000\ \text{mm}^3[/latex] After solidification (7% shrinkage):
[latex]V_1 = V_{\text{initial}} \times (1 - 0.07) = 8,000,000 \times 0.93 = 7,440,000\ \text{mm}^3[/latex] After solid contraction (8% shrinkage):
[latex]V_2 = V_1 \times (1 - 0.08) = 7,440,000 \times 0.92 = 6,844,800\ \text{mm}^3[/latex] Step 2: Final volume is a cube, so
[latex]L^3 = 6,844,800[/latex] [latex]L = \sqrt[3]{6,844,800} \approx 188.0\ \text{mm}[/latex]

question: Question 9 During a welding operation, thermal power of 2500 W is incident normally on a metallic surface. As shown in the figure below (figure is NOT to scale), the heated area is circular. Out of the incident power, 85% of the power is absorbed within a circle of radius 5 mm while 65% is absorbed within an inner concentric circle of radius 3 mm. The power density in the shaded area is _________  [latex]Wmm^{-2}[/latex] (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given: Total incident power = [latex]2500\ \text{W}[/latex] 85% of power is absorbed within a circle of radius [latex]R = 5\ \text{mm}[/latex] 65% of power is absorbed within an inner circle of radius [latex]r = 3\ \text{mm}[/latex] We are to find the power density in the shaded area (annular region between 3 mm and 5 mm) Step 1: Calculate absorbed powers [latex]P_{5} = 0.85 \times 2500 = 2125\ \text{W}[/latex] [latex]P_{3} = 0.65 \times 2500 = 1625\ \text{W}[/latex] Step 2: Power absorbed in the shaded annular area [latex]P_{\text{shaded}} = P_5 - P_3 = 2125 - 1625 = 500\ \text{W}[/latex] Step 3: Area of shaded region = Area of outer circle – Area of inner circle [latex]A = \pi (R^2 - r^2) = \pi (5^2 - 3^2) = \pi (25 - 9) = \pi \times 16 \approx 50.27\ \text{mm}^2[/latex] Step 4: Power density [latex]\text{Power Density} = \dfrac{P_{\text{shaded}}}{A} = \dfrac{500}{50.27} \approx 9.95\ \text{W/mm}^2[/latex]

question: Question 10 When assembled, the hole [latex]30^{+0.030}_{+0.000}[/latex] mm and shaft [latex]30^{+0.020}_{-0.020}[/latex] mm will result in
solution: Given: Hole: [latex] 30^{+0.030}{+0.000} \ \text{mm} [/latex] Shaft: [latex] 30^{+0.020}{-0.020} \ \text{mm} [/latex] Step 1: Determine Maximum and Minimum Sizes Maximum Hole Size: [latex] 30 + 0.030 = 30.030 \ \text{mm} [/latex] Minimum Hole Size: [latex] 30 + 0.000 = 30.000 \ \text{mm} [/latex] Maximum Shaft Size: [latex] 30 + 0.020 = 30.020 \ \text{mm} [/latex] Minimum Shaft Size: [latex] 30 - 0.020 = 29.980 \ \text{mm} [/latex] Step 2: Calculate Possible Clearances Maximum Clearance: [latex] 30.030 - 29.980 = 0.050 \ \text{mm} [/latex] Minimum Clearance: [latex] 30.000 - 30.020 = -0.020 \ \text{mm} [/latex] (which is interference) Conclusion: Since the maximum clearance is positive and the minimum clearance is negative, the assembly may result in either a small clearance or interference. [latex] \Rightarrow \text{This is a} \ \boxed{\text{transition fit}} [/latex]

question: Question 11 Ceramics and glass are machined by
solution: Concept: Ceramics and glass are brittle, hard, and non-conductive materials, which makes them difficult to machine using conventional methods. Therefore, non-traditional machining processes are used. Step 1: Analyze Each Option (A) Electric Discharge Machining (EDM): [latex] \text{EDM} [/latex] is used for electrically conductive materials only. Ceramics and glass are non-conductive. [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Not suitable. (B) Ultrasonic Machining (USM): [latex] \text{USM} [/latex] uses high-frequency vibrations and abrasive slurry to remove material. It is ideal for brittle, hard, and non-conductive materials like ceramics and glass. [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] This is the correct process. (C) Electrochemical Machining (ECM): [latex] \text{ECM} [/latex] also requires the workpiece to be electrically conductive. [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Not suitable for ceramics and glass. (D) Transferred Arc Plasma Machining: This process involves high temperatures and is mostly used for metals, not for delicate materials like ceramics or glass. [latex] \Rightarrow [/latex] Not suitable.

question: Question 12 In computer aided design (CAD), solid models can be constructed using
solution: Concept: In Computer-Aided Design (CAD), there are various methods to represent solid models. Among them, Boundary Representation (B-rep) is widely used for constructing solid models. Step 1: Understanding B-rep Boundary Representation (B-rep) defines a solid model by its boundaries — that is, its surfaces, edges, and vertices. It explicitly describes the shape and limits of a solid object. It is the standard method used in solid modeling systems because it allows accurate representation of complex geometries. Step 2: Role of Bezier, B-splines, and NURBS [latex] \text{Bezier curves}, \text{B-splines}, \text{and NURBS} [/latex] are used for curve and surface modeling — especially in free-form surface design — but not for solid modeling directly. They are often used within B-rep to define smooth surfaces, but they do not represent solid models themselves. Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{\text{(A)}\ \text{boundary representation (B-rep)}} [/latex]

question: Question 13 The welding process commonly used for fabricating tailor-welded blanks of dissimilar thickness for automotive applications is
solution: Given: The question asks for the commonly used welding process in fabricating tailor-welded blanks of dissimilar thickness, especially in automotive applications. Step 1: Understanding Tailor-Welded Blanks (TWBs) Tailor-welded blanks are sheets of metal with different thicknesses or materials joined together before forming operations. They are widely used in the automotive industry to reduce weight while maintaining strength. Step 2: Required Welding Characteristics The ideal welding process for TWBs should Handle dissimilar thicknesses efficiently Provide high precision and control Cause minimal heat-affected zone Be fast and automated for high production rates Step 3: Analyzing Options Option (A): Gas Welding [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Not precise enough for thin sheet metals or dissimilar thicknesses. Option (B): Laser Welding [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Offers high precision, narrow welds, low distortion, and is widely used for TWBs in automotive industries. Option (C): Arc Welding [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Suitable for general purposes but not ideal for thin sheet welding with high precision. Option (D): Friction Welding [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Used for rotational symmetric parts, not commonly used for sheet TWBs. Final Answer: The correct welding process is: [latex] \boxed{\text{Laser welding}} [/latex] ✅

question: Question 14 Among the following surface hardening processes, steel is heated to the lowest temperature in
solution: Step 1: Understanding Surface Hardening Processes Surface hardening processes enhance the wear resistance of steel by altering its surface composition or microstructure while maintaining a tough core. Common methods include carburizing, cyaniding, nitriding, and carbonitriding. Step 2: Temperature Ranges for Each Process Carburizing : Steel is heated to [latex]900^\circ \mathrm{C} \text{ to } 950^\circ \mathrm{C}[/latex] Cyaniding : Steel is heated to [latex]800^\circ \mathrm{C} \text{ to } 900^\circ \mathrm{C}[/latex] Nitriding : Steel is heated to [latex]500^\circ \mathrm{C} \text{ to } 590^\circ \mathrm{C}[/latex] Carbonitriding : Steel is heated to [latex]850^\circ \mathrm{C} \text{ to } 950^\circ \mathrm{C}[/latex] Step 3: Identifying the Process with the Lowest Temperature Among these processes, nitriding occurs at the lowest temperature: [latex]500^\circ \mathrm{C} \text{ to } 590^\circ \mathrm{C}[/latex]. Step 4: Final Answer The correct option is: [latex]\boxed{\text{(C) Nitriding}}[/latex]

question: Question 15 A flat surface of a C60 steel having dimensions of [latex]100 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] (length) [latex]\times 200 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] (width) is produced by a HSS slab mill cutter. The 8-toothed cutter has [latex]100 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] diameter and [latex]200 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] width. The feed per tooth is [latex]0.1 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex], cutting velocity is [latex]20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{min}[/latex] and depth of cut is [latex]2 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]. The machining time required to remove the entire stock is ______ minutes (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
Data given: [latex]\mathrm{Z}=8, \mathrm{D}=100 \mathrm{~mm}, \mathrm{w}=200 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] [latex]V=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{min}, \mathrm{d}=2 \mathrm{~mm}, \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{t}}=0.1 \mathrm{~mm} /[/latex] tooth [latex]\mathrm{N}=[/latex] ? [latex]\mathrm{QR}=\sqrt{\mathrm{d}(\mathrm{D}-\mathrm{d})}=\sqrt{2 \times(100-2)}=14 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{Le}=[/latex] effective length of approach [latex]=\mathrm{QR}+\mathrm{L}[/latex]

[latex]=14+100=114 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] [latex]=\mathrm{F}[/latex] or removal of entire length [latex]\mathrm{N}=\frac{\mathrm{V} \times 1000}{\pi \mathrm{D}}=\frac{20 \times 1000}{\pi \times 100}=63.662 \mathrm{rpm}[/latex] So, feed [latex]=f_{t} \times N Z=0.1 \times 63.662 \times 8[/latex]

[latex]=50.93 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{min}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{t}_{\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{c}}=\frac{\mathrm{Le}}{\mathrm{F}}=\frac{114}{50.93}=2.24 \mathrm{~min}[/latex]

question: Question 16 In an arc welding process, the vol tage and current are [latex]30 \mathrm{~V}[/latex] and 200A, respectively. The crosssectional area of the joint is [latex]20 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}[/latex] and the welding speed is [latex]5 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]. The heat required to melt the material is [latex]20 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]. The percentage of heat lost to the surrounding during the welding process is _______ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).

Question 17 A blanking operations is performed on C20 steel sheet to obtain circular disc having a diameter of [latex]20 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] and a thickness of [latex]2 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]. An allowance of 0.04 is provided. The punch size used for the operation is ______ [latex]\mathrm{mm}[/latex] (rounded off to 2 decimal places).

Question 18 Aluminium is casted in a cube-shaped mold having dimensions as [latex]20 \mathrm{~mm} \times 20 \mathrm{~mm} \times 20 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]. Another mold of the same mold material is used to cast a sphere of aluminium having a diameter of [latex]20 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]. The pouring temperature for both cases is the same. The ratio of the solidification times of the cube-shaped mold to the spherical mold is ______ (answer in integer).
solution:
Given, [latex]\quad \mathrm{D}=20 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] for sphere Volume of cube [latex]=20 \times 20 \times 20 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}[/latex] According chvorinov's rule [latex]
\begin{aligned}
t & \propto\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)^{2} \\
\frac{t_{\text {cube }}}{t_{\text {sphere }}} & =\frac{\left(\frac{V_{\text {cube }}}{A_{\text {cube }}}\right)^{2}}{\left(\frac{V_{\text {sphere }}}{A_{\text {sphere }}}\right)^{2}} \\
& =\frac{\left(\frac{20 \times 20 \times 20}{6 \times 20^{2}}\right)^{2}}{\left(\frac{\pi \mathrm{D}^{3}}{6}\right)^{2}} \\
& =\left(\frac{20 \times 6}{6 \times \mathrm{D}}\right)^{2} \\
& =\left(\frac{20}{D}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{20}{20}\right)^{2}=1
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 19 A cutting tool provides a tool life of 60 minutes while machining with the cutting speed of [latex]60 \mathrm{~m} /[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{min}[/latex]. When the same tool is used for machining the same material, it provides a tool life of 10 minutes for a cutting speed of [latex]100 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{min}[/latex]. If the cutting speed is changed to [latex]80 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{min}[/latex] for the same tool and work material combination, the tool life computed using Taylor's tool life model is _____ minutes (rounded off to 2 decimal places).

Question 20 The preparatory functions in Computer Numerical Controlled (CNC) machine
programing are denoted by the alphabet
solution: G-codes are also known as preparatory codes for [latex]\mathrm{CNC}[/latex] machine. The instructions provided by [latex]\mathrm{G}[/latex] codes tell the machine tool how to move in the ( [latex]X, Y, Z[/latex] ) Cartesian co-ordinate.

question:
Question 21 The most suitable electrode material used for joining low alloy steels using Gas
Metal Arc Welding (GMAW) process is
solution: For general-purpose welding of low alloy steels electrode (e.g. E7018) issued for welding of low alloy steel through GMAW. Electrode with specific alloy compositions are selected to match base metal's composition in order to achieved desired mechanical properties in the weld.

question: Question 22 The allowance provided to a pattern for easy withdrawal from a sand mold is
solution: Types of allowances: Draft/taper allowances. Machining allowance/finishing allowance. Distortion allowances/camber allowance Shrinkage allowance/contraction allowances. Shake allowance/rapping allowance. Shake allowance Before withdrawal from the sand mould, the pattern is wrapped all around the vertical faces to enlarge the mould cavity slightly, which facilitates its removal. Since it enlarge the final casting made, it is desirable that the original pattern dimensions should be reduced to account for this increase. There is no sure way of quantifying this allowance, since it is highly dependent on the foundry personnel and practices involved. It is negative allowance and is to be applied only to those dimensions, which are parallel to the parting plane. One way of reducing this allowance is to increase the draft, which can be removed during the subsequent matching. Draft/taper allowances Once pattern is embedded in the moulding sand now it is required to withdrawing the pattern from moulding sand, for this propose a vertical force is required to lift the pattern. For easy removal of pattern from mould cavity there should be some degree or [latex]\mathrm{mm}[/latex] taper in the pattern. If there is no taper in the pattern then more chance to break the mould cavity wall during withdrawing the pattern. Draft allowance varies with the complexity of job. Machining or Finishing allowance In sand casting operation machining/finishing allowances is given in the pattern as on solidification every metal get shrinked up to some extend and the outer surface of object (casting) is rough, therefore, to smoothing the outer surface of casting machining allowance is must. Distortion allowance/Camber allowance On just solidification of metal casting is weak, therefore, more chances to distorted casting. Chance of distortion are basically in [latex]U, V[/latex], then long section or complicated casting. Distortion can be minimized or eliminated by providing an allowance and constructed the pattern initially distorted, i.e. opposite in outer side direction. Among of distortion allowance varies from 1.5[latex]20 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]. It is the tendency of all metals that they shrink after cooling except bismuth, Shrinkage is only due to inter atomic vibration which are implified by increasing in temperature. Metal shrink or contract in three ways : Liquid Contraction Solidification Contraction Solid Contraction

question: Question 24 The "Earing" phenomenon in metal forming is associated with
solution: Fig. Earning in a drawn steel cup, caused by the planar anisotropy of the sheet metal In deep drawing, the edges of cups may become wavy, called earing. Ears are objectionable on deep-drawn cups because they have to be trimmed off, as they serve no useful purpose, and interfere with further processing of the cup, resulting in scarp. Earing is caused by the planar anisotropy of the sheet metal, and the number of ears produced may be two, four or eight, depending on the processing history and microstructure of the material. If the sheet is stronger in the rolling direction than transverse to the rolling direction, and the strength varies uniformly with respect to orientation, then two ears will form. If the sheet has high strength at different orientations, then more ears will form.

Fine pearlite [latex]\rightarrow \alpha[/latex] Ferrite [latex]+\mathrm{Fe}_{3} \mathrm{C} \rightarrow[/latex] Alternating layers of a ferrite and [latex]\mathrm{Fe}_{3} \mathrm{C}[/latex] that are relatively thin.

Question 27 A solid part (see figure) of polymer material is to be fabricated by additive
manufacturing (AM) in square-shaped layers starting from the bottom of the part
working upwards. The nozzle diameter of the AM machine is [latex]a/10[/latex] mm and the
nozzle follows a linear serpentine path parallel to the sides of the square layers
with a feed rate of [latex]a/5[/latex] mm/min. Ignore any tool path motions other than those involved in adding material, and any
other delays between layers or the serpentine scan lines. The time taken to fabricate this part is _______ minutes. 
(Answer in integer)
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
 V&=(3a)^2 \times 1.5a+ (2a)^2 \times a+(a)^2 \times 0.5a\\ 
 &= 18a^3\\ 
 T&=\frac{V}{\left ( \frac{a}{10} \right )^2 \times \left ( \frac{a}{5} \right )} \\
&=\frac{18a^3}{a^3} \times 100 \times 5=9000 min
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 28 A coordinate measuring machine (CMM) is used to determine the distance between Surface
SP and Surface SQ of an approximately cuboidal shaped part. Surface SP is declared as the
datum as per the engineering drawing used for manufacturing this part. The CMM is used
to measure four points P1, P2, P3, P4 on Surface SP, and four points Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4 on
Surface SQ as shown. A regression procedure is used to fit the necessary planes.
The distance between the two fitted planes is _______ mm.
(Answer in integer)
solution: Since [latex]y[/latex]-coordinate of all four points [latex]P_{1}, P_{2}, P_{3}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{P}_{4}[/latex] is zero. Hence the regression plane fitted by points [latex]P_{1}, P_{2}, P_{3}[/latex] and [latex]P_{4}[/latex] is [latex]x-z[/latex] plane. The distance of any point (i.e. [latex]\mathrm{Q}_{1}, \mathrm{Q}_{2}, \mathrm{Q}_{3}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{Q}_{4}[/latex] ) from [latex]x-z[/latex] plane is equal to [latex]y[/latex] co-ordinate Therefore, The distance of [latex]Q_{1}[/latex] from [latex]x-z[/latex] plan [latex]=6 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] The distance of [latex]Q_{2}[/latex] from [latex]x-z[/latex] plan [latex]=6 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] The distance of [latex]Q_{3}[/latex] from [latex]x-z[/latex] plan [latex]=4 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] The distance of [latex]Q_{4}[/latex] from [latex]x-z[/latex] plan [latex]=4 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] The distance of best fitted plane by [latex]Q_{1}, Q_{2}, Q_{3}[/latex] and [latex]Q_{4}[/latex] from [latex]x-z[/latex] plane is equal to average of 6,6,4 and 4 , which is equal to [latex]5 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]. Hence, the distance between two fitted planes is [latex]5 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex].

question:
Question 29 A part, produced in high volumes, is dimensioned as shown. The machining
process making this part is known to be statistically in control based on sampling
data. The sampling data shows that D1 follows a normal distribution with a mean
of 20 mm and a standard deviation of 0.3 mm, while D2 follows a normal
distribution with a mean of 35 mm and a standard deviation of 0.4 mm. An
inspection of dimension C is carried out in a sufficiently large number of parts. To be considered under six-sigma process control, the upper limit of dimension C
should be ______ mm. (Rounded off to one decimal place)
solution:
D1 and D2 follow normal distribution. So, Upper limit [latex]=\mu +3\sigma [/latex] Lower limit [latex]=\mu -3\sigma [/latex] [latex]\bar{D1}=20mm, \bar{D2}=35mm, \sigma _{D2}=0.4mm,\sigma _{D1}=0.3mm[/latex] Mean value of 
[latex] (\bar{C}) =\bar{D2}-\bar{D1}=35-20-15[/latex] Standard Devialtion of C [latex]\sigma _C^2=\sigma _{D2}^2 -\sigma _{D1}^2  [/latex] [latex]\sigma _C=\sqrt{0.4^2-0.3^2}=0.2645  [/latex] Upper Limit of C 
[latex] \bar{C}+6 \times \sigma _C=15+6 \times 0.2645=16.587 [/latex]

Question 34 In a metal casting process to manufacture parts, both patterns and moulds provide

solution: In some moulding processes like investment and full moulding, permanent moulds can be used for preparing the pattern.

question:
Question 35 Two surfaces P and Q are to be joined together. In which of the given joining
operation(s), there is no melting of the two surfaces P and Q for creating the joint?
solution:
Soldering is define as a metal joining process
wherein coalescence is produced by heating the
surface to be joint to a suitable temperature and
melting the filler metal which is a fusible alloy called
solder (melting point usually less than [latex] 427^{\circ}C[/latex]
). Principle underlying soldering is that when the
surface to be jointed are cleaned off well from
oxides they can be joined together using molten
solder that may adhere easily with the workpiece. Brazing is also one of the type of welding process
which is used for joining the two similar or dissimilar
metal piece together by heating the surface and
by using a non-ferrous filler metal having its melting
point above [latex] 427^{\circ}C[/latex] but below the melting point of
metal to be brazed. The molten filler metal is
distributed between the joint surface by the capillary
action which on cooling results in a sound joint.

question:
Question 37 A cylindrical billet of 100 mm diameter and 100
mm length is extruded by a direct extrusion process
to produce a bar of [latex]L[/latex]-section. The cross sectional
dimensions of this [latex]L[/latex]-section bar are shown in the
figure. The total extrusion pressure ([latex]p[/latex]) in MPa for
the above process is related to extrusion ratio (r) as [latex] p=K_s\sigma _m\left [ 0.8+1.5 \ln (r)+\frac{2l}{d_0} \right ]  [/latex] where [latex] \sigma _m  [/latex]  is the mean flow strength of the billet
material in MPa, [latex] l  [/latex]  is the portion of the billet length
remaining to be extruded in mm, [latex] d_0  [/latex] 
 is the initial
diameter of the billet in mm, and [latex] K[/latex]  is the die shape
factor. If the mean flow strength of the billet material is
50 MPa and the die shape factor is 1.05, then the
maximum force required at the start of extrusion is
________ kN (round off to one decimal place).
solution:
Original length of the billet [latex](L_0)=100mm [/latex] Original diameter of billet [latex] (d_0)=100mm[/latex] Mean flow stress of billet material  [latex](\sigma _m)=50MPa [/latex] Die Shape factor[latex] K_S=1.05[/latex] Original Cross Sectional Area of Billet [latex]A_0=\frac{\pi}{4}d_0^2=\frac{\pi}{4}100^2=7853.981 [/latex] Cross sectional area of extruded product [latex]A_f=(10 \times 50)+ (10 \times 50)=1000 mm^2 [/latex] Extrusion ratio [latex]r=\frac{A_0}{A_f}=\frac{7853.9816}{1000}=7.854 [/latex] Extrusion pressure will be maximum at the start of
extrusion process where [latex] L_0=100mm[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
P_{max}&= K_S\sigma _m\left [ 0.8+1.5 \ln (r)+\frac{2L_0}{d_0} \right ]\\
&=1.05 \times 50 \left [ 0.8+1.5 \ln (7.854)+\frac{2 \times 100}{100} \right ]\\
&=309.305 MPa
\end{aligned} [/latex] Maximum Extrusion force [latex]\begin{aligned}
F_{max}&= P_{max} \times A_0\\
&=309.305 \times \frac{\pi}{4}(100)^2\\
&=2429265.97N\\
&=2429.3kN
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 38 In a direct current arc welding process, the power
source has an open circuit voltage of 100 V and
short circuit current of 1000 A. Assume a linear
relationship between voltage and current. The
arc voltage ([latex]V[/latex]) varies with the arc length ([latex]l[/latex]) as
[latex]V = 10 + 5l[/latex], where [latex]V[/latex] is in volts and [latex]l[/latex] is in mm. The
maximum available arc power during the process is
_________ kVA (in integer).
solution:
Given, OCV = 100 V and SCC = 1000 A Voltage Arc length characteristic [latex] V_{arc}=10+5l[/latex] We have, [latex] \begin{aligned}
V_P&=OCV-\frac{OCV}{SCC}I\\
V_P&=100-\frac{100}{1000}I\\
_P&=100-\frac{I}{10}
\end{aligned}[/latex] For stable arc [latex]\begin{aligned}
V_{arc}&=V_P\\
10+5l&=100-\frac{I}{10}\\
I&=900-50l\\
\text{Arc Power} (P)&=V \times I\\
P&=(10+5l)(900-50l)\\
P&=9000+4000l-250l^2
\end{aligned} [/latex] For Maximum Arc Power [latex]\begin{aligned}
\frac{dP}{dl}&=0\\
\frac{d}{dl}(9000+400l-250l^2)&=0\\
l=4000/500&=8mm
\end{aligned} [/latex] Hence, for Maximum arc power, arc length is 8 mm Voltage at [latex]l=8mm [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
V&=10+5l\\
V&=10+( 5 \times 8)\\
V&=50 \;Volt
\end{aligned} [/latex] Current at [latex]l=8mm [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
I&=900-50l\\
I&=900-( 50 \times 8)\\
I&=500 \;A
\end{aligned} [/latex] Maximum Arc Power [latex] \begin{aligned}
P_{max}&= V \times I\\
P_{max}&=50 \times 500\\
&=25000VA\\
&=25 kVA
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 39 The best size wire is fitted in a groove of a metric
screw such that the wire touches the flanks of the
thread on the pitch line as shown in the figure. The
pitch (p) and included angle of the thread are 4 mm
and [latex] 60^{\circ}  [/latex] , respectively. The diameter of the best size
wire is ___________ mm (round off to 2 decimal
places).
solution:
Pitch [latex] (p) = 4 mm [/latex] Thread angle  [latex] 2\alpha =60^{\circ}[/latex] Semi Thread Angle  [latex] \alpha =30^{\circ}[/latex] Diameter of best size wire [latex] \begin{aligned}
 d_w&=\frac{p}{2}\sec \alpha \\
d_w&=\frac{4}{2} \sec 30^{\circ}\\
d_w&=2.039 mm=2.31mm
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 40 In an orthogonal machining operation, the cutting
and thrust forces are equal in magnitude. The uncut
chip thickness is 0.5 mm and the shear angle is
[latex] 15^{\circ}  [/latex] . The orthogonal rake angle of the tool is [latex] 0^{\circ}  [/latex]  and
the width of cut is 2 mm. The workpiece material
is perfectly plastic and its yield shear strength is
500 MPa. The cutting force is _________ N (round
off to the nearest integer).
solution:
Given, [latex]F_C=F_T [/latex] Uncut chip thickness [latex](t_1)=0.5mm [/latex] Shear angle  [latex] (\phi )=15^{\circ}[/latex] Orthogonal rake angle [latex] \alpha =0^{\circ} [/latex] Width of cut [latex] w=2mm[/latex] Shear strength [latex] (\tau _S) =500MPa[/latex] Cutting force [latex]f_c= [/latex] ____N [latex]\begin{aligned}
 F_S&=F_C \cos \phi -F_T \sin \phi \\
&=F_C \cos \phi -F_C \sin \phi \\ \\ 
 &= F_C(\cos \phi - \sin \phi)\\ 
 F_C&=\frac{F_S}{\cos \phi - \sin \phi} \\ 
 &= \frac{\tau _S\cdot w\cdot t_1}{\sin \phi (\cos \phi - \sin \phi)}\\
&=\frac{500 \times 2 \times 0.5}{\sin 15^{\circ}(\cos 15^{\circ}-\sin 15^{\circ})}\\
&=2732 N
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 41 A straight-teeth horizontal slab milling cutter is
shown in the figure. It has 4 teeth and diameter (D)
of 200 mm. The rotational speed of the cutter is
100 rpm and the linear feed given to the workpiece
is 1000 mm/minute. The width of the workpiece
(w) is 100 mm, and the entire width is milled in
a single pass of the cutter. The cutting force/tooth
is given by [latex]F = K t_cw[/latex], where specific cutting force
[latex]K = 10 N/mm^2
, \; w[/latex] is the width of cut, and [latex]t_c[/latex]
 is the
uncut chip thickness. The depth of cut ([latex]d[/latex]) is [latex]D/2[/latex], and hence the
assumption of [latex]\frac{d}{D} \lt \lt 1[/latex] is invalid. The maximum
cutting force required is __________ kN (round off
to one decimal place).
solution:
Given data, No. of teeth [latex] (n)=4[/latex] Diameter of cutter [latex]  (D) = 200 mm [/latex] Rotational speed  [latex] (N) = 100 rpm [/latex] Linear feed to work piece = 1000 mm/min Width of work piece [latex] (w) = 100 mm [/latex] Cutting force/tooth  [latex] = F = K t_c w[/latex] Specific cutting force  [latex] = K = 10 N/mm^2[/latex] Depth of cut   [latex](d)= D/2 [/latex] [latex]Feed(f) = 1000/100 = 10 mm/rev [/latex] Uncut chip thickness [latex] =t_c[/latex] Maximum uncut chip thickness  [latex] (t_c)_{max}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
&=\frac{2f}{n}\sqrt{d/D(1-d/D)}\\
&=\frac{2 \times 10}{4}\sqrt{\frac{D/2}{D}\left ( 1- \frac{D/2}{D}\right )}\\
&=5\sqrt{1/2(1-1/2)}=2.5mm\\
&\text{Maximum force }\\
(F)_{max}&=K(t_c)_{max}\cdot w\\
&=10 \times 2.5 \times 100\\
&=2500N=2.5kN
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 42 Which of these processes involve(s) melting in
metallic workpieces?
solution:
Non traditional thermal energy process includes
electrical discharge machining (EDM), electron
beam machining (EBM), and laser beam machining
(LBM). EDM removes metal by a series of discrete
electrical discharge (sparks) that cause localized
temperatures high enough to melt or vaporize the
metal in the immediate vicinity of the discharge.
EBM adopts a high velocity stream of electrons
focused on the workpiece surface to remove material
by melting and vaporization. LBM employs the
light energy from a laser to remove material by
vaporization and ablation.

question:
Question 43 Consider sand casting of a cube of edge length a. A
cylindrical riser is placed at the top of the casting.
Assume solidification time, [latex] t_s\propto V/A [/latex], where [latex]V[/latex] isthe
volume and [latex]A[/latex] is the total surface area dissipating
heat. If the top of the riser is insulated, which of the
following radius/radii of riser is/are acceptable?
solution:
Riser should take more time for solidification than
casting [latex]\left ( \frac{V}{A}  \right )_r\geq\left ( \frac{V}{A} \right )_c [/latex] For top riser bottom area is not cooling surface and
it is given that top cross section is also insulated. So
only lateral area is cooling area. [latex] \frac{\frac{\pi}{4}D^2H}{\pi DH}\geq \frac{a^3}{6a^2}\Rightarrow \frac{D}{4}\geq \frac{a}{6}\Rightarrow D\geq \frac{2a}{3}[/latex] Therefore, Radius [latex] R\geq \frac{a}{3} [/latex]. only answer is available [latex]  \frac{a}{2}[/latex].

question:
Question 44 Which one of the following CANNOT impart linear
motion in a CNC machine?
solution:
Chain and Sprocket mechanism is not used in CNC
Machines. Linear Motors Recently linear motors are being
increasingly considered for use in high performance
CNC machine tools. The linear motor consists of
a series of magnets attached to the machine base
and a set of electrical coils potted around a steel
laminate core attached to the moving slide. The fact that there are no mechanical parts in contact
means that there is no wear periodic maintenance
required. Linear motors are not limited in travel
like ball screws. Larger bare required to achieve
high velocity, with a longer travel to prevent undue
vibration. This larger ball screw results in a higher inertia. This
means a larger motor with more torque is required
(introduction inertia) and the responsiveness and
bandwidth of the system is reduced, resulting in
poor servo performance. Machines built with linear motors and all-digital
drive systems can produce parts with higher
accuracy and tighter tolerances at higher feeds
and speeds. Also, they reduce significantly the
non-machining time with high acceleration and
deceleration rates.

question:
Question 45 Match the additive manufacturing technique in
Column I with its corresponding input material in
Column II. Additive manufacturing technique (Column I) P. Fused deposition modelling Q. Laminated object manufacturing R. Selective laser sintering Input material (Column II) 1. Photo sensitive liquid resin 2. Heat fusible powder 3. Filament of polymer 4. Sheet of thermoplastic or green compacted metal
sheet
solution:
Fused-deposition modeling consists of a computercontrolled extruder, through which a polymer
filament is deposited to produce a part slice by slice. Laminated-object manufacturing uses a laser
beam or vinyl cutter to first cut the slices on paper
or plastic sheets (laminations); then it applies an
adhesive layer, if necessary and finally stacks the
sheets to produce the part. Selective laser sintering uses a high-powered laser
beam to sinter powders or coatings on the powders
in a desired pattern. Selective laser sintering has
been applied to polymers, sand, ceramics, and
metals.

question:
Question 46 A shaft of diameter [latex] 25^{^{-0.04}}_{-0.07}  [/latex]mm  is assembled in a
hole of diameter [latex] 25^{^{+0.02}}_{0.00}  [/latex]mm. Match the allowance and limit parameter in
Column I with its corresponding quantitative value
in Column II for this shaft-hole assembly. Allowance and limit parameter (Column I) P. Allowance Q. Maximum clearance R. Maximum material limit for hole Quantitative value (Column II) 1. 0.09 mm 2. 24.96 mm 3. 0.04 mm 4. 25.0 mm
solution:
(1) Allowance = Lower limit of hole - upper limit of
shaft Allowance = 25.00 - 24.96 = 0.04 mm (2) Maximum clearance
 [latex]C_{max}[/latex] = Upper limit of hole - lower limit of shaft [latex]C_{max}[/latex] = 25.02 - 24.93 = 0.09 mm (3) Maximum material limit for hole = minimum size
of hole = 25.00

question:
Question 47 Fluidity of a molten alloy during sand casting depends
on its solidification range. The phase diagram of a
hypothetical binary alloy of components A and B
is shown in the figure with its eutectic composition
and temperature. All the lines in this phase diagram,
including the solidus and liquidus lines, are straight
lines. If this binary alloy with 15 weight % of B
is poured into a mould at a pouring temperature of
[latex] 800^{\circ}C  [/latex], then the solidification range is
solution:
Solidification range [latex] =A'B[/latex] [latex]\triangle ABC \text{ and } \triangle MB'C [/latex] is similar [latex] \begin{aligned}
\frac{MA}{MB'}&=\frac{BC}{BC'}\\
\frac{700-T_A}{700-400}&=\frac{15}{30}\\
700-T_A&=\frac{1}{2} \times 300\\
T_A&=550^{\circ}C
\end{aligned}[/latex] Solidification range [latex]=T_A-T_B=550-400=150 ^{\circ}C[/latex]

question:
Question 48 Two mild steel plates of similar thickness, in buttjoint configuration, are welded by gas tungsten
arc welding process using the following welding
parameters. [latex] \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline
 \text{Welding voltage}&20V \\ \hline
\text{Welding current} & 150A\\ \hline
\text{Welding speed}&5mm/s \\ \hline
\end{array} [/latex] A filler wire of the same mild steel material having
3 mm diameter is used in this welding process. The
filler wire feed rate is selected such that the final
weld bead is composed of 60% volume of filler and
40% volume of plate material. The heat required to melt the mild steel material is 10 [latex]J/mm^3[/latex]. The heat
transfer factor is 0.7 and melting factor is 0.6. The
feed rate of the filler wire is __________ mm/s
(round off to one decimal place).
solution:
Welding current = 150A Welding voltage = 20V Heat Generated [latex]Q_1 = V \times I=150 \times 20=3000 Watt[/latex] Net Heat supplied to the Work Piece [latex](Q_2)=Q_1 \times \eta _{HT} =300 \times 0.7=2100 Watt[/latex] Heat Required to Melt the material [latex](Q_3)=Q_2 \times \eta _{m} =2100 \times 0.6=1260 Watt[/latex] Since Heat Required to melt the material is given 
directly in the question [latex]10^5 \; J/mm^3[/latex] Hence we can write [latex]1260=10 \times [/latex] Volumetric metal Deposition Rate (VMDR) (VMDR) [latex]=\frac{1260}{10}=126 mm^3/s[/latex] It means total [latex]126 mm^3/s[/latex] metal need to be deposited in the gap between Work Piece It is given in the question that 60% of the total volume is to be filled by electrode. Hence, effective volumetric metal deposition by electrode[latex]=126 \times 0.6=75.6 mm^3/s[/latex] Volumetric metal deposition rate = Cross section 
Area of electrode x Electrode feed rate [latex]75.6=\frac{\pi}{4}d_e^2 \times \text{feed rate}[/latex] [latex]\text{feed rate}=\frac{75.6}{\frac{\pi}{4}(3)^2}=10.69mm/s 
[/latex]

question:
Question 49 A 4 mm thick aluminum sheet of width [latex] w=100mm[/latex]
is rolled in a two-roll mill of roll diameter 200 mm
each. The workpiece is lubricated with a mineral
oil, which gives a coefficient of friction, [latex] \mu =0.1 [/latex].
The flow stress ([latex] \sigma [/latex]) of the material in MPa is [latex] \sigma=207+414\varepsilon  [/latex] , where [latex]\varepsilon  [/latex] is the true strain. Assuming
rolling to be a plane strain deformation process, the
roll separation force (F) for maximum permissible
draft (thickness reduction) is _________ kN (round
off to the nearest integer). Use : [latex] F=1.15 \bar{\sigma }\left ( 1+\frac{\mu L}{2\bar{h}} \right )wL [/latex] where [latex]\bar{\sigma } [/latex] is average flow stress, [latex] L[/latex] is roll-workpiece
contact length, and [latex] \bar{h}[/latex] is the average sheet thickness.
solution:
Initial thickness [latex]h_1=4mm[/latex] Width [latex]w= 100 mm[/latex] Roll Diameter [latex]D= 200 mm[/latex] Roll Radius [latex]R= 100 mm[/latex] Coefficient of Friction [latex]\mu =0.1[/latex] Flow stress is given by [latex]\sigma =207+414\varepsilon [/latex] We have equation for maximum possible reduction 
is [latex]\begin{aligned} 
\Delta h&=\mu ^2R\\ 
\Delta h&=(0.1)^2 \times 100=1mm=h_1-h_2\\ 
h_2&=h_1-\Delta h=4-1=3mm 
\end{aligned}[/latex] Now True strain [latex]\varepsilon = \ln\left ( \frac{h_1}{h_2} \right )= \ln \left ( \frac{4}{3} \right )=0.2876[/latex] Stress when no rolling [latex]\varepsilon =0, \sigma _1=207 MPa[/latex] Stress when material is rolled to maximum possible 
extent [latex]\varepsilon =0.2876, \sigma _2=207+414(0.2876)=326.06 MPa[/latex] Since Strain hardening characteristics is linear the 
average flow stress [latex]\bar{\sigma }=\frac{\sigma _1+\sigma _2}{2}=\frac{207+326.06}{2}=266.53MPa[/latex] Projected length of contact 
[latex]L=\sqrt{R\cdot \Delta h}=\sqrt{100 \times 1}=10mm[/latex] Rolls separation force, [latex]\begin{aligned} 
F&=1.15\bar{\sigma }\left ( 1+\frac{\mu L}{2\bar{h}} \right )wL\\ 
&=1.15 \times 266.53\left ( 1+\frac{0.1 \times 10}{2 \times \frac{7}{2}} \right ) \times 100 \times 10\\ 
F&=350.3 N\\ 
F&=0.350kN 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 50 A 1 mm thick cylindrical tube, 100 mm in diameter,
is orthogonally turned such that the entire wall
thickness of the tube is cut in a single pass. The
axial feed of the tool is 1 m/minute and the specific
cutting energy (u) of the tube material is 6 [latex]J/mm^3[/latex].
Neglect contribution of feed force towards power.
The power required to carry out this operation is
_________ kW (round off to one decimal place).
solution:
Given data, cylindrical tube thickness [latex](t)[/latex] = 1 mm Diameter [latex](D)[/latex] = 100 mm Orthogonal cutting such that entire wall thickness 
of tube is cut in single pass. Therefore, Tube thickness = depth of cut = [latex]d = 1 mm[/latex] Axial feed of the tool [latex]= 1 m/min = f.N[/latex] Specific cutting Energy [latex](U) = 6 \; J/mm^3[/latex] Power _________ kW Specific cutting energy[latex](U) = 6 \; J/mm^3=\frac{\text{Power}}{\text{MRR}}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} 
Power &= 6 \times MRR \\ 
&= 6 \times f.d.v\\ 
&= 6 \times f.d. \pi.D.N\\ 
&= 6 \times d \times \pi \times D \times f.N\\ 
&= 6 \times 1 \times \pi \times 100 \times 1 \times \frac{1000}{60}\\ 
&= 31415.9\;J/sec \; or \; Watt\\ 
&=31.4 \;kW 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 51 Under orthogonal cutting condition, a turning
operation is carried out on a metallic workpiece at a
cutting speed of 4 m/s. The orthogonal rake angle of
the cutting tool is [latex] 5^{\circ} [/latex]. The uncut chip thickness and
width of cut are 0.2 mm and 3 mm, respectively. In
this turning operation, the resulting friction angle
and shear angle are [latex] 45^{\circ} [/latex] and [latex] 25^{\circ} [/latex], respectively. If
the dynamic yield shear strength of the workpiece material under this cutting condition is 1000 MPa,
then the cutting force is ______________ N (round
off to one decimal place).
solution:
Cutting speed [latex](V) = 4m/sec[/latex] Orthogonal rake angle [latex]\alpha =5^{\circ}[/latex] Uncut chip thickness ([latex](t_1)=.0.2mm[/latex] Width of cut [latex] (w) = 3 mm[/latex] Friction angle [latex]\beta =45^{\circ}[/latex] Shear angle [latex](\phi ) =25^{\circ}[/latex] Shear strength [latex](\tau _0 ) =1000MPa[/latex] Cutting force [latex](F_c)=[/latex]____N [latex]\begin{aligned} 
F_S &= R \cos (\phi +\beta -\alpha )\\ 
R&=\frac{\tau _0 \cdot A_S}{\cos (\phi +\beta -\alpha )} \\ 
R&=\frac{\tau _0 \cdot wt_1}{\sin \phi \cos (\phi +\beta -\alpha )} \\ 
F_c&= R \cdot \cos (\beta -\alpha )\\ 
&=\frac{\tau _0 \cdot wt_1\cdot \cos (\beta -\alpha )}{\sin \phi \cos (\phi +\beta -\alpha )} \\ 
&= \frac{1000 \times 3 \times 0.2 \times \cos (45-5)}{\sin 25\cdot \cos (25+45-5)}\\ 
&=2573.4N 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 52 In [latex]Fe-Fe_3C[/latex] phase diagram, the eutectoid composition
is 0.8 weight % of carbon at [latex] 725 ^{\circ}C [/latex]. The maximum

weight % of carbon. A steel sample, having no other
alloying element except 0.5 weight % of carbon, is

The fraction of pro-eutectoid [latex]\alpha [/latex]-ferrite in the above
steel sample at room temperature is

question:
Question 53 Electrochemical machining operations are
performed with tungsten as the tool, and copper and
aluminum as two different workpiece materials.
Properties of copper and aluminum are given in the
table below. [latex]\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Material} & \text{Atomic mass (amu)} & \text{Valency} & \text{Density }(g/cm^3)\\ \hline
Copper &63  &2  & 9\\ 
Aluminum &27  & 3 & 2.7 \\ \hline
\end{array}[/latex] Ignore overpotentials, and assume that current
efficiency is 100% for both the workpiece materials. Under identical conditions, if the material removal
rate (MRR) of copper is 100 mg/s, the MRR of
aluminum will be ________________ mg/s (roundoff to two decimal places).
solution:
Copper At. Wt = 63, Valency = 2 [latex]e=\frac{\text{At.\; Wt}}{\text{Valency}}=\frac{63}{2}=31.5 [/latex] Aluminium At. Wt = 27, Valency = 3 [latex] e=\frac{27}{3}=9[/latex] Material Removal Rate in g/s is given by [latex]MRR=\frac{e.I}{F} [/latex] e = Chemical equivalent I = Current F = Faraday constant At Constant current & Faraday's constant [latex]\begin{aligned}
MRR\propto e\\
\frac{MRR_{Cu}}{MRR_{Al}}&=\frac{e_{Cu}}{e_{Al}}\\
\frac{100}{MRR_{Al}}&=\frac{31.5}{9}\\
MRR_{Al}&=28.57 mg/s
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 54 Which of the following methods can improve the
fatigue strength of a circular mild steel (MS) shaft?
solution:
Surface Treatments: During machining operations,small scratches
and grooves are invariably introduced into the
workpiece surface by cutting tool action. These
surface markings can limit the fatigue life. It has
been observed that improving the surface finish by
polishing will enhance fatigue life significantly. One of the most effective methods of increasing
fatigue performance is by imposing residual
compressive stresses within a thin outer surface
layer. Thus, a surface tensile stress of external
origin will be partially nullified and reduced in
magnitude by the residual compressive stress. The
net effect is that the likelihood of crack formation
and therefore of fatigue failure is reduced. Residual compressive stresses are commonly
introduced into ductile metals mechanically by
localized plastic deformation within the outer
surface region. Commercially, this is often
accomplished by a process termed shot peening.
Small, hard particles (shot) having diameters
within the range of 0.1 to 1.0 mm are projected at
high velocities onto the surface to be treated. The
resulting deformation induces compressive stresses
to a depth of between one-quarter and one-half of
the shot diameter.

question: Question 55 Which of the following additive manufacturing technique(s) can use a wire as a feedstock material?
solution:
Fused-deposition modeling consists of a computercontrolled extruder, through which a polymer
filament is deposited to produce a part slice by
slice. Selective laser sintering uses a high-powered laser
beam to sinter powders or coatings on the powders
in a desired pattern. Selective laser sintering has
been applied to polymers, sand, ceramics, and
metals. Stereolithography involves a computer-controlled
laser-focusing system, that cures a liquid
thermosetting polymer containing a photosensitive
curing agent. Directed energy deposition (DED) processes
enable the creation of parts by melting material as it is being deposited. Although this basic approach
can work for polymers, ceramics, and metal matrix
composites, it is predominantly used for metal
powders. Thus, this technology is often referred to
as "metal deposition" technology.

question:
Question 56 Which of the following heat treatment processes is/
are used for surface hardening of steels?
solution:
Case-hardening, also referred to as surfacehardening, commonly involves one of four different
methods: carburizing, nitriding, cyaniding, or
carbonitriding. Case- hardening is used on parts
such as gear teeth, cutting wheels, and tools. These
case-hardened pieces represent a compromise
between the hard, wear-resistant brittleness of
high-carbon steel and the softer, more ductile, less
wear-resistant low-carbon steels.

question:
Question 58 A CNC worktable is driven in a linear direction by
a lead screw connected directly to a stepper motor.
The pitch of the lead screw is 5 mm. The stepper
motor completes one full revolution upon receiving
600 pulses. If the worktable speed is 5 m/minute
and there is no missed pulse, then the pulse rate
being received by the stepper motor is
solution:
No. of steps required for one full revolution of
stepper motor shaft or lead screws [latex] n_S= 600 [/latex] Pitch [latex](p) = 5 mm  [/latex] Linear table speed [latex]V_{table}= 5 m/min
 = 5000 mm/min [/latex] RPM of lead Screw [latex] (N_S)= \frac{V_{table}}{p}=1000 rpm[/latex] We have equation of frequency of pulse generator [latex] \begin{aligned}
f_p&= N_s \times n_S\\
f_p&= 1000 \times 600=600,000 pulses/min\\

\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 59 A 76.2 mm gauge block is used under one end of a 254 mm sine bar with roll diameter of 25.4 mm. The height of gauge blocks required at the other end of the sine bar to measure an  angle  of [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex] is __________mm (round off to two decimal places).
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned} \sin 30^{\circ} &=\frac{h_{1}}{254} \\ \text{or}\qquad h_{1} &=254 \sin 30^{\circ}=127 \mathrm{~mm} \\ H_{2} &=76.2+127=203.2 \mathrm{~mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]\\
Case II: [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\sin 30^{\circ} &=\frac{76.2-h_{1}}{254} \\
\text{or}\qquad h_{1} &=76.2-254 \sin 30^{\circ}\\
&=-50.8 \mathrm{~mm}
\end{aligned}[/latex] Which is not feasible Therefore final answer 203.2 mm.

question: Question 60 The thickness, width and length of a metal slab are 50 mm,  250  mm and  3600 mm, respectively. A rolling operation on this slab reduces the thickness by 10% and increases the width by 3%. The length of the rolled slab is ________mm (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} h_{1}=50 \mathrm{~mm} ; \quad h_{2}=0.9 h_{1} ; \\ b_{1}=250 \mathrm{~mm} ; \quad b_{2}=1.03 b_{1} ; \\ L_{1}=3600 \mathrm{~mm} ; \quad L_{2}=? \end{array}[/latex] Volume remains const. in theory of plasticity [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{1} b_{1} L_{1} &=h_{2} b_{2} L_{2} \\ &=0.9 h_{1} \times 1.03 b_{1} \times L_{2} \\ L_{2} &=\frac{3600}{0.9 \times 1.03}=3883.5 \mathrm{~mm}=3883.5 \mathrm{~mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 61 In a pure orthogonal turning by a zero rake angle single point carbide cutting tool, the shear force has been computed  to be 400  N.  The  cutting velocity, [latex]V_c=100 \; m/min[/latex], depth of cut, [latex]t=2.0 \; mm[/latex], feed, [latex]s_0=0.1 \; mm/revolution[/latex] and chip velocity, [latex]V_f=20 \; m/min[/latex], the shear strength, [latex]\tau _s[/latex] of the material will be  _______MPa (round off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \alpha &=0^{\circ} \\ F_{s} &=400 \mathrm{~N} \\ \text { Cutting velocity }(\mathrm{V}) &=100 \mathrm{~m} / \min \left(V_{c}\right) \\ d &=2.0 \mathrm{~mm}(t) \\ f &=0.1 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{rev}\left(S_{o}\right) \\ \text { Chip velocity }\left(V_{c}\right) &=20 \mathrm{~m} / \min \quad\left(V_{f}\right) \\ r &=\frac{t}{t_{c}}=\frac{l_{c}}{l}=\frac{V_{c}}{V} \quad\left(V_{c}=\text { chip velocity; } V=\right.\text { cutting velocity) }\\ &=\frac{20}{100}=0.2\\ \tan \phi &=\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha}=\frac{0.2 \cos 0^{\circ}}{1-0.2 \sin 0^{\circ}}=0.2 \\ \phi &=11.31^{\circ} \\ & \frac{F_{S}}{A_{S}}=\frac{F_{S}}{\left(\frac{b t}{\sin \phi}\right)}=\frac{F_{S} \sin \phi}{f d} \\ t &=f \sin 90^{\circ} \\ b &=d \sin 90^{\circ} \\ b t &=f d \\ &=\frac{400 \sin 11.31^{\circ}}{0.1 \times 2.0} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ &=392.23 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 62 A surface grinding operation has been performed on a Cast Iron plate having dimensions 300 mm (length) x 10 mm (width) x 50 mm (height). The grinding was performed using an alumina wheel having a wheel diameter of 150 mm and wheel width of 12 mm. The grinding velocity used is 40 m/s, table speed is 5 m/min, depth of cut per pass is 50 [latex]\mu m[/latex] and the number of grinding passes is 20. The average tangential and average normal force for each pass is found to be 40 N and 60 N respectively. The value of the specific grinding energy under the aforesaid  grinding  conditions  is  __________[latex]J/mm^3[/latex] (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Power } &=F_{c} \cdot V \\ &=40 \mathrm{~N} \times 40 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}=1600 \mathrm{~W} \\ \mathrm{MRR} &=10 \times 0.050 \times \frac{5000}{60} \mathrm{~mm}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ &=41.667 \mathrm{~mm}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] e=\frac{\text { Power }}{\text { MRR }}=\frac{1600 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}}{41.667 \mathrm{~mm}^{3} / \mathrm{s}}=38.40 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{mm}^{3}[/latex]

question: Question 63 A spot welding operation performed on two pieces of steel yielded a nugget with a diameter of 5 mm and a thickness of 1 mm. The welding time was 0.1 s. The melting energy for the steel is 20 [latex]J/mm^3[/latex]. Assuming the heat conversion efficiency as 10%, the power required for performing the spot welding operation is  _________kW (round off to two decimal places).
solution: Heat transfer efficiency [latex]=10\%[/latex] Energy required to melt [latex]=20 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{mm}^{3}[/latex] Diameter of nugget [latex]=5 \mathrm{~mm} [/latex] Thickness [latex]=1 \mathrm{~mm} [/latex] Time [latex]=0.1 \mathrm{~second} [/latex] Heat required to melt, [latex]Q=20 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{mm}^{3} \times \frac{\pi}{4}(5)^{2} \times 1=392.5 \mathrm{~J}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Power } &=\frac{\text { Heat required to melt }}{\text { Time }} \\ P &=\frac{392.5}{0.1} \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s} \\ P &=3925 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}=3925 \mathrm{~W} \\ \text { Actual power supplied } &=\frac{3925}{\eta_{\text {th }}} \\ \eta_{\text {th }} &=10 \% \\ P &=\frac{3925}{0.1}=39250 \mathrm{~W}=39.25 \mathrm{~kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 64 A cast product of a particular material has dimensions 75 mm x 125 mm x 20 mm. The total solidification time for the cast product is found to be 2.0 minutes as calculated using Chvorinov's rule having the index, n = 2. If under the identical casting conditions, the cast product shape is changed to a cylinder having diameter = 50 mm and height = 50 mm, the total solidification time will be __________minutes (round off to two decimal places).
solution: Casting dimensions [latex]=75 \mathrm{~mm} \times 125 \mathrm{~mm} \times 20 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] Total solidification time [latex]\left(t_{s}\right)_{\mathrm{cu}}=2.0 \mathrm{~min}.[/latex] Cylindrical casting [latex]=\mathrm{H}=\mathrm{D}=50 \mathrm{~min}[/latex] Total solidification Time [latex]\left(t_{s}\right)_{c y}=?[/latex] Chvorinov's rule, [latex]\begin{aligned} t_{s} &\propto\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)^{n} \quad n=2 \\ \frac{\left(t_{s}\right)_{c u}}{\left(t_{s}\right)_{c y}}&=\frac{\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)_{c u}^{2}}{\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)_{c y}^{2}}\\ \left(\frac{V}{A}\right)_{c y} &=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} h}{2 \frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} h+\pi d h} \\ h &=d \\ \left(\frac{V}{A}\right)_{c y} &=\frac{d}{6} \\ \frac{\left(t_{s}\right)_{c U}}{\left(t_{s}\right)_{c_{y}}} &=\frac{\left[\frac{75 \times 125 \times 20}{2(75 \times 125+125 \times 20+20 \times 75)}\right]^{2}}{\left(\frac{50}{6}\right)^{2}} \\ \frac{2}{\left(t_{s}\right)_{c y}} &=\frac{49.131}{69.44}=0.7075 \\ \left(t_{s}\right)_{c y} &=2.83 \mathrm{~min} . \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 The allowance provided in between a hole and a shaft is calculated from the difference between
solution: It is minimum clearance or maximum interference. It is the intentional difference between the basic dimensions of the mating parts. The allowance may be positive or negative.

options.A: lower limit of the shaft and the upper limit of the hole

question: Question 66 The machining process that involves ablation is
solution: Laser beam machining (LBM) is a nonconventional machining process,   which   broadly   refers   to the process of material removal, accomplished through the interactions between the laser and target materials. The processes can include laser drilling, cutting, grooving, writing, scribing, ablation, welding, cladding, milling, and so on. LBM is a thermal process, and unlike conventional mechanical processes, LBM removes material without mechanical engagement. In general, the workpiece is heated to melting or boiling point and removed by melt ejection, vaporization, or ablation.

question: Question 67 In a CNC machine tool, the function of an interpolator is to generate
solution: In contouring systems the machining path is usually constructed from a combination of linear and circular segments. It is only necessary to specify the coordinates of the initial and final points of each segment, and the feed rate. The operation of producing the required shape based on this information is termed interpolation and the corresponding unit is the "interpolator". The interpolator coordinates the motion along the machine axes, which are separately driven, by providing reference positions instant by instant for the position-and velocity control loops, to generate the required machining path. Typical interpolators are capable of generating linear and circular paths.

options.A: signal for the lubrication pump during machining
options.B: error signal for tool radius compensation during machining
options.C: NC code from the part drawing during post processing
options.D: reference signal prescribing the shape of the part to be machined

question: Question 68 The size distribution of the powder particles used in Powder Metallurgy process can be determined by
solution: Particle Size, Shape, and Distribution: Particle size is generally controlled by screening, that is, by passing the metal powder through screens (sieves) of various mesh sizes. Several other methods also are available for particle-size analysis: 1. Sedimentation, which involves measuring the rate at which particles settle in a fluid. 2. Microscopic analysis, which may include the use of transmission and scanning- electron microscopy. 3. Light scattering from a laser that illuminates a sample, consisting of particles suspended in a liquid medium; the particles cause the light to be scattered, and a detector then digitizes the signals and computes the particle-size distribution. 4. Optical methods, such as particles blocking a beam of light, in which the particle is sensed by a photocell. 5. Suspending particles in a liquid and detecting particle size and distribution by electrical sensors.

question: Question 69 The Cast Iron which possesses all the carbon in the combined form as cementite is known as
solution: On the basis of nature of carbon present in cast iron, it may be divided into white cast iron and gray cast iron. In the gray cast iron, carbon is present in free form as graphite. Under very slow rate of cooling during solidification, carbon atoms get sufficient time to separate out in pure form as graphite. In addition, certain elements promote decomposition of cementite. Silicon and nickel are two commonly used graphitizing elements. In white cast iron, carbon is present in the form of combined form as cementite. In normal conditions, carbon has a tendency to combine with iron to form cementite.

question: Question 70 Two smooth identical spheres each of radius 125 mm and weight 100 N rest in a horizontal channel having vertical walls. The distance between vertical walls of the channel is 400 mm. The reaction at the point of contact between two spheres is  _______N (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} B C &=250^{2}-150^{2} \\ \cos \theta &=\frac{200}{250} \\ \theta &=36.869^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{2} \cos \theta &=100 \\ R_{2} &=\frac{100 \times 250}{200}=125 \mathrm{~N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 71 The XY table of a NC machine tool is to move from P(1,1) to Q(51,1); all coordinates are in mm. The pitch of the NC drive leadscrew is 1 mm. If the backlash between the leadscrew and the nut is  [latex]1.8^{\circ}[/latex], then the total backlash of the table on moving from P to Q is  _______mm (round off to two decimal places).
solution: P(1, 1) to P(51, 1) is 50 mm distance. As pitch of the leadscrew is 1 mm. It has to move 50 rotation and in each rotation, backlash is 1.8 degree. Therefore total backlash = 1.8 x 50 degree. In one rotation i.e. [latex]360^{\circ}[/latex] rotation - 1 mm movement take place In [latex]1.8 \times 50^{\circ}=\frac{1.8 \times 50}{360} \mathrm{~mm}=0.25 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]

question: Question 72 A 200 mm wide plate having a thickness of 20 mm is fed through a rolling mill with two rolls. The radius of each roll is 300 mm. The plate thickness is to be reduced to 18 mm in one pass using a roll speed of 50 rpm. The strength coefficient (K) of the work material flow curve is 300 MPa and the strain hardening exponent, n is 0.2. The coefficient of friction between the rolls and the plate is 0.1. If the friction is sufficient to permit the rolling operation then the roll force will be _____kN (round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
Given: Width of plate, w = 200 mm Thickness of plate, [latex]t_0 = 20 mm[/latex] Radius of roller, R = 300 mm Reduced thickness of plate in one pass, [latex]t_f = 18 mm[/latex] Rollers speed, N = 50 rpm Strength coefficient, (K) = 300 MPa Strain hardening exponent, n = 0.2 Coefficient of friction, [latex]\mu = 0.1[/latex] Find: Roll force (F) [latex]\Delta h=h_0-h_f=20-18=2mm[/latex] Contact length, [latex]L=\sqrt{R\Delta h}=\sqrt{300 \times 2 }=24.49mm[/latex] True strain,  [latex]\varepsilon _T=\ln \left ( \frac{t_0}{t_f} \right )=\ln\left ( \frac{20}{18} \right )=0.1054[/latex] Average Flow stress,  
[latex]\bar{\sigma _f}=\frac{K(\varepsilon )^n}{1+n}=\frac{300 \times 0.1054^{0.2}}{1.2}=159.4MPa[/latex] Rolling force,  [latex]F=\sigma _f(Lw)=159.4 \times 24.49 \times 200=780.776kN[/latex]

question: Question 73 In a grinding operation of a metal, specific energy consumption is 15 [latex]J/mm^3[/latex]. If a grinding wheel with a diameter of 200 mm is rotating at 3000 rpm to obtain a material removal rate of 6000 [latex]mm^3/min[/latex], then the tangential force on the wheel is  _______N (round off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}  E_{s p} &=15 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ \mathrm{MRR} &=6000 \mathrm{~mm}^{3} / \mathrm{min} \\ N &=3000 \mathrm{rpm} \\ D &=200 \mathrm{~mm} \\ E_{s p} &=\frac{F_{C} \mathrm{~V}}{L d V} \\ 15 &=\frac{F \times \frac{m}{m i n}}{600 \frac{m m^{3}}{\min }} \\ V &=\frac{\pi D N}{1 m}=\frac{\pi(200)(3 m)}{1000}=600 \times 3.14\\ 15 &=\frac{F \times 600 \times 3 \pi y}{6000} \\ F &=\frac{150}{\pi}=47.746 \mathrm{~N} \simeq 47.75 \mathrm{~N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 74 An orthogonal cutting operation is performed using a single point cutting tool with a rake angle of [latex]12^{\circ}[/latex] on a lathe. During turning, the cutting force and the friction force are 1000 N and 600 N, respectively. If the chip thickness and the uncut chip thickness during turning are 1.5 mm and 0.75 mm, respectively, then the shear force is _______N (round off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex] F_{c}=1000 \mathrm{~N}, F=600 \mathrm{~N}, t=0.75 \mathrm{~mm}, t_{c}=1.5 \mathrm{~mm}, \alpha=12^{\circ}[/latex] This is orthogonal turning operation [latex] \begin{aligned} r &=\frac{t}{t_{C}}=\frac{0.75}{1.5}=0.5 \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{0.5 \cos 12^{\circ}}{1-0.5 \sin 12^{\circ}} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \phi &=28.63^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Method - 1: Using force relations [latex] \begin{aligned} F &=F_{c} \sin \alpha+F_{t} \cos \alpha \\ 600 &=1000 \sin 12^{\circ}+F_{t} \cos 12^{\circ}\\ \text{or}\qquad F_{t}&=400.85 \mathrm{~N} \\ \therefore \qquad F_{s}&=F_{c} \cos \phi-F_{t} \sin \phi\\ &=1000 \cos 28.63^{\circ}-400.85 \sin 28.63^{\circ} \\ &=685.66 \mathrm{~N} \end{aligned}[/latex] Method - 2 : Using Merchant circle [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{c} &=R \cos (\beta-\alpha) \\ F &=R \sin \beta \\ \text{or}\quad \frac{F}{F_{c}} &=\frac{R \sin \beta}{R \cos (\beta-\alpha)} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{600}{1000} &=\frac{\sin \beta}{\cos (\beta-12)} \\ 0.6 \cos \beta \cos 12^{\circ}+0.6 & \sin \beta \sin 12^{\circ}=\sin \beta \\ 0.586888 \cos \beta &=\left(1-0.6 \sin 12^{\circ}\right) \sin \beta=0.875253 \sin \beta \\ \tan \beta &=\frac{0.586888}{0.875253} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \quad \beta &=33.84^{\circ} \\ \therefore \quad F &=R \sin \beta \\ 600&=R \sin 33.84^{\circ}\\ \Rightarrow R&=1077.44 \mathrm{~N}\\ \therefore \quad F_{s}&=R \cos (\phi+\beta-\alpha)\\ &=1077.44 \cos \left(28.63^{\circ}+33.84^{\circ}-12^{\circ}\right)\\ &=685.77 \mathrm{~N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 75 The resistance spot welding of two 1.55 mm thick metal sheets is performed using welding current of 10000 A for 0.25 s. The contact resistance at the interface of the metal sheets is 0.0001 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. The volume of weld nugget formed after welding is 70 [latex]mm^3[/latex]. Considering the heat required to melt unit volume of metal is 12 [latex]J/mm^3[/latex], the thermal efficiency of the welding process is ______% (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Thickness } &=1.55 \mathrm{~mm} \\ I &=10000 \mathrm{~A} \\ t &=0.25 \mathrm{~s} \\ R &=0.0001 \Omega \\ V_{n} &=70 \mathrm{~mm}^{3} \\ H_{m} &=12 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ \eta_{m} &=? \\ \eta_{m} &=\frac{H_{m}}{H_{s}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Melting efficiency = Thermal efficiency [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta_{m} &=\frac{H_{m}}{I^{2} R t}=\frac{12 \times 70}{(10000)^{2} \times 0.0001 \times 0.25} \\ &=0.336 \\ \eta_{m} &=33.6 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 76 A true centrifugal casting operation needs to be performed horizontally to make copper tube sections with outer diameter of 250 mm and inner diameter of 230 mm. The value of acceleration due to gravity, [latex]g = 10 \; m/s^2[/latex]. If a G-factor (ratio of centrifugal force to weight) of 60 is used for casting the tube, the rotational speed required is _____rpm (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Given: } D_{0}&=250 \mathrm{~mm} ; \\ D_{i}&=230 \mathrm{~mm} ;  \\ g&=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} ; \\ \text { G-factor }&=60 \\ F_{c} &=m r \omega^{2} \\ F_{g} &=m g \\ \text { G-factor } &=\frac{F_{c}}{F_{g}}=60 \\ \text { G-factor } &=\frac{F_{c}}{F_{g}}=\frac{m r \omega^{2}}{m g}=\frac{D_{0}}{2 g}\left(\frac{2 \pi N}{60}\right)^{2} \\ N &=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times G-\text { Factor } \times g}{D_{0}}} \times\left(\frac{60}{2 \pi}\right) \\ N &=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 60 \times 10}{0.25}} \times\left(\frac{60}{2 \pi}\right) \\ N &=661.93 \\ N &=662 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 77 Consider the surface roughness profile as shown in the figure. The center line average roughness ([latex]R_a \text{ in }\mu m[/latex]) of the measured length (L) is

question: Question 78 In modern CNC machine tools, the backlash has been eliminated by
Question 79 The correct sequence of machining operations to be performed to finish a large diameter through hole is
solution: Drilling: to produce a hole, which then may be followed by boring it to improve its dimensional accuracy and surface finish. Boring: to enlarge a hole or cylindrical cavity made by a previous process or to produce circular internal grooves. Reaming: is an operation used to (a) make an existing hole dimensionally more accurate than can br achived by drilling alone and (b) improve  its surface finish. The most accurate holes in workpieces generally are produced by the following sequence of operation. Centering ->  Drilling -> Boring -> Reaming.
