Question 81 A point 'P' on a CNC controlled XY-stage is moved to another point 'Q' using the coordinate
system shown in the figure below and rapid positioning command (G00). A pair of stepping motors with maximum speed of 800 rpm, controlling both the X and
Y motion of the stage, are directly coupled to a pair of lead screw, each with a uniform
pitch of 0.5 mm. The time needed to position the point 'P' to the point 'Q' is _______ minutes.
(round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N&=800 \mathrm{rpm}, P=0.5 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{rev} \\ V &=N \times P\\ &=\mathrm{rev} / \mathrm{min} \times \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{rev}\\&=400 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{min} \\ \Delta t_{x} &=\frac{600}{400}=1.5 \mathrm{min} \\ \Delta t_{y} &=\frac{300}{400}=0.75 \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex] There are two stepper motor so both will work till 0.75 min then y axis motor will stop then only x axis motor will run for 0.75 more, so total time will be 1.5 min.

question:
Question 82 Bars of 250 mm length and 25 mm diameter are to be turned on a lathe with a feed
of 0.2 mm/rev. Each regrinding of the tool costs Rs. 20. The time required for each tool
change is 1 min. Tool life equation is given as [latex]VT^{ 0.2} = 24[/latex] (where cutting speed V is
in m/min and tool life T is in min). The optimum tool cost per piece for maximum
production rate is Rs. ________ (round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Optimum tool life } \left(T_{o}\right)&=\frac{T_{c}(1-n)}{n} \\ &=\frac{1(1-0.2)}{0.2}=4 \mathrm{min} \\ V_{o} T_{o}^{n} &=C \\ \text { or } V_{o}&=\frac{C}{T_{o}^{n}}\\ &=\frac{24}{4^{0.2}}=18.19 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \\ V &=\pi D \mathrm{N} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 18.19 &=\pi \times 0.025 \times N \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow N=231.6 \mathrm{rpm}[/latex] Maching time per piece [latex] \left(T_{m}\right)=\frac{L}{f N}=\frac{250}{0.2 \times 231.6}=5.397 \mathrm{min}[/latex] Number of tool needed per piece work [latex] =\frac{5.397}{4} \text { piece }[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] The optimum tool cost per piece [latex] =\frac{5.397}{4} \times 20=26.985[/latex]

question:
Question 83 There are two identical shaping machines [latex]S_1[/latex] and [latex]S_2[/latex]. In machine [latex]S_2[/latex], the width of the
workpiece is increased by 10% and the feed is decreased by 10%, with respect to that
of [latex]S_1[/latex]. If all other conditions remain the same then the ratio of total time per pass in
[latex]S_1[/latex] and [latex]S_2[/latex] will be __________ (roundoff to one decimal place).

Question 84 A cylindrical bar with 200 mm diameter is being turned with a tool having geometry [latex]0^{\circ}- 9^{\circ} - 7^{\circ} - 8^{\circ} - 15^{\circ} - 30^{\circ} - 0.05[/latex] inch (Coordinate system, ASA) resulting in a cutting force
[latex]F_{c1}[/latex]. If the tool geometry is changed to [latex]0^{\circ}- 9^{\circ} - 7^{\circ} - 8^{\circ} - 15^{\circ} - 0^{\circ} - 0.05[/latex] inch (Coordinate
system. ASA) and all other parameters remain unchanged, the cutting force changes
to [latex]F_{c2}[/latex]. Specific cutting energy (in [latex]J/mm^3[/latex]) is [latex]U_c = U_0 (t_1)^{-0.4}[/latex], where [latex]U_0[/latex] is the specific
energy coefficient, and [latex]t_1[/latex] is the uncut thickness in mm. The value of percentage change
in cutting force [latex]F_{c2}[/latex], i.e. [latex]\left ( \frac{F_{c2}-F_{c1}}{F_{c1}} \right ) \times 100[/latex], is _______ (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C_{s 1}&=30^{\circ}\\ \therefore \quad \lambda_{1}&=90-30=60^{\circ} \\ C_{s 2}&=0^{\circ}\\ \therefore \lambda_{2}&=90-0=90^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] We know that specific energy consumption [latex] \begin{aligned} U_{C}&=\frac{F_{C}}{1000 \mathrm{fd}}=U_{0}\left(t_{1}\right)^{-0.4}(\text {given }) \\ \therefore \quad F_{C}&=U_{0}(f \sin \lambda)^{-0.4} \times 1000 \mathrm{fd}\\ \therefore \quad F_{c} &\propto(\sin \lambda)^{-0.4}\\ \therefore \quad &=\frac{F_{c 2}-F_{c 1}}{F_{c 1}} \times 100=\left[\left(\frac{\sin \lambda_{2}}{\sin \lambda_{1}}\right)^{-0.4}-1\right] \times 100 \\ &=\left[\left(\frac{\sin 90^{\circ}}{\sin 60^{\circ}}\right)^{-0.4}-1\right] \times 100=-5.59 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 85 A mould cavity of 1200 [latex]cm^3[/latex] volume has to be filled through a sprue of 10 cm length
feeding a horizontal runner. Cross-sectional area at the base of the sprue is 2 [latex]cm^2[/latex].
Consider acceleration due to gravity as 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. Neglecting frictional losses due to
molten metal flow, the time taken to fill the mould cavity is _______ seconds (round off
to 2 decimal places).
solution: Volume of mould cavity [latex](V)=1200 \mathrm{cm}^{3} [/latex] Height of sprue [latex]\left(h_{s}\right)=10 \mathrm{cm} [/latex] Area of sprue at the bottom [latex]\left(A_{s}\right)=2 \mathrm{cm}^{2} [/latex] [latex] g=9.81 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[/latex] Sprue is feed a horizontal runner: Filling time required [latex] \left(t_{t}\right)=? [/latex] By assuming top gate, [latex]A_{g}=A_{s}=A_{3}=2 \mathrm{cm}^{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Filling time }\left(t_{t}\right) &=\frac{V}{A_{g} v_{g}}=\frac{1200}{2 \sqrt{2 \times 981}}=4.28 \mathrm{s} \\ t_{f} &=4.28 \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 86 Two rollers of diameters [latex]D_1[/latex] (in mm) and [latex]D_2[/latex] (in mm) are used to measure the internal
taper angle in the V-groove of a machined component. The heights [latex]H_1[/latex] (in mm) and [latex]H_2[/latex]
(in mm) are measured by using a height gauge after inserting the rollers into the same
V-groove as shown in the figure. Which one of the following is the correct relationship to evaluate the angle [latex]\alpha[/latex] as shown
in the figure?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} O B &=\left(H_{1}-\frac{D_{1}}{2}\right)-\left(H_{2}-\frac{D_{2}}{2}\right)\\ &=\left(H_{1}-H_{2}\right)-\left(\frac{D_{1}-D_{2}}{2}\right) \\ O A &=\frac{D_{1}-D_{2}}{2} \\ \sin \alpha &=\frac{\frac{\left(D_{1}-D_{2}\right)}{2}}{\left(H_{1}-H_{2}\right)-\frac{\left(D_{1}-D_{2}\right)}{2}} \\ \sin \alpha &=\frac{\left(D_{1}-D_{2}\right)}{2\left(H_{1}-H_{2}\right)-\left(D_{1}-D_{2}\right)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 88 Which one of the following statements about a phase diagram is INCORRECT?
solution:
Phase diagram - Useful information: Important information, useful in materials
development and selection, obtainable from a phase
diagram: It shows phases present at different compositions
and temperatures under slow cooling
(equilibrium) conditions. It indicates equilibrium solid solubility of one
element/compound in another. It suggests temperature at which an alloy starts
to solidify and the range of solidifcation. It signals the temperature at which different
phases start to melt. Amount of each phase in a two-phase mixture
can be obtained.

options.A: It indicates the temperature at which different phases start to melt
options.B: Relative amount of different phases can be found under given equilibrium conditions
options.C: It gives information on transformation rates
options.D: Solid solubility limits are depicted by it

question:
Question 89 Two plates, each of 6 mm thickness, are to be butt-welded. Consider the following
processes and select the correct sequence in increasing order of size of the heat affected
zone 1. Arc welding 2. MIG welding 3. Laser beam welding 4. Submerged arc welding
solution:
Processes with low rate of heat input (slow heating) tend to produce high total heat
constant within the metal, slow cooling rates, and large heat-affected zones. high heat
input process, have low total heats, fast cooling rates and small heat affected zones

question: Question 90 The process, that uses a tapered horn to amplify and focus the mechanical energy for machining of glass, is
solution:
In Ultrasonic machining, the function of horn (also
called concentrator, it is a tapered metal bar) is to
amplify and focus vibration of the transducer to an
adequate intensity for driving the tool to fulfll the
cutting operation.

question:
Question 91 The thickness of a steel plate with material strength coefficient of 210 MPa, has to be
reduced from 20 mm to 15 mm in a single pass in a two-high rolling mill with a roll radius
of 450 mm and rolling velocity of 28 m/min. If the plate has a width of 200 mm and
its strain hardening exponent, n is 0.25, the rolling force required for the operation
is____________kN (round off to 2 decimal places). Note: Average Flow Stress = Material Strength Coefficient [latex]\times \frac{(True \; Strain)^n}{(1+n)}[/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { True strain, }\left(\epsilon_{T}\right) &=\ln \left(\frac{h_{f}}{h_{o}}\right) \\ &=\ln \left(\frac{15}{20}\right)=-0.28768 \\ \bar{\sigma}_{o} &=k\left(\frac{\epsilon_{T}^{n}}{1+n}\right) \\ &=210 \times \frac{(0.28768)^{0.25}}{1+0.25}=123.04 \mathrm{MPa} \\ F &=\bar{\sigma}_{o} \times \sqrt{R \Delta h} \times b \\ &=123.04 \times \sqrt{450 \times(20-15)} \times 200 \\ &=1167259.9 \mathrm{N}=1167.26 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 92 In a turning process using orthogonal tool geometry, a chip length of 100 mm is obtained
for an uncut chip length of 250 mm. The cutting conditions are cutting speed = 30 m/min. rake angle=[latex]20^{\circ}[/latex]. The shear plane angle is _________ degrees (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} r &=\frac{l_{C}}{l}=\frac{100}{250}=0.4 \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha}=\frac{0.4 \cos 20^{\circ}}{1-0.4 \times \sin 20^{\circ}}=0.4354 \\ \phi &=\tan ^{-1}(0.4354)=23.5^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 93 A steel part with surface area of 125[latex]cm^2[/latex] is to be chrome coaled through an electroplating
process using chromium acid sulphate as an electrolyte. An increasing current is applied
to the part according to the following current time relation: I = 12 + 0.2t where, I = current (A) and t = time (minutes). The part is submerged in the plating solution
for a duration of 20 minutes for plating purpose. Assuming the cathode efficiency of
chromium to be 15% and the plating constant of chromium acid sulphate to be
[latex]2.50 \times 10^{-2} mm^3/A\cdot s[/latex], the resulting coating thickness on the part surface is _________ [latex]\mu m[/latex] (round off to one decimal place)
solution: [latex]I=12+0.2 t[/latex] After time, 't', Next infinitly small time 'dt' let heat deposited 'dQ '. [latex] \therefore d Q=2.50 \times 10^{-2}\left(\mathrm{mm}^{3} / \mathrm{A} . \mathrm{s}\right) \times 12+0.2 \mathrm{t} \times d t[/latex] As we have to convert this 's' to 'min' [latex] \therefore d Q=2.50 \times 10^{-2}\left(\mathrm{mm}^{3} / \mathrm{A} \times \min \right) \times 12+0.2 \mathrm{t} \times d t[/latex] Considering cathode efficiency of 15% [latex]\begin{aligned} d Q &=2.50 \times 10^{-2} \times 60 \times(12+0.2 t) d t \times 0.15 \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ \therefore \ln 20 \mathrm{min}, \quad Q&=\int d Q\\&=\int_{0}^{20} 2.50 \times 10^{-2} \times 60 \times(12+0.2 t) d t \times 0.15 \\ &=0.225\left[12+0.1 t^{2}\right]_{0}^{20}\\ &=0.225\left[12 \times 20+0.1 \times 20^{2}\right] \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ &=63 \mathrm{mm}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] As area os 125 [latex]\mathrm{cm}^{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \text { Plating thickness, } t=\frac{63}{125 \times(100)}=0.00504 \mathrm{mm}=5.04 \mu \mathrm{m} \\ (\text { As } 1 \mathrm{cm}^{2}=100 \mathrm{mm}^{2} )\end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 94 The following data applies to basic shaft system: tolerance for hole = 0.002 mm, tolerance for shaft = 0.001 mm, allowance = 0.003 mm, basic size = 50 mm. The maximum hole size is ______ mm (round off to 3 decimal places).
solution: Using diagram method UL of hole = BS + 0.003 + 0.002 mm = 50.005 mm

question:
Question 95 A slot of 25 mm x 25 mm is to be milled in a workpiece of 300 mm length using a
side and face milling cutter of diameter 100 mm, width 25 mm and having 20 teeth. For a depth of cut 5 mm, feed per tooth 0.1 mm, cutting speed 35 m/min and approach
and over travel distance of 5 mm each, the time required for milling the slot is_______
minutes (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V &=\pi D N \\ 35 &=\pi \times 0.100 \times N \\ N &=\pi \times 111.408 \mathrm{rpm} \\ &=\frac{L+\frac{D}{2}+A+O}{f Z N}=\frac{300+\frac{100}{2}+5+5}{0.1 \times 20 \times 111.408} \\ &=1.6157 \mathrm{min} \text { per pass } \end{aligned}[/latex] For [latex]25 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] cuts min [latex]5 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] depth of cut 5 pass needed Total machining time [latex]=8.078 \mathrm{min} \simeq 8.1 \mathrm{min}[/latex]

question:
Question 96 A strip of thickness 40 mm is to be rolled to a thickness of 20 mm using a two-high
mill having rolls of diameter 200 mm. Coefficient of friction and arc length in mm,
respectively are
solution: [latex]h_{0}=40 \mathrm{mm}, h_{f}=20 \mathrm{mm}, \Delta h=40-20=20 \mathrm{mm}, D=200 \mathrm{mm}, R=100 \mathrm{mm}[/latex][latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Projected length, } \quad L&=\sqrt{R \Delta h}\\ &=\sqrt{100 \times 20} \\ &=\sqrt{2000}=44.7213 \mathrm{mm} \\ \Delta h&=\mu^{2} R \\ \therefore \quad 20 &=\mu^{2} \cdot 100 \\ \therefore \quad 2.0 &=\mu^{2} \\ \mu &=0.4472 \end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 97 A sheet metal with a stock hardness of 250 HRC has to be sheared using a punch and
a die having a clearance of 1 mm between them. If the stock hardness of the sheet
metal increases to 400 HRC, the clearance between the punch and the die should
be_________ mm.
solution: Tensile strength [latex]\propto[/latex] Hardness number [latex]\therefore[/latex] Shear strength =0.5 tensile strength (Tresca theory) =0.577 tensile strength (Von mises theory) Shear strength [latex]\propto[/latex] Hardness number [latex] \begin{aligned} &\text{and clearance, } \\ C &=0.0032 t \sqrt{\tau} \\ C & \propto \sqrt{\text { Hardness number }} \\ \frac{C_{2}}{C_{1}} &=\sqrt{\frac{(\text { Hardness number })_{2}}{(\text { Hardness number })_{1}}} \\ \text{or}\quad C_{2} &=1 \times \sqrt{\frac{400}{250}}=1.265 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

grinding wheel grade specification is

question: Question 99 Match The Following
solution:
Tempering is a process of heat treating, which is
used to increase the toughness of iron-based alloys. Quench hardening is a mechanical process in which
steel and cast iron alloys are strengthened and
hardened. Annealing is a process involving heating and
cooling, usually applied to produce softening of the
metal to facilitate machining or forming operations. Normalising is used to improve the mechanical
properties of, mainly, unalloyed and low-alloy
structural steel and cast steel.

question: Question 100 The crystal structure of [latex]\gamma[/latex] iron (austenite phase) is
solution:
Austenite has a cubic-close packed crystal structure,
also referred to as a face-centred cubic structure
with an atom at each corner and in the centre of
each face of the unit cell.

question: Question 101 In an orthogonal machining with a single point cutting tool of rake angle [latex]10^{\circ}[/latex], the uncut chip thickness and the chip thickness are 0.125mm and 0.22mm,respectively. Using Merchant's first solution for the condition of minimum cutting force, the coefficient of friction at the chip-tool interface is ______ (round off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \alpha=10^{\circ}, t_{l}=0.125, \quad t_{2}=0.22 \\ r=\frac{0.125}{0.22}=0.57 \\ \text { shear angle, } \phi=\tan ^{-1}\left[\frac{r \cos \alpha_{0}}{1-r \sin \alpha_{0}}\right] \\ \qquad \begin{aligned} \phi &=\tan ^{-1}\left[\frac{0.57 \cos 10}{1-0.57 \sin 10}\right] \\ \phi &=31.8 \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex] From Merchant's [latex]I^{\text {st}}[/latex] solution [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 \phi+\beta-\alpha_{0}=90 & \\ \beta=90+\alpha_{0}-2 \phi &=90+10-2 \times 31.8 \\ &=36.4^{0} \end{aligned}[/latex] Coefficient of friction, [latex] \mu=\tan \beta=\tan 36.4=0.737[/latex]

question: Question 102 A through hole is drilled in an aluminum alloy plate of 15 mm thickness with a drill bit of diameter 10 mm, at a feed of 0.25 mm/rev and a spindle speed of 1200 rpm. If the specific energy required for cutting this material is 0.7 [latex]N\cdot m/mm^3[/latex], the power required for drilling is______W (round off to two decimal places).
solution: Given data [latex] \begin{array}{l} \mathrm{t}=\text { thickness }=15 \mathrm{mm} \\ \mathrm{d}=\operatorname{dia} \text { of drill }=10 \mathrm{mm} \\ \mathrm{f}=0.25 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{rev} \\ \text { Speed, } \mathrm{N}=1200 \mathrm{rpm} \\ \text { Specific cutting energy }=0.7 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ \text { S.P.C.E. }=\frac{\text { Power }}{\mathrm{MRR}} \\ \text { Power }=\mathrm{MRR} \times \mathrm{S.P.C.E} \\ =\text { Area of drill } \times(\mathrm{Feed} / \mathrm{sec}) \times \mathrm{S.P.C.E}\\=\frac{\pi}{4} \mathrm{d}^{2} \times \frac{\mathrm{f}}{60} \times \mathrm{N} \times \mathrm{S.P.C.E} \\ =\frac{\pi}{4} \times 10^{2} \times \frac{0.25}{60} \times 1200 \times 0.7=274.75 \mathrm{W}  \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 103 The thickness of a sheet is reduced by rolling (without any change in width) using 600mm diameter rolls. Neglect elastic deflection of the rolls and assume that the coefficient of friction at the roll-workpiece interface is 0.05. The sheetenters the rotating rolls unaided. If the initial sheet thickness is 2mm, the minimum possible final thickness that can be produced by this process in a single pass is ______mm(round off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} (\Delta \mathrm{h})_{\max }=\mu^{2} \mathrm{R} \\ \mu=0.05, \mathrm{R}=300 \mathrm{mm} \\ (\Delta \mathrm{h})_{\max }=0.05^{2} \times 300=0.75 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Minimum possible final thickness }=\mathrm{h}_{0}-(\Delta \mathrm{h})_{\max } \\ =2-0.75=1.25 \mathrm{mm} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 104 A gas tungsten arc welding operation is performed using a current of 250A and an arc voltage of 20V at a welding speed of 5mm/s. Assuming that the arc efficiency is 70%, the net heat input per unit length of the weld will be ______kJ/mm(round off to one decimal place).
solution: GTAW, current [latex] \mathrm{I}=250 \mathrm{A} [/latex] Voltage, [latex] \mathrm{V}=20 \mathrm{V}, [/latex] Speed, [latex] v=5 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{sec} [/latex] Arc efficiency, [latex] \eta=0.7 [/latex] Duty cycle, D=1 (not given) Heat input per unit length, [latex] \frac{\mathrm{H}}{\ell}=\frac{\eta \mathrm{D} \mathrm{VI}}{v} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{0.7 \times 1 \times 250 \times 20}{5} \\ =700 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{mm}=0.7 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{mm} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 105 The figure shows a pouring arrangement for casting of a metal block. Frictional losses are negligible. The acceleration due to gravity is 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. The time (in s, round off to two decimal places) to fill up the mold cavity (of size 40 cm x 30 cm x 15 cm) is___
solution: [latex]\frac{\text { Volume }}{\mathrm{t}}=\mathrm{A}_{\mathrm{c}} \sqrt{2 \mathrm{gh}_{\mathrm{c}}} [/latex] At point (3) is open to atmosphere so (3) is the choke. [latex] \mathrm{g}=9.81 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec}^{2}=981 \mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{sec}^{2} \\ \frac{40 \times 30 \times 15}{\mathrm{t}}=\frac{\pi}{4} \times 2^{2} \sqrt{2 \times 981 \times 20} \Rightarrow \frac{18000}{\mathrm{t}}=622.32088 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \mathrm{t}=28.923 \mathrm{sec}[/latex]

question: Question 106 The binary phase diagram of metals P and Q is shown in the figure. An alloy X containing 60% P and 40% Q (by weight) is cooled from liquid to solid state. The fractions of solid and liquid (in weight percent) at [latex]1250^{\circ}C[/latex], respectively, will be
solution: Lever line : [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Mass friction of solid }&=\frac{c_{o}-c_{L}}{c_{s}-c_{L}} \\ &=\frac{40-32}{68-32} \\ \mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{s}}&=\frac{8}{36}=0.2222 \approx 22.2 \% \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Mass friction of liquid }&=\frac{c_{s}-c_{o}}{c_{s}-c_{L}} \\ &=\frac{68-40}{68-32} \\ \left(\mathrm{m}_{\ell}\right)&=\frac{28}{36}=0.777 \approx 77.8 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 107 In an electrical discharge machining process, the breakdown voltage across inter electrode gap (IEG) is 200 V and the capacitance of the RC circuit is 50 [latex]\mu F[/latex]. The energy (in J) released per spark across the IEG is___
solution: [latex]\text { Energy released }=\frac{1}{2} C V^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times 50 \times 10^{-6} \times(200)^{2}=1 J[/latex]

question: Question 108 The most common limit gage used for inspecting the hole diameter is
solution: Plug gauges used for hole & Ring gauge used for shaft

question: Question 109 The cold forming process in which a hardened tool is pressed against a workpiece (when there is relative motion between the tool and the workpiece) to produce a roughened surface with a regular pattern is
solution:
Knurling is the process of producing a straight angled cross lines by rolling using lathe machine.
It is done by using one or more hard rollers that contain reverse of the pattern to be imposed.

question: Question 110 The fluidity of molten metal of cast alloys (without any addition of fluxes) increases with increase in
solution: Fluidity increases with increase of degree of super heat.

question: Question 111 Hardenability of steel is a measure of
solution:
It is the depth to which required hardening is obtained when it is austenitized and then quenched.
Hardenability is the ability of steel to form marteniste. The greater the hardenability the more
martensite.

options.A: the ability to harden when it is cold worked
options.B: the maximum hardness that can be obtained when it is austenitized and then quenched
options.C: the depth to which required hardening is obtained when it isaustenitized and then quenched
options.D: the ability to retain its hardness when it is heated to elevated temperatures

question: Question 112 Taylor's tool life equation is given by [latex]VT^n=C[/latex], where V is in m/min and T is in min. In a turning operation, two tools X and Y are used. For tool X, n = 0.3 and C= 60 and for tool Y, n = 0.6 and C = 90. Both the tools will have the same tool life for the cutting speed (in m/min, round off to one decimal place) of____
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{x}} \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{x}}^{0.3}=60 \ldots(1)\\ \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{Y}} \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{Y}}^{0.6}=90 \ldots(2)\\ \text { Diving }(2) \mathrm{by}(1) \\ \mathrm{T}_{0}^{0.3}=1.5 \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{T}_{0}=(1.5)^{1 / 0.3}=3.85 \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{V}_{0} \times(3.85)^{0.3}=60 \Rightarrow \mathrm{V}_{0}=40 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 113 In ASA system, the side cutting and end cutting edge angles of a sharp turning tool are [latex]45^{\circ} \; and \; 10^{\circ}[/latex], respectively. The feed during cylindrical turning is 0.1 mm/rev. The center line average surface roughness (in [latex]\mu m[/latex], round off to one decimal place) of the generated surface is____
solution: Peak to valley height [latex] h_{\max }=\frac{f}{\tan C_{s}+\cot C_{e}} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{s}}=\mathrm{S} . \mathrm{C} . \mathrm{E} . \mathrm{A}, \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{c}}=\mathrm{E} . \mathrm{C} . \mathrm{E} . \mathrm{A} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow h_{\max }=\frac{0.1}{\tan 45^{\circ}+\cot 10^{\circ}} [/latex] [latex] h_{\max }=\frac{0.1}{1+5.67}=0.015 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] The approximate value of centre line average [latex] R_{a}=\frac{h_{\max }}{4}=\frac{0.015}{4}=0.00375 \mathrm{mm}=3.75 \mu \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 114 Match the following sand mold casting defects with their respective causes.
solution: Blow hole [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Poor Permeability Misrun [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Insufficient Fluidity Hot tearing [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Poor Collapsibility Wash [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Mold erosion

question: Question 115 A circular shaft having diameter [latex]65.00_{-0.05}^{+0.01}[/latex] mm is manufactured by turning process. A 50 [latex]\mu m[/latex] thick coating of TiN is deposited on the shaft. Allowed variation in TiN film thickness is [latex]\pm 5\mu m[/latex]. The minimum hole diameter (in mm) to just provide clearance fit is
solution:
Shaft  [latex]65_{-0.05}^{+0.01} \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Locating  [latex]\rightarrow 0.05 \pm 0.005 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] [latex]
U.L=65.01+2 \times 0.055=65.12 [/latex] [latex]
L \cdot \mathrm{L}=64.95+2 \times 0.045=65.04 [/latex] Min hole dia to provide clearance fit is Upper limit of shaft after coating i.e.  =65.12mm

question: Question 116 In orthogonal turning of a cylindrical tube of wall thickness 5 mm, the axial and the tangential cutting forces were measured as 1259 N and 1601 N, respectively. The measured chip thickness after machining was found to be 0.3 mm. The rake angle was [latex]10^{\circ}[/latex] and the axial feed was 100 mm/min. The rotational speed of the spindle was 1000 rpm.  Assuming the material to be perfectly plastic and Merchant's first solution, the shear strength of the material is closest to
solution: Axial cutting force = Feed Force [latex]=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{F}}=1259 \mathrm{N} [/latex] Tangental Force [latex]=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{c}}=1601 \mathrm{N} [/latex] Chip thickness [latex]=\mathrm{t}_{2}=0.3 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Rake angle [latex]\alpha_{0}=10^{\circ} [/latex] Feed [latex]=100 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{min} [/latex] Rotational speed [latex]=1000 \mathrm{rpm} [/latex] Feed in [latex]\mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{rev}, \mathrm{f}=\frac{100}{1000}=0.1 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{rev} [/latex] Shear strength [latex]=\tau_{\mathrm{s}}=? [/latex] since S.C.E A is not mentioned therefore it can be assumed to be zero [latex]\therefore[/latex] S.C.E.A [latex]\psi_{\mathrm{s}}=0[/latex] and hence feed = uncut thickness =[latex]t_{1}=0.1 \mathrm{mm} \mathrm{s} [/latex] [latex]\therefore [/latex] Chip thickness ratio r [latex]=\frac{\mathrm{t}_{1}}{\mathrm{t}_{2}}=\frac{0.1}{0.3}[/latex] since S.C.E.A [latex]\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{S}}=0 [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Feed force = Thrust Force [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{T}}=1259 \mathrm{N} \\ \mathrm{r}=\frac{\mathrm{t}_{1}}{\mathrm{t}_{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{f}}{\mathrm{t}_{2}}=\frac{0.1}{0.3}=0.333 \\ \tan \phi=\frac{\mathrm{r} \cos \alpha}{1-\mathrm{r} \sin \alpha}=\frac{0.333 \cos 10}{1-0.333 \sin 10} \\ \Rightarrow \phi=19.19^{\circ} \end{array}[/latex] In [latex]\Delta OBC[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \tan (\beta-\alpha)=\frac{\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{T}}}{\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{C}}}=\frac{1259}{1601} \\ \Rightarrow \beta-\alpha=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{1259}{1601}\right)=38.18^{\circ} \end{array}[/latex] From [latex]\Delta \mathrm{OAC} [/latex] [latex] \text { Shear Force } \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{S}}=\mathrm{R} \cos (\phi+\beta-\alpha) [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\sqrt{1601^{2}+1259^{2}} \cos (19.19+38.18) \\ =2036.73 \times 0.44 \\ =1098.22 \mathrm{N} \end{array}[/latex] Assuming whole thickness of tube is being turned: width of cut = thickness of Tube [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \mathrm{w}=5 \mathrm{mm} \\ \Rightarrow \text { Shear Strength }=\frac{\text { Shear Force }}{\text { Shear Area }}=\frac{\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{s}}}{\left(\mathrm{w} \times \mathrm{t}_{1}\right) / \sin \phi} \\ = \frac{1098.22 \sin 19.19}{5 \times 0.1}=721.98 \approx 722 \mathrm{MPa} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 117 The length, width and thickness of a steel sample are 400 mm, 40 mm and 20 mm, respectively. Its thickness needs to be uniformly reduced by 2 mm in a single pass by using horizontal slab milling. The milling cutter (diameter: 100 mm, width: 50 mm) has 20 teeth and rotates at 1200 rpm. The feed per tooth is 0.05 mm. The feed direction is along the length of the sample. If the over-travel distance is the same as the approach distance, the approach distance and time taken to complete the required machining task are
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \begin{aligned} \text { Approach } &=\sqrt{d(D-d)}\\&=\sqrt{2(100-2)} \\ &=\sqrt{196}=14 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned} \\ \text { Here, } \mathrm{AP}=\mathrm{OR}=14 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Machine time }=\frac{L+A P+O R}{f Z N}=\frac{400+14+14}{0.05 \times 20 \times 1200} \\ =0.356 \mathrm{min}=21.4 \mathrm{sec} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 118 Which one of the following welding methods provides the highest heat flux ([latex]W/mm^2[/latex])?
solution:
Heat flux means power input in terms of heat per unit area. It will be maximum in Laser beam
welding.

question: Question 119 In a casting process, a vertical channel through which molten metal flows downward from pouring basin to runner for reaching the mold cavity is called
solution: Vertical channel is called sprue and the horizontal channel is called runner

question:
Question 120 A welding operation is being performed with voltage = 30 V and current = 100 A. The
cross-sectional area of the weld bead is 20 [latex]mm^{2}[/latex]. The work-piece and filler are of titanium
for which the specific energy of melting is 14 J/[latex]mm^{3}[/latex]. Assuming a thermal efficiency of the
welding process 70%, the welding speed (in mm/s) is __________ (correct to two decimal
places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Welding speed } (\mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{s})&=?\\ \text { Effective power } &=\eta_{\mathrm{th}} \times(\mathrm{Vl}) \\ &=0.7 \times 30 \times 100=2100 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{S} \\ \text { Sp.engery } &=\frac{\text { Power }}{A \times V} \\ V &=\frac{\text { Power }}{\text { sp.energy } \times \mathrm{A}} \\ &=\frac{2100}{14 \times 20}=7.5 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

[latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{MRR}&=4 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{IT}^{-1.23} \mathrm{mm}^{3} / \mathrm{min}\\ &\text{Volume required to remove}\\ &=\frac{\pi}{4} D^{2} L=\frac{\pi}{4} \times 25^{2} \times 20 \\ &=9817.477 \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ \text { Now, }\qquad \mathrm{MRP}&=4 \times 10^{4} \times I \times T^{-1.23} \\ &=4 \times 10^{4} \times 300 \times(1600)^{-1.23} \\ &=3 \times 4 \times 10^{6} \times(1600)^{-1.23} \\ &=1374.40 \mathrm{mm}^{3} / \mathrm{min} \\ \text { Time required } &=\frac{9817.477}{1374.4} \\ &=7.1431 \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 122 For sand-casting a steel rectangular plate with dimensions 80 mm [latex]\times[/latex]  120 mm [latex]\times[/latex]  20 mm, a
cylindrical riser has to be designed. The height of the riser is equal to its diameter. The total
solidification time for the casting is 2 minutes. In Chvorinov's law for the estimation of the
total solidification time, exponent is to be taken as 2. For a solidification time of 3 minutes
in the riser, the diameter (in mm) of the riser is __________ (correct to two decimal
places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { casting } \operatorname{size} &=80 \times 120 \times 20 \mathrm{mm} \\ \left(t_{s}\right)_{\text {casting }} &=2 \mathrm{min} \\ \left(t_{s}\right)_{\text {riser }} &=3 \mathrm{min} \\ 2 &=k\left(\frac{80 \times 120 \times 20}{2(80 \times 120+120 \times 20+20 \times 80)}\right)^{2}\\ k &=0.040138 \mathrm{min} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \text { Riser : } \left(t_{S}\right)_{\text {riser }}&=k\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)^{2} \\ 3 &=0.040138\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)^{2} \\ \left(\frac{V}{A}\right) &=8.64 \\ \frac{d}{6} &=8.64\\ \text{Riser if } h&=d \text{ then }\frac{V}{A}=\frac{d}{6} \\ \frac{V}{A}&=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} h}{2 \frac{\pi}{4} d^{2}+\pi d h}\\ \text{If } h=d, \text{ then }\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)&=\frac{d}{6} \\ h=d&=51.84 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 123 Taylor's tool life equation is used to estimate the life of a batch of identical HSS twist drills
by drilling through holes at constant feed in 20 mm thick mild steel plates. In test 1, a drill
lasted 300 holes at 150 rpm while in test 2, another drill lasted 200 holes at 300 rpm. The
maximum number of holes that can be made by another drill from the above batch at 200
rpm is ______ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: Time required for drilling a hole [latex] t=\frac{L}{f N}[/latex] Here 'L' const. 'f const, N is variable. [latex] \begin{array}{l} V_{1}=\pi D \times 150 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \\ T_{1}=300 \times \frac{L}{f \times 150} \mathrm{min}\\ V_{2}=\pi D \times 300 \mathrm{min} \\ T_{2}=200 \times \frac{L}{f \times 300} \mathrm{min} \\ V_{3}=\pi D \times 200 \mathrm{min} \\ T_{3}=x \times \frac{L}{f \times 200} \mathrm{min}\qquad \text{[No. of hole is 'x'] }\\ V_{1} T_{1}^{n}=V_{2} T_{2}^{n} \end{array}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \pi D \times 150 \times\left(300 \times \frac{L}{f \times 150}\right)^{n} &=\pi D \times 300 \times\left(200 \times \frac{L}{f \times 300}\right)^{n} \\ \text{Or,}\quad2^{n} &=2\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{n} \\ \text{Or,}\quad 3^{n}&=2 \\ n &=0.63093 \\ V_{1} T_{1}^{n} &=V_{3} T_{3}^{n} \\ \pi D \times 150 \times\left(300 \times \frac{L}{f \times 150}\right)^{0.63093} &=\pi D \times 200 \times\left(x \times \frac{L}{f \times 200}\right)^{0.63093} \\ 3 \times 2^{0.63093} &=4 \times\left(\frac{x}{200}\right)^{0.63093} \\ \Rightarrow & x=253.53 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 124 Following data correspond to an orthogonal turning of a 100 mm diameter rod on a lathe.
Rake angle:[latex]+15^{\circ}[/latex] ; Uncut chip thickness: 0.5 mm; nominal chip thickness after the cut: 1.25
mm. The shear angle (in degrees) for this process is _______ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \alpha &=15^{\circ} \\ t &=0.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ t_{c} &=1.25 \mathrm{mm} \\ r &=\frac{t}{t_{c}}=\frac{0.5}{1.25}=0.4 \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha}=\frac{0.4 \cos 15}{1-0.4 \sin 15} \\ \phi &=23.3155^{\circ} \approx 23.32^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 125 A steel wire is drawn from an initial diameter([latex]d_{i}[/latex]) of 10 mm to a final diameter ([latex]d_{f}[/latex]) of 7.5
mm. The half cone angle ([latex]\alpha[/latex]) of the die is [latex]5^{\circ}[/latex] and the coefficient of friction ([latex]\mu[/latex]) between the die and the wire is 0.1. The average of the initial and final yield stress [latex][(\sigma_{Y}) _{avg}][/latex]  is 350
MPa. The equation for drawing stress [latex]\sigma_{f}[/latex], (in MPa) is given as : [latex]\sigma _{f}=(\sigma _{Y})_{avg}\left \{ 1+\frac{1}{\mu cot \alpha } \right \}\left [ 1-{\left (\frac{d_{f}}{d_{i}}\right )}^{2\mu cot\alpha } \right ][/latex] The drawing stress (in MPa) required to carry out this operation is _________ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} d_{i} &=10 \mathrm{mm} \\ d_{f} &=7.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ \alpha &=5^{\circ} \\ \mu &=0.1 \\ (\sigma y)_{\mathrm{avg}} &=350 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \sigma_{f} &=\left(\sigma_{y}\right)_{\mathrm{avg}} \times\left\{1+\frac{1}{\mu \cot \alpha}\right\}\left[1-\left(\frac{d_{f}}{d_{i}}\right)^{2 \mu \cot \alpha}\right] \\ &=350 \times\left[1+\frac{1}{0.1 \mathrm{cot} 5}\right]\left[1-\left(\frac{7.5}{10}\right)^{2 \times 0.1 \times \cot 5}\right] \\ &=316.2472 \mathrm{MPa} \approx 316.25 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 126 The preferred option for holding an odd-shaped workpiece in a centre lathe is
solution:
4 jaw independently adjusted chuck are used to hold and support a wide variety
of workpiece including odd shaped workpiece. Practically odd shaped job can be mounted on a face plate. But this is not given
as option. Lathe dog may be used on round, square, rectangular and odd-shaped workpieces
but most appropriate is option (D).

solution:

question: Question 128 Feed rate in slab milling operation is equal to
solution: Feed rate in slab milling operation  [latex]=f_{m} [/latex] [latex]f_{m}=f_{t} Z N[/latex] where,  [latex]f_{t}=[/latex] feed per tooth Z=  number of teeth in cutter N=r p m

options.B: product of rpm and number of teeth in the cutter

question: Question 132 An electrochemical machining (ECM) is to be used to cut a through hole into a 12 mm thick aluminum plate. The hole has a rectangular cross-section, [latex]10 mm \times 30 mm[/latex]. The ECM operation will be accomplished in 2 minutes, with efficiency of 90%. Assuming specific removal rate for aluminum as [latex]3.44 \times 10^{-2} mm^{3}/(As)[/latex] , the current (in A)  required is __________ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: Volume of metal to be removed [latex] \begin{aligned} &=(10 \times 30) \times 12 \mathrm{mm}^{3}=3600 \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ \text { Ideal energy required } &=\frac{3600 \mathrm{mm}^{3}}{3.44 \times 10^{-2} \frac{\mathrm{mm}^{3}}{(\mathrm{A} s)}}=104651.163 \mathrm{As} \\ \text { Actual energy required } &=\frac{104651.163}{0.9} \mathrm{As} \\ &=116279.07 \mathrm{As} \\ \text { Time is } 2 \mathrm{min} &=120 \mathrm{s} \\ \therefore \qquad \text { Current }&=\frac{116279.07}{120} \mathrm{A}=968.992 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 133 An orthogonal cutting operation is being carried out in which uncut thickness is 0.010 mm, cutting speed is 130 m/min, rake angle is [latex]15^{\circ}[/latex]  and width of cut is 6 mm. It is observed that the chip thickness is 0.015 mm, the cutting force is 60 N and the thrust force is 25 N. The ratio of friction energy to total energy is __________ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} t &=0.010 \mathrm{mm} \\ v &=130 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \\ \alpha &=15^{\circ} \\ b &=6 \mathrm{mm} \\ t_{c} &=0.015 \mathrm{mm} \\ F_{c} &=60 \mathrm{N} \\ F_{t} &=25 \mathrm{N} \\ F &=F_{c} \sin \alpha+F_{t} \cos \alpha \\ &=60 \sin 15+25 \cos 15=39.6773 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex] Ratio of frictional energy to total energy [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{F}{F_{C}} \cdot \frac{V_{C}}{V}=\frac{F}{F_{C}}\left(\frac{t}{t_{C}}\right) \qquad \left[\therefore \; \frac{t}{t_{C}}=\frac{V_{C}}{V}=r \right] \\ =\frac{39.6773}{60} \times \frac{0.010}{0.015}=0.4408 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 134 The percentage scrap in a sheet metal blanking operation of a continuous strip of sheet metal as shown in the figure is _______ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: This rectangle ABCD will be repeated again and again. [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{t}&=\text { Total Area }=\frac{7}{5} D \times \frac{6}{5} D=\frac{42}{25} D^{2} \\ A_{u}&=\text { Area of blanking Disc }=\frac{\pi D^{2}}{4}\\ \% \text { of scrap } &=\frac{A_{t}-A_{v}}{A_{t}} \times 100 \% \\ &=\left[1-\frac{\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)}{\left(\frac{42}{25}\right)}\right] \times 100 \%=53.25 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 135 The maximum reduction in cross-sectional area per pass ( R ) of a cold wire drawing process is [latex]R=1-e^{-(n+1)}[/latex] where n represents the strain hardening coefficient. For the case of a perfectly plastic  material, R is
solution: [latex]\sigma_{d}=\sigma_{0} \ln \frac{A_{0}}{A_{f}}[/latex] For maximum reduction [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{d} &=\sigma_{0} \\ \sigma_{0} &=\sigma_{0} \ln \frac{A_{0}}{A_{f, \min }} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad 1&=\ln \left(\frac{A_{0}}{A_{f, \min }}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \frac{A_{0}}{A_{f, \min }} &=e=2.71828 \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum reduction in Area [latex] R=\frac{A_{0}-A_{f, \min }}{A_{0}}=\left(1-\frac{1}{e}\right)=\left(1-\frac{1}{2.71828}\right)=0.632[/latex]

question: Question 136 The height (in mm) for a 125 mm sine bar to measure a taper of  [latex]27^{\circ}{32}'[/latex]  on a flat work piece is _______ (correct to three decimal places).
solution: (57.782) [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta &=27^{\circ} 32^{\prime} \\ &=27+\left(\frac{32}{60}\right)^{\circ}=27.533^{\circ} \\ \text{In sine bar,}\quad \sin \theta &=\frac{H}{L}\\ \therefore \quad \sin 27.533^{\circ} &=\frac{H}{125} \\ H &=57.782427 \\ H & \approx 57.782 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 137 The number of atoms per unit cell and the number of slip systems, respectively, for a face-centered cubic (FCC) crystal are
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline \text {Unit cell} & N & C N & \text {a/R} & \text {APF} \\ \hline \text {Simple cubic} & 1 & 6 & 2 & 0.52 \\ \hline \text {Body centered cubic} & 2 & 8 & \frac{4}{\sqrt{3}} & 0.68 \\ \hline \text {Face centered cubic} & 4 & 12 & \frac{4}{\sqrt{2}} & 0.74 \\ \hline \text { Hexagonal close packed } & 6 & 12 & \begin{array}{l} a / \mathrm{R}=2 \\ \mathrm{c} / \mathrm{a}=1.633 \end{array} & 0.74 \\ \hline \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 138 Interpolator in a CNC machine
solution: As interpolator provides two functions: 1. It computes individual axis velocities to drive the tool along the programmed path at given feed rate. 2. It generates intermediate coordinate positions along the programmed path.

Question 142 In an orthogonal machining with a tool of [latex]9^{\circ}[/latex] orthogonal rake angle, the uncut chip thickness is 0.2mm. The chip thickness fluctuates between 0.25 mm and 0.4 mm. The ratio of the maximum shear angel to the minimum shear angle during machining is _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given} \quad\alpha &=9^{\circ} \\ t &=0.2 \mathrm{mm} \\ t_{c \max } &=0.4 \mathrm{mm} \\ t_{c \min } &=0.25 \mathrm{mm} \\ \tan \phi_{\max } &=\frac{r_{\max } \cos \alpha}{1-r_{\max } \sin \alpha}=\frac{\frac{0.2}{0.25} \cos 9^{\circ}}{1-\frac{0.2}{0.25} \sin 9}\\ \text{or }\quad \phi_{\max } &=42.09^{\circ} \\ \tan \phi_{\min } &=\frac{r_{\min } \cos \alpha}{1-r_{\min } \sin \alpha}=\frac{\frac{0.2}{0.4} \cos 9^{\circ}}{1-\frac{0.2}{0.4} \sin 9^{\circ}}\\ \text{or}\quad \phi_{\mathrm{min}} &=28.18^{\circ} \\ \text { Ratio } &=\frac{\phi_{\max }}{\phi_{\min }}=\frac{42.09}{28.18}=1.494 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 143 During the turning of a 20mm-diameter steel bar at a spindle speed of 400 rpm, a tool life of 20 minute is obtained. When the same bar is turned at 200 rpm, the tool life become 60 minute. Assume that Taylor's tool life equation is valid. When the bar is turned at 300 rpm, the tool lidfe (in minute) is approximately.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{1}=\pi D \times 400 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} ; & T_{1}=20 \mathrm{min} \\ V_{2}=\pi D \times 200 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} ; & T_{2}=60 \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now using Taylor's equation [latex] \begin{array}{l} \qquad V_{1} T_{1}^{n}=V_{2} T_{2}^{n} \\ \text { or } \pi D \times 400 \times(20)^{n}=\pi D \times 200 \times 60^{\text {n }} \\ \text { or } \quad n=0.6309\\ \text { and } \quad V_{3}=\pi D \times 300 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} ; \quad T_{3}=?\\ \qquad V_{1} T_{1}^{n}=V_{2} T_{2}^{n}=V_{3} T_{3}^{n} \\ \pi D \times 400 \times(20)^{0.6309}=\pi D \times 300 \times T_{3}^{0.6309} \\ \therefore \quad T_{3}=31.55 \mathrm{min} \approx 32 \mathrm{min} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 144 A cylindrical pin of [latex]25_{+0.020}^{+0.010}\,mm[/latex]  diameter is electroplated. Plating thickness is [latex]2.0^{\pm 0.005}[/latex] mm.Neglecting the gauge tolerance, the diameter (in mm, up to 3 decimal points accuracy) of the GO ring gauge to inspect the plated pin is _______
solution: GO ring gauge will inspect maximum metal conditions i.e. UL of shaft i.e. Largest size after platting. UL after platting [latex] =25.02+2.005+2.005 \mathrm{mm}=  29.030 \mathrm{mm} [/latex]

question: Question 145 A strip of 120 mm width and 8 mm thickness is rolled between two 300 mm-diameter rolls to get a strip of 120 mm width and 7.2 mm thickness. The speed of the strip at the exit is 30 m/min. There is no front or back tension. Assuming uniform roll pressure of 200 MPa in the roll bite and 100% mechanical efficiency, the minimum total power (in kW) required to drive the two roll is _______.
solution: Method-1: Projected length, [latex] \begin{aligned} L_{p} &=R \sin \alpha \approx \sqrt{R \Delta h} \\ &=\sqrt{150 \times(8-7.2)}=10.954 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Projected Area, [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{p} &=L_{p} \times b=10.954 \times 120 \\ &=1314.48 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Roll Separating Force, [latex] \begin{aligned} F &=\sigma_{0} \times L_{p} \times b N \\ &=200 \times 1314.48 \mathrm{N}=262.9 \mathrm{kN}\\ &\left[\sigma_{o} \text { in } N / m m^{2} \text { i.e. } M P a\right] \\ \text{ Arm length (a in mm)}&=0.5 L_{p} \text{for hot rolling}\\ &=0.5 \times 10.954 \mathrm{mm}=5.477 \mathrm{mm}\\ &=0.45 L_{p} \;\text{for cold rolling }\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Torque per roller, [latex] \begin{aligned} T &=F \times \frac{a}{1000} \mathrm{Nm} \\ &=262.9 \mathrm{kN} \times 5.477 \mathrm{mm} \\ &=1439.9 \mathrm{Nm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total power for two roller, [latex] P=2 T \omega \text { in } W=2 T \times \frac{2 \pi N}{60}[/latex] For the calculation of N we need velocity of  neutral plane Continuity equation [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{0} b_{0} v_{0} &=h_{f} b_{f} v_{f} \\ 8 \times 120 \times v_{0} &=7.2 \times 120 \times 30 \\ \text{or}\quad v_{0} &=27 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex] Assuming velocity of neutral plane average velocity, [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=\frac{V_{0}+V_{f}}{2}=\frac{27+30}{2} \\ &=28.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min}\\ \text{Now,}V&=\pi D N\\ \text{or}\quad 28.5&=\pi \times 0.300 \times N\\ \text{or}\quad N&=30.24 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]  Total power for two roller, [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=2 T \times \frac{2 \pi N}{60} \\ &=2 \times 1439.9 \times \frac{2 \times \pi \times 30.24}{60} \mathrm{W} \\ &=9.1195 \mathrm{kW} \approx 9.12 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex] Method-II : Velocity at the neutral plane =? [latex] \begin{aligned} H_{n} V_{n}&=H_{2} V_{2} \quad(\text { Applying continuity }) \\ H_{n}&=H_{2}+0.25 \Delta H\\ &\text{(Standard relation)}\\ &=7.2+0.25 \times 0.8=7.4 \mathrm{mm} \\ V_{n}&=\frac{\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{V}_{2}}{\mathrm{H}_{n}}=29.19 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \\ N&=\frac{29.19 \times 1000}{\pi \times 300}=30.98 \mathrm{rpm}\\ \text{total power }&=2 T \omega \\ &=2 \times 1439.9 \times 2 \pi \frac{30.98}{60} \\ &=9.34 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: In metal forming there will be increased mechanical properties due to change in grain size and work hardening.

question: Question 149 Which one of the following statements is TRUE for the ultrasonic machining (USM) process?
solution: Ultrasonic Machining uses an abrasive slurry which transfers the impact load provided by the vibrating tool to the work piece.

question: Question 150 Two cutting tools with tool life equations given below are being compared: Tool 1: [latex]VT^{0.1}[/latex]  = 150 Tool 2: [latex]VT^{0.3}[/latex]  = 300 Where V is cutting speed in m/minute and T is tool life in minutes. The breakeven cutting speed beyond which Tool 2 will have a higher tool life is ________ m/minute.
solution: Let us assume the speed is [latex]x\;\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} x T_{1}^{0.1} &=150 \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{1} &=\left(\frac{150}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.1}} \text { and } x T_{2}^{0.3}=300\\ T_{2}&=\left(\frac{300}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.3}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now [latex]T_{2}>T_{1} [/latex] [latex] \text { or }\left(\frac{300}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.3}}=\left(\frac{150}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.1}}[/latex] For solving inequality [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(\frac{300}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.3}}&=\left(\frac{150}{x}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.1}}\\ \text{or }\quad\left(\frac{300}{x}\right)^{0.1}&=\left(\frac{150}{x}\right)^{0.3} \\ \text{or }\quad\quad \frac{x^{0.3}}{x^{0.1}}&=\frac{150^{03}}{300^{01}} \\ \text{or }\quad x&=106.066 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 151 A sprue in a sand mould has a top diameter of 20mm and height of 200mm. The velocity of the molten metal at the entry of the sprue is 0.5m/s. Assume acceleration due to gravity as [latex]9.8\,m/s^{2}[/latex] and neglect all losses. If the mould is well ventilated, the velocity (upto 3 decimal points accuracy) of the molten metal at the bottom of the sprue is ________ m/s.
solution: [latex]d^{2}=20\mathrm{mm}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{s} &=200 \mathrm{mm} \\ u_{2} &=0.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ g &=9.8 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ u_{3} &=? \\ u_{2} &=\sqrt{2 g h_{c}} \\ 0.5 &=\sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times h_{c}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad h_{c}&=0.01274 \mathrm{m}\\ h_{t}&=h_{s}+h_{c}=0.200+0.01274\\ &=0.2127 \mathrm{m} \\ u_{3} &=\sqrt{2 g h_{t}}=\sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.2127} \\ &=2.043 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 152 A block of length 200mm is machined by a slab milling cutter 34mm in diameter. The depth of cut and table feed are set at 2mm and 18mm/minute, respectively. Considering the approach and the over travel of the cutter to be same, the minimum estimated machining time per pass is _____________ minutes.
solution: Over travel length is given by [latex]=\sqrt{d(D-d)}=\sqrt{2(34-2)}=8[/latex] Estimated maching time per pass is given by [latex]=\frac{Block\;length+Approach+over \;travel}{Table\;feed}=\frac{200+8+8}{18}=12\;min[/latex]

question: Question 153 Assume that the surface roughness profile is triangular as shown schematically in the figure. If the peak to valley height is [latex]20\,\mu m[/latex], The central line average  surface roughness [latex]R_{a}(in\,\mu m)[/latex]  is
solution: [latex]R_{a}=\frac{h}{4}=\frac{20}{4}=5 \mu \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 154 Circular arc on a part profile is being machined on a vertical CNC milling machine. CNC part program using metric units with absolute dimensions is listed below: ------------------------------ N60 G01 X 30 Y 55 Z 5 F 50 N70 G02 X 50 Y 35 R 20 N80 G01 Z 5 -------------------------------- The coordinates of the centre of the circular arc are :

Question 155 A 10 mm deep cylindrical cup with diameter of 15mm is drawn from a circular blank. Neglecting the variation in the sheet thickness, the diameter (upto 2 decimal points accuracy) of the blank is _________ mm.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} D &=\sqrt{d^{2}+4 d h}=\sqrt{15^{2}+4 \times 15 \times 10} \\ &=28.723 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 156 Metric thread of 0.8 mm pitch is to be cut on a lathe. Pitch of the lead screw is 1.5 mm. If the spindle rotates at 1500 rpm, the speed of rotation of the lead screw (rpm) will be ________
solution: Pitch of thread, [latex] P_{t}=0.8 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Speed of spindle, [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{t} &=1500 \mathrm{rpm} \\ P_{s} &=1.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ N_{s} \times P_{s} \times Z_{z} &=N_{t} \times P_{t} \times Z_{t}\left[\because z_{s}=z_{t}=1\right] \\ N_{s} \times 1.5 \times 1 &=1500 \times 0.8 \times 1 \\ N_{s} &=800 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 157 In an arc welding process, welding speed is doubled. Assuming all other process parameters to be constant, the cross sectional area of the weld bead will
solution: [latex]H_{s}=\frac{V I}{v A_{b}}[/latex] If v is doubled (2 v) to make [latex]H_{s}[/latex] constant [latex]A_{b}[/latex] will be reduced by 50% [latex] H_{s}=\frac{V I}{2 v \frac{A_{b}}{2}}=\frac{V I}{v A_{b}}[/latex]

question: Question 158 Match the processes with their characteristics.

Question 159 A firm uses a turning center, a milling center and a grinding machine to produce two parts. The table below provides the machining time required for each part and the maximum machining time available on each machine. The profit per unit on parts I and II are Rs. 40 and Rs. 100, respectively. The maximum profit per week of the firm is Rs._________
solution: The question will be solved using the graphical method [latex]\text{Maximize } Z=40X_1+100X_2[/latex] Constraints are [latex]\begin{aligned} 12X_1+6X_2 \leq 6000 \\ 4X_1+10X_2 \leq 4000 \\ 2X_1+3X_2 \leq 1800 \\ X_1,X_2 \geq 0 \end{aligned}[/latex] We have three corner points as follow [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{At }(0,400)\;\;\;&Z=40,000\\ \text{At }(375,250)\;\;\;&Z=40,000\\ \text{At }(500,100)\;\;\;&Z=20,000 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, maximum profit per week is 40,000.

question: Question 160 A point P(1,3,-5) is translated by [latex]2\hat{i}+3\hat{j}-4\hat{k}[/latex] and then rotated counter clockwise by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]  about the z-axis. The new position of the point is
solution: Initial point is (1, 3, -5) After tranlated by 2i+3j-4k, it becomes =(1+2, 3+3, -5-4)= (3, 6, -9) Rotation by 90 CCW about z axis (NOTE: : when rotated about z-axis the z component will remain same.) Hence the point (3, 6, -9) changes to (-6, 3, -9).

question: Question 161 Two optically flat plates of glass are kept at a small angle [latex]\theta[/latex]  as shown in the figure.  Monochromatic light is incident vertically. If the wavelength of light used to get a fringe spacing of 1 mm is 450 nm, the wavelength of light (in nm) to get a fringe spacing of 1.5 mm is _________
solution: Given [latex] \begin{aligned} 1 \mathrm{mm} &=450 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Spacing } &=1.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ n &=\frac{2}{\lambda} \quad \text { As given in question }\\ 1.5&=n \times \frac{\lambda_{2}}{2} \\ \lambda_{2}=\frac{1.5 \times 2}{n}&=\frac{1.5 \times 2}{\frac{2}{450}}=1.5 \times 450=675 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 162 In a single point turning operation with cemented carbide tool and steel work piece, it is found that the Taylor's exponent is 0.25. If the cutting speed is reduced by 50% then the tool life changes by ______ times.

Question 163 In a sheet metal of 2 mm thickness a hole of 10 mm diameter needs to be punched. The yield strength in tension of the sheet material is 100 MPa and its ultimate shear strength is 80 MPa. The force required to punch the hole (in kN) is __________
solution: Punching force, [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{\max } &=\pi d t\tau_{\text {pers. }} \\ &=\pi \times 10 \times 2 \times 80=5.024 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 164 For an orthogonal cutting operation, tool material is HSS, rake angle is [latex]22^{\circ}[/latex], chip thickness is  0.8 mm, speed is 48 m/min and feed is 0.4 mm/rev. The shear plane angle (in degrees) is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{rl} \alpha=22^{\circ} t_{2}=0.8 & v=48 \quad t_{1}=0.4 \\ r= & t_{1} / t_{2}=0.5 \\ \phi & =\tan ^{-i}\left(\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha}\right) \\ & =\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{0.5 \cos 22^{\circ}}{1-0.5 \sin 22^{\circ}}\right)=29.7^{\circ} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 165 Spot welding of two steel sheets each 2 mm thick is carried out successfully by passing 4 kA of current for 0.2 seconds through the electrodes. The resulting weld nugget formed between the sheets is 5 mm in diameter. Assuming cylindrical shape for the nugget, the thickness of the nugget is________mm.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} t &=2 \mathrm{mm} \\ I &=4 \mathrm{kA} \\ \mathrm{Time} &=0.25 \\ D_{N} &=5 \mathrm{mm} \\ I^{2} R t &=\text { Volume } \times \rho \times \mathrm{H.R} / \mathrm{kg} \\ 4000^{2} \times 200 \times 10^{-6} \times 0.2&=\mathrm{Vol} . \times 8000 \times 1400 \times 10^{3} \\ h&=2.91 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 166 Match the following part programming codes with their respective functions
solution: G01 is used for linear interpolation, G03 is used for circular interpolation counter clockwise, M03 for spindle rotation clockwise and M05 for spindle top.

options.B: P- IV, Q- II, R- III, S- I

question: Question 167 Internal gears are manufactured by
solution: Internal gears are manufactured by gear Broaching and shaping with pinion cutter only, whereas shaping with pinion cutter is used for both external and internal gears.

question: Question 168 In a wire-cut EDM process the necessary conditions that have to be met for making a successful cut are that
solution: In a wire-cut EDM process, a thin metallic wire is fed on to the conducting workpiece, which is submerged in a tank of dielectric fluid such as de-ionized water. Wire is fed in the programmed path & material is cut from the workpiece accordingly. Material removal takes place by a series of discrete discharges between the wire electrode & workpiece in the presence of a dielectric fluid. The di-electric fluid gets ionized in between the tool electrode gap thereby creating a  path for each discharge. The area wherein discharge takes place gets heated to very high temperature such that the surface get melted & removed. The cut particles (debris) get flushed away by continuous flowing dielectric fluid. Generally, wire-cut EDM is used for cutting Aluminium, brass, etc. & wire material used for quicker cutting action is zinc coated brass wires.

options.A: wire and sample are electrically non-conducting
options.B: wire and sample are electrically conducting
options.C: wire is electrically conducting and sample is electrically non-conducting
options.D: sample is electrically conducting and wire is electrically non-conducting

question: Question 169 Equal amounts of a liquid metal at the same temperature are poured into three moulds made of steel, copper and aluminum. The shape of the cavity is a cylinder with 15 mm diameter. The size of the moulds are such that the outside temperature of the moulds do not increase appreciably beyond the atmospheric temperature during solidification.  The sequence of solidification in the mould from the fastest to slowest is (Thermal conductivities of steel, copper and aluminum are 60.5, 401 and 237 W/m-K, respectively. Specific heats of steel, copper and aluminum are 434, 385 and 903 J/kg-K, respectively. Densities of steel, copper and aluminum are 7854, 8933 and 2700 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex], respectively.)
solution: Solidification time is inversely proportional to diffusivity and based on the values diffusivity is highest for copper, next is aluminum and then steel. Hence the solidification time is lowest for copper, next aluminum and then steel.

question: Question 170 Engineering strain of a mild steel sample is recorded as 0.100%. The true strain is
solution: Given data Engineering strain, [latex] \begin{aligned} \epsilon &=0.100 \%=0.001 \\ \text { True strain : } \bar{\epsilon} &=\ln (1+\epsilon) \\ &=\ln (1+0.001) \\ &=0.00099=0.099 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 171 For the situation shown in the figure below the expression for H in terms of r, R and D is
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} A B &=\sqrt{(R+r)^{2}-(D-R-r)^{2}} \\ H &=R+A B+r \\ &=R+r+\sqrt{(R+r+D-R-r)(R+r-D+R+r)} \\ &=R+r+\sqrt{(R+r+D-R-r)(R+r-D+R+r)} \\ &=R+r+\sqrt{D[2(R+r)-D]} \\ &=R+r+\sqrt{2 D(R+r)-D^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 172 The surface irregularities of electrodes used in an electrochemical machining (ECM) process are 3 [latex]\mu m[/latex] and 6 [latex]\mu m[/latex] as shown in the figure. If the work-piece is of pure iron and 12V DC is applied between the electrodes, the largest feed rate is ___________mm/min. Assume the iron to be dissolved as [latex]Fe^{+2}[/latex]  and the Faraday constant to be 96500 Coulomb.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R &=\frac{\rho L}{\text { Area }}=\frac{\frac{1}{0.02} \times 0.009}{\text { Area }} \\ &=\frac{50 \times 0.009}{\text { Area }} \\ I &=\frac{V}{R}=\frac{(12-1.5) \times \text { Area }}{50 \times 0.009} \\ &=23.33 \times \text { Area } \\ L &=3+6=9 \mu \mathrm{m}=0.009 \mathrm{m} \\ \mathrm{MRR} &=\frac{A I}{\rho Z F}=\frac{55 \times 85 \times 23.33 \times \text { Area }}{7860 \times 10^{-6} \times 2 \times 96500} \\ \frac{\mathrm{MRR}}{\mathrm{Area}} &=0.8590 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{s} \\ &=51.542 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 173 For a certain job, the cost of metal cutting is Rs. 18C/V and the cost of tooling is Rs. 270C/(TV),where C is a constant,  V is the cutting speed in m/min and T  is the tool life in minutes. The Taylor's tool life equation is [latex]VT^{0.25}[/latex] =150. The cutting speed (in m/min) for the minimum total cost is _______
solution: Total cost = metal cutting cost + tooling cost [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{180 C}{V}+\frac{270 C}{V T}\\ \text { Here, } T&=\left(\frac{150}{V}\right)^{\frac{1}{0.25}}=\left(\frac{15}{V}\right)^{4} \\ C_{t} &=\frac{18 C}{V}+\frac{270 C}{V \cdot\left(\frac{150}{V}\right)^{4}}\\ \frac{d C_{t}}{d V} &=0 \\ -\frac{18 C}{V^{2}}+\frac{270 C}{(150)^{4}} \times 3 v^{2}&=0\\ \text { or } \quad V^{4}&=\frac{150^{4} \times 18}{270 \times 3} \\ V&=57.91 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 174 The voltage-length characteristic of a direct current arc in an arc welding process is v=(100+40[latex]l[/latex]) , where [latex]l[/latex]  is the length of the arc in mm and V is arc voltage in volts. During a welding operation, the arc length varies between 1 and 2 mm and the welding current is in the range 200-250 A. Assuming a linear power source, the short circuit current is_________ A.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V &=100+40 \mathrm{L} \\ \text{When}\quad L &=1 \quad I=250 \\ V &=(100+40 \times 1)=140 \\ &=V_{0}-\frac{V_{0}}{I_{0}} \times 250 \\ L &=2 \quad I=200 \\ V &=(100+40 \times 2) \\ 180 &=V_{0}-\frac{V_{0}}{I_{0}} \times 200 \\ V_{0} &=140+\frac{4}{5} \times 250=340 \\ I &=\frac{V_{0} \times 5}{4}=\frac{340 \times 5}{4} \\ &=425 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 175 Gray cast iron blocks of size 100 mm x 50 mm x 10 mm with a central spherical cavity of diameter 4 mm are sand cast. The shrinkage allowance for the pattern is 3%. The ratio of the volume of the pattern to volume of the casting is _________
solution: Ratio of volume of pattern to volume of casting is given by [latex]=\frac{(1.03\times100)\times(1.03\times50)\times(1.03\times10)}{100\times50\times10}=1.093[/latex] Volume of cavity is assumed to be small and negligible as it will complicate the question to a higher level. If your answer was less than 1, read below. There are three things to be understood here :- 1. Liquid Shrinkage It refers to the reduction in volume when the metal changes from liquid state to solid state at the solidus temperature. The liquid shrinkage is rarely a problem, because the molten metal is continuously flowing in mold cavity and also riser to compensate the shrinkage of liquid in the cavity. 2. Solidification i.e Liquid to solid phase transformation (GCI expands in this process unlike other metals) So now during phase transformation gray cast iron expands (unlike other metals which contract) and there is no need of riser (used to take care of phase transformation shrinkage + liquid shrinkage). 3. Solid state Cooling (GCI contracts in this process just like other metals) It refers to the reduction in volume caused when metal loses temperature in solid state. To account for this, shrinkage allowance is provided on the patterns. The Shrinkage allowance depends primarily upon Coefficient of thermal expansion. For Grey CI in particular it is positive, it means solid grey cast iron expands on increasing temp and contracts on decreasing temperature just like any other metal. Adding all above factors Neglecting the Liquid shrinkage we see that GCI expands in during solidification and contracts when cooled in solid form. So the net result would be sum of them. According to NPTL in the table for GCI they have given the net value of shrinkage’s which is positive and hence the pattern size would be more than the casting. Note: The expansion of GCI during phase change (solidification) is a fact but at the same time we need to consider the contraction of GCI when cooling in solid state. So net result according to IISC and NPTEL is contraction so the size of pattern will be more than that of casting.

question:
Question 176 In a binary system of A and B, a liquid of 20% A (80% B) is coexisting with a solid of 70% A
(30% B). For an overall composition having 40% A, the fraction of solid is
solution: Weight of the liquid [latex]A=W_{LA}=l_a \times W_l=0.2 \times W_l[/latex] where, [latex]W_l[/latex] is Weight of total liquid Weight of solid of [latex]A=W_{SA}=S_a(W_T-W_l)=0.7(W_T-W_l)[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} W_A&=0.2W_l+0.7(W_T-W_l) \\ W_A&=0.7W_T-0.5W_l \\ \frac{W_A}{W_T}&=0.7-0.5\frac{W_l}{W_T} \\ 0.4 &=0.7-0.5(\% W_l) \\ 0.5(\% W_l) &= 0.3\\ (\% W_l)&=\frac{3}{5}\\ (\% W_l)&=1-\frac{3}{5}=0.4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 178 The following data is applicable for a turning operation. The length of job is 900 mm, diameter of job is 200 mm, feed rate is 0.25 mm/rev and optimum cutting speed is 300 m/min. The machining time (in min) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} t &=\frac{L}{f N} \text { and } V=\pi D N \\ \therefore \quad t &=\frac{L \pi D}{f V} \\ &=\frac{900 \times \pi \times 200}{0.25 \times 300 \times 1000} \\ &=\frac{18 \pi}{30 \times 0.25} \min \\ &=\frac{6 \pi}{2.5} \min =7.5 \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 183 A 300 mm thick slab is being cold rolled using roll of 600 mm diameter. If the coefficient of friction is 0.08, the maximum possible reduction (in mm) is __________

question: Question 184 A cylindrical job with diameter of 200 mm and height of 100 mm is to be cast using modulus method of riser design. Assume that the bottom surface of cylindrical riser does not contribute as cooling surface. If the diameter of the riser is equal to its height, then the height of the riser (in mm) is
solution: According to modulus method [latex] \begin{aligned}  M_{R} &=1.2 M_{C} \\ \left(\frac{V}{A_{s}}\right)_{R} &=1.2\left(\frac{V}{A_{s}}\right)_{C}\\ \text{Since, for riser } D&=H \text{, we have}\\ \left (\frac{V}{A_s} \right )_R&=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4}D^2H}{\pi DH+\frac{\pi}{4}D^2}=\frac{D}{5} \\ \text{Also, } & \\ \left (\frac{V}{A_s} \right )_C&=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4}D^2H}{\pi DH+2\times\frac{\pi}{4}D^2}  \\ \left (\frac{V}{A_s} \right )_C&=\frac{200^2(100)}{4 (200)(100)+2\times200^2}=25\\ \text{Hence, }&\text{from (i) we have} \\ \frac{D}{5} &=1.2\times 25 \\ D&=H=150\;mm\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 185 The tool life equation for HSS tool is  [latex]VT^{0.14}f^{0.7}d^{0.4}= Constant[/latex]. The tool life (T) of 30 min is obtained using the following cutting conditions: V = 45 m/min, f = 0.35 mm, d = 2.0 mm If speed (V), feed (f) and depth of cut (d) are increased individually by 25%, the tool life (in min) is
solution:
[latex]\begin{array}{l}
45000 \times 30^{0.14} \times 0.35^{0.7} \times 2^{0.4}=K \\
K=45,842.58 \\
\Rightarrow T^{0.14}=\frac{K}{(1.25 V)(1.25 f)^{0.7}(1.25 \times d)^{0.4}} \\
\Rightarrow T^{0.14}=\frac{K}{(1.25 \times 45000)(1.25 \times 0.35)^{0.7}(1.25 \times 2)^{0.4}} \\
\Rightarrow \quad T=1.06 \mathrm{min}
\end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 186 Heat is removed from a molten metal of mass 2 kg at a constant rate of 10 kW till it is completely solidified. The cooling curve is shown in the figure. Assuming uniform temperature throughout the volume of the metal during solidification, the latent
heat of fusion of the metal (in kJ/kg) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=m \times \mathrm{L} . \mathrm{H} \\ Q &=\text { total heat removed } \\ m &=\text { mass } \\ \text { L.H. } &=\text { Latent heat of fusion } \\ Q &=\dot{Q} \times t \\ \dot{Q} &=\text { Heat removal rate, } \\ t &=\text { time } \\ \therefore 10 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{s} \times(20-10) \mathrm{s}&=2 \times \mathrm{L} . \mathrm{H} \\ \text { or }\text { L.H. }&= 50 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternatively [latex] \begin{aligned} Q &=m \times \mathrm{L} . \mathrm{H} \\ Q &=\text { total heat removed } \\ m &=\text { mass } \\ \mathrm{L} . \mathrm{H} &=\text { Latent heat of fusion } \\ Q &=\dot{Q} \times t \\ \dot{Q} &=\text { Heat removal rate, } \\ t &=\text { time } \\ \therefore 10 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{s} \times(20-10) \mathrm{s}&=2 \times \mathrm{L} . \mathrm{H} \\ \text{or}\quad\text{ L.H. }&=50 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 187 Match the following:
solution: Feeler gauge is used to measure clearance or gap between components. Fillet gauge is also known as radius gauge. Snap gauge is a limit gauge used to measure diameter within limits by comparison.

question: Question 188 In an orthogonal cutting process the tool used has rake angle of zero degree. The measured cutting force and thrust force are 500 N and 250 N, respectively. The coefficient of friction between the tool and the chip is _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \because \quad \tan \beta &=\frac{F_{T} / F_{C}+\tan \alpha}{1-(\tan \alpha) F_{T} / F_{C}} \\ \therefore \quad\alpha &=0 \\ \tan \beta &=\frac{F_{T}}{F_{C}}=\frac{250}{500}=0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 191 Under optimal conditions of the process the temperatures experienced by a copper work piece in fusion welding, brazing and soldering are such that
solution: In welding, the two metals (or thermoplastic) must be similar. For example, copper cannot be welded to steel. Welding uses high temperatures to melt and join two metal parts. A filler metal is often used as well. When properly done, the finished weld is as strong as the surrounding metal. Brazing joins two metals by heating and melting a filler (alloy) that bonds to the two pieces of metal and joins them. The filler obviously must have a melting temperature below that of the metal pieces. Brazing can join dissimilar metals such as aluminum, silver, copper, gold, and nickel. Soldering  is a low-temperature analog to brazing. By the American Welding Society’s definition, soldering takes place with fillers (also known as solders) that melt at below [latex]840^{\circ}F (450^{\circ}C)[/latex]. Metals that can be soldered include gold, silver, copper, brass, and iron. The filler, called solder, melts. When it solidifies, it is bonded to the metal parts and joins them. The bond is not as strong as brazed joint or welded one. Solder was once made mainly of lead, but environmental concerns are pushing industry to lead-free alternatives.

question: Question 193 The dimensions of a cylindrical side riser (height = diameter) for a 25 cm x 15 cm x 5 cm steel casting are to be determined. For the tabulated shape factor values given below, the diameter of the riser (in cm) is ________
solution: [latex]Z=\frac{L+w}{t}[/latex] Z= shape factor L= length w= width t= thickness [latex] Z=\frac{25+15}{5}=8[/latex] [latex] \frac{\text { Riser volume }}{\text { Casting volume }}=0.5 [/latex] Given casting volume [latex] =25 \times 15 \times 5 [/latex] [latex] \frac{\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} \times h}{25 \times 15 \times 5}=0.5[/latex] Given [latex](d=h) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\pi}{4} d^{3} &=0.5 \times 25 \times 15 \times 5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad d &=10.60 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 194 A shaft of length 90 mm has a tapered portion of length 55 mm. The diameter of the taper is 80 mm at one end and 65 mm at the other. If the taper is made by tailstock set over method, the taper angle and the set over respectively are
solution: In [latex]\Delta AOB[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \tan\frac{\theta}{2}&=\frac{AB}{OA} \\ \tan\frac{\theta}{2}&=\frac{\frac{80-65}{2}}{55} \\ \tan\frac{\theta}{2}&=0.135 \\ \frac{\theta}{2}&=7.765^{\circ} \\ \theta&=15.37^{\circ} \\ \text{Set }&\text{over is given by} \\ &=\sin\frac{\theta}{2}\times 90\\ &=0.13511\times 90\\ &=12.16\;mm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 196 Orthogonal turning of a mild steel tube with a tool of rake angle [latex]10^{\circ}[/latex] is carried out at a feed of 
 0.14 mm/rev. If the thickness of the chip produced is 0.28 mm, the values of shear angle and shear strain will be respectively
solution: Feed = unit thickness of orthogonal turning [latex] \begin{aligned} r &=\frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}=\frac{0.14}{0.28}=0.5 \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha} \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{0.5 \cos 10^{\circ}}{1-\left(0.5 \sin 10^{\circ}\right)} \\ \phi&=28.33^{\circ}=28^{\circ}, 20^{\circ} \\ \gamma &=\cot \phi+\tan (\phi-\alpha) \\ \gamma &=2.1858 \approx 2.19 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 197 Ratio of solidification time of a cylindrical casting (height = radius) to that of a cubic casting of side two times the height of cylindrical casting is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T&=k\left[\frac{V}{A}\right]^{2}\\ T&=k\left[\frac{\pi r^{2} \times h}{2 \pi r^{2}+2 \pi r h}\right] \\ \text { Given, } h&=r \\ T&=\left[\frac{\pi r^{3}}{4 \pi r^{2}}\right] \\ \Rightarrow \quad T &=k\left[\frac{r^{2}}{16}\right] \\ T_{c u} &=k\left[\frac{V}{A}\right]^{2} \\ T_{c}&= k\left[\frac{a^{3}}{6 a^{2}}\right]^{2} \\ \text{But }\;a=2h\Rightarrow2r\\ T_{c}&= k\left[\frac{4 r^{2}}{36}\right] \\ T_{\text {cylin }} \text {/Take}&= \left[k\left[\frac{r^{2}}{16}\right]\right] \div \left[k \frac{r^{2}}{g}\right] \\ &=\frac{k r^{2}}{16} \times \frac{9}{k r^{2}} \\ &=\frac{9}{16}=0.5625 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 198 In a rolling operation using rolls of diameter 500 mm, if a 25 mm thick plate cannot be reduced to less than 20 mm in one pass, the coefficient of friction between the roll and the plate is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} D &=500 \mathrm{mm} \\ R &=250 \mathrm{mm} \\ (\Delta t)_{\max } &=\mu^{2} R \\ 5 &=\mu^{2} \times 250\\ \frac{5}{250} &=\mu^{2} \\ \text{or}\quad \mu &=0.1414 \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: (i) and (iv) All solid state welding are autogenous welding.

question: Question 201 In full mould (cavity-less) casting process, the pattern is made of
solution: The pattern is made of expanded polystrene. In the expanded polystyrene casting process, a sand mold is packed around a polystyrene pattern representing the metal casting to be manufactured. The pattern is not removed, and the molten metal is poured into the pattern which is vaporized from the heat of the metal. The liquid metal takes the place of the vaporized polystyrene and the casting solidifies in the sand mold.

question: Question 202 In a machining operation, if the generatrix and directrix both are straight lines, the surface obtained is
solution: Generatrix:- In geometry, generotrix or generator is a point, curve or surface that, when moved generates a new shape Directrix- The path of generatrix motion is called directrix Table showing generatrix and directrix of various curves [latex]\begin{matrix} &\text{Generatrix}& \text{Directrix}\\ \text{Cylindrical surfaces} &\text{Straight line} &\text{Fixed curve}\\ \text{Helicel surfaces} &\text{Curve} &\text{Straight line}\\ \text{Plane} &\text{Straight line} &\text{Straight line}\\ \text{Surface of revolution }&\text{Plane curve} &\text{Fixed curve}\\ \end{matrix}[/latex]

question: Question 203 The strain hardening exponent n of stainless steel SS 304 with distinct yield and UTS values undergoing plastic deformation is
solution: The value of strain hardening constant (n) lies between 0 and 1 n = 0 means material is perfectly plastic solid n = 1 means material is perfectly elastic solid

question: Question 204 A resistance-capacitance relaxation circuit is used in an electrical discharge machining process. The discharge voltage is 100 V. At a spark cycle time of 25 [latex]\mu[/latex]s, the average power input required is  1 kW. The capacitance (in [latex]\mu[/latex]F) in the circuit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Power } &=\frac{\text { Work }}{\text { Time }} \\ P &=\frac{1}{2} \frac{C V^{2}}{t} \\ \Rightarrow \quad C &=\frac{P \times 2 t}{V^{2}}=\frac{1000 \times 2 \times 25 \times 10^{-6}}{(100)^{2}} \\ &=5 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 205 A single point cutting tool with [latex]0^{\circ}[/latex] rake angle is used in an orthogonal machining process. At a cutting speed of 180 m/min, the thrust force is 490 N. If the coefficient of friction between the tool and the chip is 0.7, then the power consumption (in kW) for the machining operation is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{F}{N}&=\frac{F_{T}}{F_{C}}=0.7\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{490}{F_{C}} &=0.7 \\ F_{C} &=700 \mathrm{N} \\ \text { Power } &=F_{C} \times V=\frac{700 \times 180}{60} \\ &=2.1 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 206 During a TIG welding process, the arc current and arc voltage were 50 A and 60 V, respectively, when the welding speed was 150 mm/min. In another process, the TIG welding is carried out at a welding speed of 120 mm/min at the same arc voltage and heat input to the material so that weld quality remains the same. The welding current (in A) for this process is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{50 \times 60}{150} &=\frac{I \times 60}{120} \\ I &=\frac{50 \times 12}{155}=40 \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 207 The flow stress (in MPa) of a material is given by [latex]\sigma=500\varepsilon^{0.1}[/latex] ; where [latex]\varepsilon[/latex] is true strain. The Young's modulus of elasticity of the material is 200 GPa. A block of thickness 100 mm made of this material is compressed to 95 mm thickness and then the load is removed. The final dimension of the block (in mm) is _________
solution: Equating the stress to the equation up to elastic limit, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma &=500 \varepsilon^{0.1}=200 \times 10^{3} \times \varepsilon \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\varepsilon^{0.9} &=\frac{500}{200 \times 10^{3}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \varepsilon(\text { tuestain })&=1.28476 \times 10^{-3}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \varepsilon_{T}&=\ln (1+\varepsilon)\\ \varepsilon(\text { engg.strain })_{\text {upto elastic limit }}&=1.285586 \times 10^{-3}=\frac{\Delta L}{L} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad(\Delta L)_{\text {upto elastic limit }}&=0.128558 \mathrm{mm}\\ \Rightarrow \qquad & \text{Final dimension of block} \\ &=95+ \text{ elastic recover}\\ &=95.128558 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 208 In a two-stage wire drawing operation, the fractional reduction (ratio of change in cross-sectional area to initial cross-sectional area) in the first stage is 0.4. The fractional reduction in the second stage is 0.3. The overall fractional reduction is
solution: Fractional reduction in first stage [latex] =\frac{\text { Change in area in first stage }}{\text { Original area }(A) \text { before reduction }} [/latex] [latex] 0.4=\frac{\text { Change in area in first stage }}{A} [/latex] Change in area in first stage [latex]=0.4 \mathrm{A}[/latex] Area after first redirection [latex] =A-0.4 A=0.6 A [/latex] Fraction reduction in second stage [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{\text { Change in area in second stage }}{\text { Original area before second stage }} \\ 0.3=\frac{\text { Change in area in second stage }}{0.6 \mathrm{A}} \end{array}[/latex] Change in after 2 nd stage [latex]=0.18 A [/latex] Remaining area after 2nd reduction [latex] \begin{array}{l} =0.60 .18 \mathrm{A} \\ =0.42 \mathrm{A} \end{array}[/latex] Overall reduction in area [latex] =A-0.42 A=0.58 A[/latex] Overall fractional reduction [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{\text { Overall reduction in area }}{\text { Original area }} \\ =\frac{0.58 \mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{A}}=0.58 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 209 A cube and a sphere made of cast iron (each of volume 1000 [latex]cm^{3}[/latex]) were cast under identical conditions.  The time taken for solidifying the cube was 4 s. The solidification time (in s) for the sphere is __________
solution: Time of solidification(T) [latex] \begin{array}{l} =k\left[\frac{\text { volume }}{\text { surface area }}\right]^{2} \\ {\left[\begin{array}{l} \left.\frac{T_{\text {sphere }}}{T_{\text {cube }}}\right]=\left[\frac{A_{\text {cube }}}{A_{\text {sphere }}}\right]^{2}=\left[\frac{6 a^{2}}{4 / 3 \pi r^{3}}\right]^{2}-(1) \end{array}\right.}\\ \because\left[V_{\text {sphere }}=V_{\text {cube }}\right] \\ V_{\text {cube }}=a^{3}=1000 \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\ \therefore \qquad a =10\mathrm{cm}\\ V_{\text {sphere }}=\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}=1000\\ \Rightarrow \qquad r=6.2035 \mathrm{cm} \\ \end{array}[/latex] Putting in Eq.(1), we get [latex] \frac{T_{\text {sphere }}}{T_{\text {cube }}}=\left[\frac{6 \times 10^{2}}{4 \pi \times(6.2035)^{2}}\right]^{2} [/latex] [latex] T_{\text {sphere }} =6.157355 \mathrm{seconds}[/latex]
