Question 212 The atomic packing factor for a material with body centered cubic structure is __________
solution: Atomic packing factor [latex] =\frac{\text { volume occupied by } N_{\text {average }}}{\text { Volume of unit cell }} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{N_{\text {average }} \times \frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}}{a^{3}} [/latex] for bec structrue, [latex] a=\frac{4 r}{\sqrt{3}} and N_{\text {average }}=2 \Rightarrow A.P.F. =0.68[/latex]

question: Question 213 In a slab rolling operation, the maximum thickness reduction ([latex]\Delta h_{max}[/latex] ) is given by [latex]\Delta h_{max}[/latex]=[latex]\mu ^{2}R[/latex] , where R is the radius of the roll and ? is the coefficient of friction between the roll and the sheet. If [latex]\mu [/latex] = 0.1, the maximum angle subtended by the deformation zone at the centre of the roll (bite angle in degrees) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta h_{\max } &=\mu^{2} R \\ \Delta h &=D(1-\cos \alpha) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \mu^{2} R&=D(1-\cos \alpha) \\ \Rightarrow \quad(0.1)^{2}&=2(1-\cos \alpha) \\ \text{or }\quad \alpha&=5.73^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 214 The solidification time of a casting is proportional to [latex](V/A)^{2}[/latex] , where V is the volume of the casting and A is the total casting surface area losing heat. Two cubes of same material and size are cast using sand casting process. The top face of one of the cubes is completely insulated. The ratio of the solidification time for the cube with top face insulated to that of the other cube is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{\text {solidification }}&= k\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}} &=\frac{k\left(\frac{V_{1}}{A_{1}}\right)^{2}}{k\left(\frac{V_{2}}{A_{2}}\right)^{2}} \\ V_{1} &=V_{2}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}&=\frac{A_{2}^{2}}{A_{1}^{2}}=\frac{\left(6 a^{2}\right)^{2}}{\left(5 a^{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{36}{25} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 215 An orthogonal turning operation is carried out under the following conditions: rake angle = [latex]5^{\circ}[/latex] ; spindle rotational speed = 400 rpm; axial feed = 0.4 m/min and radial depth of cut = 5 mm. The chip thickness, [latex]t_{c}[/latex], is found to be 3 mm. The shear angle (in degrees) in this turning process is_____
solution: Rake angle [latex](\alpha)=5^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} N &=400 \mathrm{rpm} \\ \text { Axial feed } &=0.4 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \\ &=\frac{0.4 \times 1000}{400}=1 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{rev} \end{aligned}[/latex] Radial dreeth of cut [latex]=5 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Chip thickness: [latex]r_{c}= 3 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} r&=\text{chip thickness ratio}\\ &= \frac{t}{t_{c}}=\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \tan\phi&=\frac{r\cos\alpha}{1-r\sin\alpha}\\ &=\frac{\frac{1}{3} \cos \left(5^{\circ}\right)}{1-\frac{1}{3} \sin \left(5^{\circ}\right)} \\ \tan \phi &=0.342\\ \text{or }\qquad \phi&=\tan ^{-1}(0.342)=18.88^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 216 A triangular facet in a CAD model has vertices: P1(0,0,0); P2(1,1,0) and P3(1,1,1). The area of the facet is
solution: [latex]\text{Area}=\frac{1}{2} \times \sqrt{2} \times 1=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}=0.707[/latex]

question: Question 217 A DC welding power source has a linear voltage-current (V-I) characteristic with open circuit voltage of 80 V and a short circuit current of 300 A. For maximum arc power, the current (in Amperes) should be set as_________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V&=V_{O C}-\left(\frac{V_{O C}}{I_{S C}}\right) I \\ \Rightarrow\quad V&=80-\left(\frac{80}{300}\right) I \\ P&=V I \\ &=(80-0.2666 I) I \\ &=80 I-0.2666 I^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] for power to be maximum [latex] \begin{array}{l} \quad\left(\frac{d P}{d I}\right)=0 \\ \Rightarrow 80-2 \times 0.2666 I=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad \quad I=150 \mathrm{A} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 218 In the assembly shown below, the part dimensions are: [latex] L1 = 22.0^{\pm 0.01}[/latex]mm, [latex]L2 = L3 =10.0^{\pm 0.005}[/latex]mm.  Assuming the normal distribution of part dimensions, the dimension  in [latex]L_{4}[/latex]  mm for assembly condition would be:
Question 219 The function of  interpolator in a CNC machine controller is to
solution: Interpolator in a CNC machine controller is used for circular interpolation purpose. It simple means that interpolator gives motion (or feed) to the coordinate axes for circular interpolations.

options.D: perform Miscellaneous (M) functions (tool change, coolant control etc.)

question: Question 220 In a linear arc welding process, the heat input per unit length is inversely proportional to
solution: In Linear arc welding process the heat input per unit length depends on many factors. (A) Welding current: As welding current increase as heat input increases because we know that heat input is [latex]I^2RT[/latex] so [latex](\text{Heat input per unit length})\propto ( \text{current} )^2[/latex] (B) Welding Voltage: As welding voltage increase as heat input also increase because we know that heat input is [latex]\frac{V^2}{R}[/latex] [latex](\text{Heat input per unit length})\propto ( \text{voltage} )^2[/latex] (C) Welding Speed: As welding speed increase as welding electrode spend less time to release heat so as speed increase as heat input per unit length decrease proportionaly [latex](\text{Heat input per unit length})\propto \frac{1}{( \text{welding speed} )}[/latex] (D) Duty cycle: Duty cycle is defined as the % of time for which arc is on without overheating element of welding machine so [latex](\text{Heat input per unit length})\propto ( \text{duty cycle} )[/latex]

options.D: duty cycle of the power source

question: Question 221 Under certain cutting conditions, doubling the cutting speed reduces the tool life to [latex](1/16)^{th}[/latex] of the original. Taylor's tool life index(n) for this tool-workpiece combination will be ___________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{1} T_{1}^{n} &=V_{2} T_{2}^{n} \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{1}\left(T_{1}\right)^{n} &=2 V_{1}\left[\frac{1}{16} T_{1}\right]^{n} \\ n &=0.25 \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: Minimum clearances [latex]=(\text { Hole })_{\text {minimum }}- (\text { Shaft })_{\text {maximum }} [/latex] [latex] 25.02-25.005=0.015mm[/latex]

question: Question 223 Match the following products with preferred manufacturing processes:

Question 224 A cast iron block of 200 mm length is being shaped in a shaping machine with a depth of cut of  4 mm, feed of 0.25 mm/stroke and the tool principal cutting edge angle of 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. Number of cutting strokes per minute is 60. Using specific energy for cutting as 1.49 J/[latex]mm^{3}[/latex], the average power consumption (in watt) is _______
solution: The volume rate of material removal is: [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=f d L N \\ \text { where } f(\text { feed })&=0.25 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{stroke} \\ d(\text { depth of } \mathrm{cut})&=4 \mathrm{mm} \\ \quad L(\text { length of block })&=200 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] N(number of cutting stroke per minute) =60 [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\frac{0.25 \times 4 \times 200 \times 60}{60}\left(\frac{m m^{3}}{s}\right)\\ &=200 \mathrm{mm}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ U_{c} &=1.49 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ P_{\text {average }} &=U_{c} \times Q=1.49 \times 200 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{s}=298 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 225 A cylindrical riser of 6 cm diameter and 6 cm height has to be designed for a sand casting mould for producing a steel rectangular plate casting of 7 cm x 10 cm x 2 cm dimensions having the total solidification time of 1.36 minute. The total solidification time (in minute) of the riser is  _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{\text {casting }}&=7 \times 10 \times 2=140 \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\ A_{\text {casting }}&= 2(7 \times 10+7 \times 2+2 \times 10) \\ &=2 \times(70 \times 20 \times 14)\\&=2 \times 104=208 \mathrm{cm}^{2}\\ \qquad\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)_{\text {casting }}&=\frac{140}{208}=0.673 \mathrm{cm} \\ \qquad\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)_{\text {Top Riser }}&=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4} d^{3}}{\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2}+\pi d^{2}}=\frac{d}{5}\\ &=1.2\mathrm{cm}\qquad(\therefore d=h=6\mathrm{cm}) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \left(\frac{V}{A}\right)_{\text {Bottom Riser }}&=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4} d^{3}}{\frac{\pi}{2} d^{2}+\pi d^{2}}=\frac{d}{6}=1 \mathrm{cm} \\ \frac{t_{R}}{t_{C}}&= \frac{(V / A)_{\text {Top Riser }}^{2}}{(V / A)_{\text {Casting }}^{2}}=\left(\frac{1.2}{0.673}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow t_{R}&=4.133 \text { minute } \text { (for top riser) }\\ \frac{t_{R}}{t_{C}} &=\frac{(V / A)_{\text {Bottom Riser }}^{2}}{(V / A)_{\text {Casting }}^{2}}=\left(\frac{1}{0.673}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow t_{R} &=3 \text { minute } \quad \text { (for bottom riser) } \end{aligned}[/latex] Solidification time considering top and bottom riser comes under range given in the answer.

question: Question 226 A GO-No GO plug gauge is to be designed for measuring a hole of nominal diameter 25 mm with a hole tolerance of  [latex]\pm 0.015mm[/latex] . Considering 10% of work tolerance to be the gauge tolerance and no wear condition, the dimension (in mm) of the GO plug gauge as per the unilateral tolerance    system is
solution: Hole dimensions are [latex]24.985 \mathrm{mm} and 25.015 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Total tolerance [latex]=0.015+0.015=0.03 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Work tolerance [latex]=0.03 \times 0.1=0.003 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Dimension of GO plug gauge [latex] \begin{aligned} &=24.985-0.000 \mathrm{mm} \\ &=24.985+0.003 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 227 In a rolling process, the maximum possible draft, defined as the difference between the initial and the final thickness of the metal sheet, mainly depends on which pair of the following parameters? P:   Strain Q:  Strength of the work material R:  Roll diameter S:  Roll velocity T:  Coefficient of friction between roll and work
solution: [latex]\left(t_{i}-t_{f}\right)_{\max }=\mu^{2} R[/latex] where [latex]\mu [/latex] is coefficient of friction R is roll radius.

question: Question 228 Match the heat treatment processes (Group A) and their associated effects on properties (Group B) of medium carbon steel
Question 229 Better surface finish is obtained with a large rake angle because
solution: Large positive side rake angle result in less chip formation, less cutting force, good surface finish because increase in rake angle results in decrease the area of shear plane that result decrease in shear force.

options.A: the area of shear plane decreases resulting in the decrease in shear force and cutting force
options.B: the tool becomes thinner and the cutting force is reduced
options.C: less heat is accumulated in the cutting zone
options.D: the friction between the chip and the tool is less

question: Question 230 The principle of material removal in Electrochemical machining is
solution: In an ECM material removal rate is governed by Faraday’s law of electrolysis. The amount of chemical change produced by an electric current (or the amount of substance deposited or dissolved) is proportional to the quantity of electric charges passed through electrolyte.

question: Question 231 Two separate slab milling operations, 1 and 2, are performed with identical milling cutters. The depth of cut in operation 2 is twice that in operation 1. The other cutting parameters are identical. The ratio of maximum uncut chip thicknesses in operations 1 and 2 is _______
solution: [latex](0.70 \text { to } 0.72) [/latex] [latex] t_{\max }=\frac{2 f}{N Z} \sqrt{\frac{d}{D}}[/latex] Formula for maximum uncut thickness [latex] \therefore \quad \frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{d_{1}}{d_{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=0.707[/latex] [latex] (\therefore D_{1}=D_{2})[/latex]

question: Question 232 Within the Heat Affected Zone (HAZ) in a fusion welding process, the work material undergoes
solution: The heat affected zone (HAZ) is the area of base metal which is not melted & has had its micro structural & properties altered in Fusion welding. The extend & magnitude of property change depends primarily on the base material, the well filler metal, amount & concentration heat input by Fusion weld process.

options.A: microstructural changes but does not melt
options.C: both melting and microstructural changes after solidification
options.D: melting and retains the original microstructure after solidification

question: Question 233 For spot welding of two steel sheets (base metal) each of 3 mm thickness, welding current of  10000 A is applied for 0.2 s. The heat dissipated to the base metal is 1000 J. Assuming that the heat required for melting 1[latex]mm^{3}[/latex]  volume of steel is 20 J and interfacial contact resistance between sheets is 0.0002[latex]\Omega[/latex], the volume (in [latex]mm^{3}[/latex] ) of weld nugget is _______
solution: Total heat generation [latex] \begin{aligned} &=I^{2} R t \\ &=(10000)^{2} \times 0.0002 \times 0.2 \\ &=4000 \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}[/latex] Heat required to melt the nugget [latex] =4000-1000=3000 \mathrm{J}[/latex] Volume of nugget [latex] =\frac{3000}{20}=150 \mathrm{mm}^{3}[/latex]

question: Question 234 Which pair of following statements is correct for orthogonal cutting using a single-point cutting tool? P.  Reduction in friction angle increases cutting force Q. Reduction in friction angle decreases cutting force R. Reduction in friction angle increases chip thickness S. Reduction in friction angle decreases chip thickness
solution: For orthogonal cutting using a single-point cutting tool reduction in friction angle will increase the shear angle From Merchant theory [latex]\phi =\frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\alpha }{2}-\frac{\beta }{2}[/latex] [latex]\alpha \rightarrow[/latex] rate angle (constant) [latex]\beta \rightarrow[/latex] friction angle [latex]\phi \rightarrow[/latex] shear angle [latex]\beta \downarrow \phi \uparrow[/latex] we can see that as shear angle will increase shear plane area will get decrease which results decrease in cutting force subsequently reduction in chip thickness.

question: Question 235 The diameter of a recessed ring was measured by using two spherical balls of diameter [latex]d_{2}=60[/latex]  mm and [latex]d_{1}=40[/latex]  mm as shown in the figure. The distance [latex]H_{2}=35.55[/latex]  mm and [latex]H_{1}=20.55[/latex]  mm. The diameter (D, in mm) of the ring gauge  is _______

Question 236 A cylindrical blind riser with diameter d and height h, is placed on the top of the mold cavity of a closed type sand mold as shown in the figure. If the riser is of constant volume, then the rate of solidification in the riser is the least when the ratio h:d is
solution: For least solidification time, surface area should be minimum [latex] \begin{aligned} A&=\pi d h+\frac{\pi d^{2}}{4} \quad(\text { for top rises }) \\ V &=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} h \\ \Rightarrow \quad h &=\frac{4 V}{\pi d^{2}} \\ A &=\frac{4 V}{d}+\frac{\pi d^{2}}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex] For area to be minimum, [latex] \begin{aligned} & \frac{\partial A}{\partial d}=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad&-\frac{4 V}{d^{2}}+\frac{\pi d}{2}=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad d^{3}&=\frac{8 V}{\pi}=\frac{8}{\pi} \times \frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} \times h \\ \Rightarrow \qquad & \frac{h}{d}=\frac{1}{2}=1: 2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 237 The hot tearing in a metal casting is due to
solution: Hot tear is a defect that occurs during solidification of a casting. Though steel is poured at high temperature, this temperature is low relative to high freezing temperature range of steel.

question: Question 238 Cutting tool is much harder than the workpiece. Yet the tool wears out during the tool-work interaction, because
solution: Tool wears out during the tool-work interaction because extra hardness is imported to the workpiece due to severe rate of strain on the tool tip.

options.A: extra hardness is imparted to the workpiece due to coolant used
options.B: oxide layers on the workpiece surface impart extra hardness to it
options.C: extra hardness is imparted to the workpiece due to severe rate of strain
options.D: vibration is induced in the machine tool

Question 240 A minimal spanning tree in network flow models involves
solution: A path forms a loop or cycle if it connects to itself at the end. A spanning tree links all the nodes of network with no cycle/loops allowed.

options.A: all the nodes with cycle/loop allowed
options.B: all the nodes with cycle/loop not allowed
options.C: shortest path between start and end nodes

question: Question 241 A straight turning operation is carried out using a single point cutting tool on an AISI 1020 steel rod.  The feed is 0.2 mm/rev and the depth of cut is 0.5 mm. The tool has a side cutting edge angle of 60[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The uncut chip thickness (in mm) is _______
solution: (0.08 to 0.12) [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta+\Psi &=90^{\circ} \\ \theta &=90^{\circ}-60^{\circ}=30^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] (uncut chip thickness) [latex] \begin{array}{l} =f \sin \theta=0.2 \times \sin 30^{\circ} \\ =0.1 \mathrm{mm} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 242 The process utilizing mainly thermal energy for removing material is
solution:
Machining by laser beam is achieved through 
 thermo-optic interaction between the beam and 
 work material. Following phases are involved: (i) interaction of laser beam with work material (ii) heat conduction and temperature rise (iii) melting, vaporization and ablation.

question: Question 243 A rectangular hole of size 100 mm x 50 mm is to be made on a 5 mm thick sheet of steel having ultimate tensile strength and shear strength of 500 MPa and 300 MPa, respectively. The hole is made by punching process. Neglecting the effect of clearance, the punching force (in kN) is (
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Shear area } &=P \times t \\ &=2(100+50) \times 5=1500 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Punching force: [latex] \begin{aligned} F &=\tau \times A_{s}=300 \times 1500 \\ &=450 \times 10^{ 3} \mathrm{N}=450 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 244 A hole of 20 mm diameter is to be drilled in a steel block of 40 mm thickness. The drilling is performed at rotational speed of 400 rpm and feed rate of 0.1 mm/rev. The required approach and over run of the drill together is equal to the radius of drill. The drilling time (in minute) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Drilling time: } t &=\frac{L}{f N} \\ L=\text { thickness } &+\text { Approach + Overrun } \\ &=40+10=50 \mathrm{mm} \\ & f=0.1 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{reV}\\ N&=400 \mathrm{rpm} \\ \therefore t=\frac{50}{0.1 \times 400}&=\frac{500}{400}=1.25 \mathrm{minutes} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 245 A mild steel plate has to be rolled in one pass such that the final plate thickness is 2/[latex]3^{rd}[/latex]  of the initial thickness, with the entrance speed of 10 m/min and roll diameter of 500 mm. If the plate widens by 2% during rolling, the exit velocity (in m/min) is _______
solution: since there is no change in metal volume at a give point per unit time throughout the process. therefore [latex] \begin{aligned} b_{i} h_{i} v_{i}&=b_{f} h_{f} v_{f} \\ &\begin{aligned} \text { Given, } \quad \frac{h_{f}}{h_{i}}&=\frac{2}{3} \\ \frac{b_{f}}{b_{i}}&=1.02 \end{aligned} \\ \therefore v_{f}&=\frac{b_{i}}{b_{f}} \times \frac{h_{i}}{h_{f}} \times v_{i}=\frac{1}{1.02} \times \frac{2}{3} \times 10 \\ &=14.7 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 246 For the CNC part programming, match Group A with Group B:
Question 247 With respect to metal working, match Group A with Group B:
Question 248 The relationship between true strain ([latex]\varepsilon_{T}[/latex]) and engineering strain ([latex]\varepsilon_{E}[/latex])  in a uniaxial tension test is given as
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { True strain: } d \epsilon_{T}&=\frac{d L}{L} \\ \qquad \epsilon_{T}&=\int_{L_{0}}^{L} \frac{d L}{L}=\ln \frac{L}{L_{0}}\\ \text { As } \quad d V&=0\\ A L &=A_{0} L_{0} \\ \frac{L}{L_{0}} &=\frac{A_{0}}{A} \\ \epsilon_{E} &=\frac{L-L_{0}}{L_{0}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{L}{L_{0}} &=1+\epsilon_{E}\\ \therefore \quad \epsilon_{T}&=\ln \left(1+\epsilon_{E}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 249 The following four unconventional machining processes are available in a shop floor. The most appropriate one to drill a hole of square cross section of 6 mm x 6 mm and 25 mm deep is
solution:
EDM is most suitable process of square holes, 
intricate triangular holes etc.

question: Question 250 Match the Machine Tools (Group A) with the probable Operations (Group B):
Question 251 A robot arm PQ with end coordinates P(0,0) and Q(2,5) rotates counter clockwise about P in the XY plane by 90[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The new coordinate pair of the end point Q is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{l} x^{\prime} \\ y^{\prime} \end{array}\right] &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l} x \\ y \end{array}\right] \\ \text { Here } \theta &=90^{\circ} \\ \left[\begin{array}{l} x^{\prime} \\ y^{\prime} \end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{ll} 0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l} 2 \\ 5 \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c} -5 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 252 The flatness of a machine bed can be measured using
solution: Auto collimater is used to measure the flatness of the machine bed. Vernier calipers is used to measure the dimensions (dia) of component. Height gauge measures height.

question: Question 253 If the Taylor's tool life exponent n is 0.2, and the tool changing time is 1.5 min, then the tool life (in min)  for maximum production rate is _______
solution: Given,n=0.2 [latex] T_{c t}=1.5 \text { minute }[/latex] Tool life for maximum production rate, [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\left(\frac{1}{n}-1\right) T_{c t} \\ \therefore \text { Tool life } &=\left(\frac{1}{0.2}-1\right) \times 1.5 \\ &=4 \times 1.5=6 \text { minutes } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 254 For the given assembly: 25 H7/g8, match Group A with Group B

Question 255 During pure orthogonal turning operation of a hollow cylindrical pipe, it is found that the thickness of the chip produced is 0.5 mm. The feed given to the zero degree rake angle tool is 0.2 mm/rev. The shear strain produced during the operation is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma &=\cot \phi+\tan (\phi-\alpha) \\ \text { Given, } \alpha&=0 \\ &=0.2 \mathrm{mm} \\ t_{c} &=0.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ r &=\frac{t}{t_{c}}=\frac{0.2}{0.5}=0.4 \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha}=r \\ \therefore \gamma(\text { shear strain }) &=\cot \phi+\tan (\phi-\alpha) \\ &=\frac{1+\tan ^{2} \phi}{\tan \phi}=\frac{1+0.4^{2}}{0.4} \\ &=\frac{1.16}{0.4}=2.9 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 256 A metal rod of initial length [latex]L_{0}[/latex]  is subjected to a drawing process. The length of the rod at any instant is given by the expression, [latex]L(t)=L_{0}(1+t^2)[/latex]  , where t is the time in minutes. The true strain rate (in [latex]min^{-1}[/latex]) at the end of one minute is  _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L(t)&= L_{0}\left(1+t^{2}\right) \\ \Rightarrow d L&= L_{0} \times 2 t d t \\ \text{As }\quad d\epsilon _{T}&=\frac{d L}{L} \\ d \varepsilon_{T}&=\frac{L_{0} 2 t d t}{L_{0}\left(1+t^{2}\right)} \\ \frac{d \epsilon_{T}}{d t} &=\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}} \\ \text{at}\qquad t &=1 \mathrm{min} \\ \frac{d \epsilon_{T}}{d t}&=\frac{2 \times 1}{1+t^{2}}=1 \; {min} ^{-1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 257 In solid-state welding, the contamination layers between the surfaces to be welded are removed by
solution: Plastic deformation is used to remove contamination layers between the surfaces to be welded, in solid-state welding.

question: Question 258 The process of reheating the martensitic steel to reduce its brittleness without any significant loss in its hardness is
solution: Martensitic steel is very hard and brittle after quenching. To reduce brittleness while retaining most of the hardness, the steel is reheated below the critical temperature and then cooled. This heat treatment process is called tempering.

question: Question 259 The main cutting force acting on a tool during the turning (orthogonal cutting) operation of a metal is 400 N. The turning was performed using 2 mm depth of cut and 0.1 mm/rev feed rate. The specific cutting pressure [latex](in N/mm^{2})[/latex]   is
solution: Cutting force [latex]F_c=400 \; N[/latex] depth [latex]d=2 \; mm[/latex] feed rate [latex]f=0.1 \; mm/rev.[/latex] It means per revolution it moves 0.1 mm (t) Specific cutting pressure [latex]=\frac{F_c}{d \times t}=\frac{400}{2 \times 0.1}=2000 \; N/mm^2[/latex]

question: Question 260 The major difficulty during welding of aluminium is due to its
solution: Aluminium has high tendency of oxidation so during welding it is converted into aluminium oxide ([latex]\text{Al}_2O_3[/latex]) and [latex]\text{Al}_2O_3[/latex] has very high melting point ([latex]2702^{\circ}C[/latex]), so now it will not melt and welding can not be performed easily.

question: Question 261 Which one of the following instruments is widely used to check and calibrate geometric features of machine tools during their assembly?
solution: To check and calibrate geometric features of machine tools, we use laser interferometer.

question: Question 262 For machining a rectangular island represented by coordinates P(0,0), Q(100,0), R(100,50) and S(0,50) on a casting using CNC milling machine, an end mill with a diameter of 16 mm is used. The trajectory of the cutter centre to machine the island PQRS is
solution:
Normal Coordinates : [latex]
 P(0,0), Q(100,0), R(100,50), S(0,50) [/latex] With cutter compensation : [latex]
 P_{1}(-8,-8), Q(108,-8), R(108,58), S(-8,58) [/latex]

question: Question 263 In orthogonal turning of a bar of 100 mm diameter with a feed of 0.25 [latex]mm/rev[/latex], depth of cut of 4 mm and cutting velocity of 90 [latex]m/min[/latex], it is observed that the main (tangential) cutting force is perpendicular to the friction force acting at the chip-tool interface. The main (tangential) cutting force is 1500 N. The normal force acting at the chip-tool interface in  N  is
solution: Since normal force is given by [latex]N=F_C \cos \alpha -F_r \sin \alpha[/latex] and [latex]\alpha =0^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]N=F_C \cos \alpha[/latex] [latex]N=F_C=1500\; N[/latex]

question: Question 264 In orthogonal turning of a bar of 100 mm diameter with a feed of 0.25 [latex]mm/rev[/latex], depth of cut of 4 mm and cutting velocity of 90 [latex]m/min[/latex], it is observed that the main (tangential) cutting force is perpendicular to the friction force acting at the chip-tool interface. The main (tangential) cutting force is 1500 N. The orthogonal rake angle of the cutting tool in degree is
solution: Since it is given that the main (tangential) cutting force is perpendicular to friction force acting at the chip-tool interface, therefore rake angle [latex]\alpha =0^{\circ}[/latex]

question: Question 265 During the electrochemical machining (ECM) of iron (atomic weight = 56, valency = 2) at current of 1000 A with 90% current efficiency, the material removal rate was observed to be 0.26 gm/s. If Titanium (atomic weight = 48, valency = 3) is machined by the ECM process at the current of  2000 A with 90% current efficiency, the expected material removal rate in gm/s will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{MRR} &=\frac{\rho I}{\rho f}=\frac{A I}{\rho z F} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.26 &=\frac{28 \times 1000 \times 0.9}{\rho \times 96500} \\ \rho &=0.9956 \\ \text { New MRR } &=\frac{\frac{48}{3} \times 2000 \times 0.9}{0.9956 \times 96500} \\ &=0.30 \mathrm{gm} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 266 cylindrical pains of [latex]25^{_{+0.010}^{+0.020}}[/latex]
mm diameter are electroplated in a shop. Thickness of the plating is 
[latex]30^{\pm 2.0}[/latex]
 micron. Neglecting gage tolerances, the size of the GO gage in mm to inspect the plated components is
solution: Size of the Go gauge [latex] \begin{aligned} &=(25+0.20)+\left[(30+2) \times 10^{-3}\right] \times 2 \\ &=25.084 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 269 A cube shaped casting solidifies in 5 min. The solidification time in min for a cube of the same material, which is 8 times heavier than the original casting, will be
solution: Solidification time, [latex] \begin{aligned} t &=k\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)^{2} \\ \text{For cube,}\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)&=\frac{a}{6}\\ \frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}} &=\frac{a_{1}^{2}}{a_{2}^{2}} \\ t_{2} &=5\left(\frac{a_{2}}{a_{1}}\right)^{2} \quad \cdots(i)\\ m_{1} &=V_{1} \times \rho_{1} \\ m_{2} &=V_{2} \times \rho_{2} \\ V_{2} &=8 V_{1} \\ a_{2}^{3} &=8 a_{1}^{3}\\ \Rightarrow \quad a_{2}&=2 a_{1} \\ \text{or}\frac{a_{2}}{a_{1}}&=2\\ \text{Substituting }\frac{a_{2}}{a_{1}}&=2 \text{ in Eq. (1), we get}\\ t_{2}&=5(2)^{2}=5 \times 4=20 \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 270 A steel bar 200 mm in diameter is turned at a feed of 0.25 mm/rev with a depth of cut of 4 mm. The rotational speed of the workpiece is 160 rpm. The material removal rate in [latex]mm^{3}/s[/latex]
 is
solution: Cutting speed is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} V_c&=\frac{\pi DN}{60} \\ V_c&=\frac{\pi 200\times160}{60} \\ V_c&=1675.51 \;mm/s \\ &\text{MRR is given by} \\ &=f\times d \times V_c \\ &=0.25\times 4 \times 1675.516\\ &= 1675.516\;mm^3/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 271 Match the CORRECT pairs
solution: Friction welding: Joining of cylindrical dissimilar materials. Gas metal arc welding: Consumable electrode wire. Tungsten inert gas welding: Nonconsumable electrode. Electroslag welding: Joining of thick plates

question: Question 272 In a rolling process, the state of stress of the material undergoing deformation is
solution: Most metal rolling operations are similar in that the work material is plastically deformed by compressive forces between two constantly spinning rolls. Thus in a Rolling process, the material undergoing deformation is in the state of pure biaxial compression

question:
Question 273 In a DC arc welding operation, the voltage-arc length characteristic was obtained as [latex]V_{arc}[/latex]
 = 20+5l where the arc length l was varied between 5 mm and 7 mm. Here [latex]V_{arc}[/latex]
 denotes the arc voltage in Volts. The arc current was varied from 400 A to 500 A. Assuming linear power source characteristic, the open circuit voltage and the short circuit current for the welding operation are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{\mathrm{arc}} &=20+5 l \\ l &=5 \mathrm{mm}, V_{\mathrm{arc}}=45 V \\ l &=7 \mathrm{mm}, V_{\mathrm{arc}}=55 \mathrm{V} \\ V &=V_{0}-\frac{V_{0}}{I_{s}} I \\ V_{0} &=\text { Open circuit voltage } \\ I_{s} &=\text { Short circuit current } \\ 45 &=V_{0}-\frac{V_{0}}{I_{s}} \times 500 \\ 55 &=V_{0}-\frac{V_{0}}{I_{s}} \times 400 \\ \Rightarrow V_{0} &=95 \mathrm{volts} \\ I_{s} &=950 \mathrm{amp} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 274 In a single pass rolling process using 410mm diameter steel rollers, a strip of width 140mm and thickness 8mm undergoes 10% reduction of thickness. The angle of bite in radians is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta H &=D(1-\cos \alpha) \\ \cos \alpha &=1-\frac{\Delta H}{D}=1-\frac{0.1 \times 8}{410}=0.99804 \\ \text{or}\quad \alpha &=\cos ^{-1}(0.99804)=3.58^{\circ} \\ &=0.0625 \;\text{radians}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 275 Calculate the punch size in mm, for a circular blanking operation for which details are given below

question:
Question 276 In a single pass drilling operation, a through hole of 15 mm diameter is to be drilled in a steel plate of 50 mm thickness. Drill spindle speed is 500 rpm, feed is  0.2 mm/rev and drill point angle is [latex]118^{\circ}[/latex]
. Assuming 2 mm clearance at approach and exit, the total drill time (in seconds) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Drilling time } &=\frac{\text { Distance covered }}{\text { Speed }} \\ \text { Distance covered } &=\frac{50+2 \times 2+4.5}{0.2 \times \frac{500}{60}} \\ &=35.1 \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 277 Details pertaining to and orthogonal metal cutting process are given below: The shear strain rate in [latex]s^{-1}[/latex]
 during the process is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} r &=0.4 \\ t_{1} &=0.6 \mathrm{mm} \\ \alpha &=10^{\circ} \\ V_{c} &=2.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ t_{m} &=25 \mu \mathrm{m} \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha}=0.4233\\ \Rightarrow \quad \phi&=22.9^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Shear strain rate [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{V_{c} \cos \alpha}{\cos (\phi-\alpha) \times t_{m}} \\ &=\frac{2.5 \cos 10}{\cos 12.9 \times 25 \times 10^{-6}} \\ &=1.0104 \times 10^{5} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 278 A solid cylinder of diameter 100 mm and height 50 mm is forged between two frictionless flat dies to a height of 25 mm. The percentage change in diameter is
solution: since volume remains constant [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad V_{1} &=V_{2} \\ \frac{\pi}{4} d_{1}^{2} h_{1} &=\frac{\pi}{4} d_{2}^{2} h_{2} \\ (100)^{2}(50) &=\mathrm{d}_{2}^{2}(25) \\ \text { or }\qquad d_{2} &=141.4 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { or } \quad \text { \% change } &=\frac{d_{2}-d_{1}}{d_{1}} \times 100 \\ &=\left(\frac{141.4-100}{100}\right) \times 100 \\ &=0.414=41.4 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 279 A CNC vertical milling machine has to cut a straight slot of 10 mm width and 2 mm depth by a cutter of 10 mm diameter between points (0,0) and (100, 100) on the XY plane (dimensions in mm). The feed rate used for milling is 50 mm/min. Milling time for the slot (in seconds) is
solution: Distance travelled for cut between points (0,0) and (100, 100) By Pythagoras theorem [latex]d=\sqrt{100^2+100^2}=141.42\;mm[/latex] Feed Rate   [latex]f = 50 \; min /mm=\frac{50}{60}=0.833\; mm/sec[/latex] Time required to cut distance (d) [latex]t=\frac{d}{f}=\frac{141.42}{0.833}=169.7\simeq 170\; sec[/latex]

Question 286 A single-point cutting tool with [latex]12^{\circ}[/latex]
 rake angle is used to machine a steel work- piece. The depth of cut, i.e. uncut thickness is 0.81mm. The chip thickness under orthogonal machining condition is 1.8mm. The shear angle is approximately
solution: Uncut chip thickness [latex]=0.81 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Chip thickness [latex]=1.8 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \tan \theta &=\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha \alpha}=\frac{\cos \alpha}{\frac{1}{r}-\sin \alpha} \\ &=\frac{\cos 12^{\circ}}{\frac{t_{2}}{t_{1}}-\sin 12^{\circ}} \\ \tan \theta &=\frac{\cos 12^{\circ}}{\left(\frac{1.8}{0.81}\right)-\sin 12^{\circ}} \\ \theta &=25.9^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 293 The maximum possible draft in cold rolling of sheet increases with the
solution: The main objective in rolling is to decrease the thickness of the metal. The relation for the rolling is given by [latex]F=\mu P_r[/latex] where, [latex]F= [/latex] tangential frictional force [latex]\mu =[/latex] Coefficient of friction [latex]P_r=[/latex] Normal force between the roll and work piece Now, from the increase in [latex]\mu[/latex], the draft in cold rolling of sheet increases.

question: Question 294 In a shear cutting operation, a sheet of 5mm thickness is cut along a length of 200mm. The cutting blade is 400mm long and zero-shear (S=0) is provided on the edge. The ultimate shear strength of the sheet is 100MPa and penetration to thickness ratio is 0.2. Neglect friction. A shear of 20mm (S=20mm) is now provided on the blade. Assuming force vs displacement curve to be trapezoidal, the maximum force (in kN) exerted is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} s&=10 \mathrm{mm} \text { (for length of } 200 \mathrm{mm}) \\ F &=\frac{F_{\max } \times p t}{s}=\frac{100}{10}=10 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 295 In a shear cutting operation, a sheet of 5mm thickness is cut along a length of 200mm. The cutting blade is 400mm long and zero-shear (S=0) is provided on the edge. The ultimate shear strength of the sheet is 100MPa and penetration to thickness ratio is 0.2. Neglect friction. Assuming force vs displacement curve to be rectangular, the work done (in J) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Maximum force: }F&=L(t) . \tau \\ L &=\text { Perimeter of cut } \\ t &=\text { thickness of cut } \\ P &=\text { Penetration } \\ F &=200 \times(5) \times 100 \\ &=100 \mathrm{kN} \\ \text{Work done}&=F \times p t \\ &=20000 \times 5 \times 10^{-3} \times 0.2 \\ &=100 \mathrm{Nm}=100 \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 296 A taper hole is inspected using a CMM, with a probe of 2mm diameter. At a height, Z=10mm from the bottom, 5 points are touched and a diameter of circle (not compensated for probe size) is obtained as 20mm. similarly, a 40mm diameter is obtained at a height Z=40mm. the smaller diameter (in mm) of hole at Z=0 is
solution: [latex]\tan \theta=\frac{C B}{A B}=\frac{10}{30}=\frac{1}{3} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Now, } \quad \tan \theta &=\frac{x}{10} \\ \frac{1}{3} &=\frac{x}{10} \\ x&=\frac{10}{3} \mathrm{mm}=3.33 \mathrm{mm}\\ \text{So, dia at } z&=0 \\ =20-2 x=20-2 &\times 3.33=13.334 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 297 For tool A, Taylor's tool life exponent (n) is 0.45 and constant (K) is 90. Similarly for tool B, n=0.3 and K=60. The cutting speed (in m/min) above which tool A will have a higher tool life than tool B is
solution: By taylor's tool life equation [latex]V T^{n}=K [/latex] Let V is the speed above which tool A will have a higher tool life than tool B , but at V, [latex]T_{A}=T_{B} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{then }\quad V T_{A}^{0.45}&=90\\ V T_{B}^{0.3}&=60\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking log both sides [latex] \begin{aligned} \log V+0.45 \log T_{A} & =\log 90 \\ \log V+0.3 \log T_{B} & =\log 60 \\ \log T_{A}-\log T_{B} & =\frac{\log 90-\log V}{0.45} \\ \text{as}\qquad T_{A}&=T_{B}\\ 0=&\frac{0.3 \log 90-0.3 \log V-0.45 \log 60+0.45 \log V}{0.45 \times 0.3}\\ 0.4925&=0.15 \log V \\ V&=26.67 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 298 Two pipes of inner diameter 100mm and outer diameter 110mm each joined by flash butt welding using 30V power supply. At the interface, 1mm of material melts from each pipe which has a resistance of 42.4[latex]\Omega[/latex]. If the unit melt energy is 64.4MJ[latex]m^{-3}[/latex], then time required for welding in seconds is
solution: Unit melting energy [latex] \begin{aligned} &=64.4 \mathrm{MJ} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \text { Voltage } &=30 \mathrm{V}\\ \text{Resistance} &=42.4\mathrm{ohm}\\ \text { Melting energy } &=\frac{\pi}{4}\left(d_{0}^{2}-d_{l}^{2}\right) t \times 64.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{J} \\ &=212.32 \mathrm{J} \\ d_{0} &=110 \mathrm{mm} \\ d_{i} &=100 \mathrm{mm} \\ t &=2 \times 1=2 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Now, } \quad I^{2} R t &=\text { Melting energy } \\ \frac{V^{2}}{R} t &=\text { Melting energy } \\ \text { Time required } &=\frac{212.32 \times 42.4}{30^{2}} \mathrm{second}=10 \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 302 The material property which depends only on the basic crystal structure is
solution: Fracture strength be a material property which depends on the basic crystal structure. Fracture strength depends on the strength of the material. Elastic constant depends not only on material parameters but also on the experimental geometry.

question: Question 303 In a machining experiment, tool life was found to vary with the cutting speed in the following manner: What is the percentage increase in tool life when the cutting speed is halved?
solution: Taylor's tool life equation [latex] V T^{0.5}=K=540[/latex] if cutting speed is halved. [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{1}=V & \qquad T_{1}=T \\ V_{2}=V / 2 &\qquad T_{2}=? \\ V_{1} T_{1}^{0.5} & =V_{2} T_{2}^{0.5} \\ T_{2} & =T_{1}\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)^{2}=T_{1}\left(\frac{V}{V / 2}\right)^{2} \\ T_{2} & =4 T_{1}=4 T \end{aligned}[/latex] Percentage increase in tool life [latex] =\frac{T_{2}-T_{1}}{T_{1}} \times 100=\frac{4 T-T}{T} \times 100=300 \%[/latex]

question: Question 304 In a machining experiment, tool life was found to vary with the cutting speed in the following manner: The exponent (n) and constant (k) of the Taylor's tool life equation are
solution: Taylor's tool life equations, [latex] V T^{m}= [/latex]constant =K [latex] \begin{aligned} (60)(81)^{n}&=k \qquad \cdots(i)\\ (90)(36)^{n}&=k \qquad \cdots(ii)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Divide Eq. (i) by Eq. (ii) [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{(60)(81)^{n}}{(90)(36)^{n}}&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \left(\frac{81}{36}\right)^{n}&=\left(\frac{90}{60}\right)\\ \Rightarrow \quad(2.25)^{n}&=1.5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad n \ln (2.25)&=\ln 1.5 \\ \Rightarrow n&=0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] Keep the value of n in Eq. (i) [latex] (60)(81)^{0.5}=k [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; k=540[/latex]

question: Question 305 Match the items in Column I and Column II.

Exothermic padding [latex] \longrightarrow [/latex] control cooling of critical section Riser [latex] \longrightarrow [/latex] supply additional metal to the casting

question:
Question 306 What are the upper and lower limits of the shaft represented by 60 [latex]f_{8}[/latex]
? Use the following data: Diameter 60 lies in the diameter step of 50-80mm Fundamental tolerance unit, i, in [latex]\mu m= 0.45D^{1/3}+0.001D[/latex]
, where D is the representative size in mm; Tolerance value for IT8=25i. Fundamental deviation for 'f' shaft = [latex]-5.5D^{0.41}[/latex]
solution: [latex] 60 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] diameter lies in the diameter step of [latex]50-80 \mathrm{mm} . [/latex] Therefore, geometric mean diameter, [latex] D=\sqrt{D_{\min } \times D_{\max }}=\sqrt{50 \times 80}=63.246 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Fundamental tolerance, [latex] \begin{aligned} i &=\left(0.45 D^{1 / 3}+0.001 D\right) \mu \mathrm{m} \\ &=\left[0.45(63.246)^{1 / 3}+0.001(63.246)\right] \\ &=1.859 \mu \mathrm{m}=0.00186 \mathrm{mm} \\ I T 8 &=25 \mathrm{i}=25 \times 0.00186=0.04646 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Fundamental deviation for 'f' shaft, [latex] \begin{aligned} \epsilon_{d} &=-5.5 D^{0.41} \\ &=-5.5[63.246]^{0.41} \\ &=-0.030115 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Upper limit of shaft [latex] \begin{aligned} &= \text{Basic size} - \text{ Fundamental deviation}\\ &=60-0.03012=59.9678 \mathrm{mm} \\ &\approx 59.97 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Lower limit of shaft [latex] \begin{aligned} &= \text{Upper limit }- \text{Tolerance}\\ &=59.97-0.0464=59.9236 \mathrm{mm}\\ & \approx 59.924 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 307 Match the following
solution: M05 [latex] \longrightarrow [/latex] Spindle Stop/Off G01 [latex]\longrightarrow [/latex] Linear Interpolation G04 [latex] \longrightarrow [/latex] Dwell G90 [latex]\longrightarrow [/latex] Absolute Coordinate System or (Absolute Programming)

question: Question 308 Electrochemical machining is performed to remove material from an iron surface of 20mmx20mm under the following conditions: The material removal rate (in g/s) is
solution: Electrochemical machining Inter electrode gap, [latex]y=0.2 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Supply voltage (DC), [latex]V=12 \mathrm{V} [/latex] Specific resistance of electrolyte, [latex] 1 / K=2 \Omega \mathrm{cm}[/latex] Atomic weight of iron [latex]A=55.85 [/latex] Valency of iron: [latex]Z=2 [/latex] Faraday's constant: F=96540 coulombs Material is removed from iron surface of [latex] 20 \mathrm{mm} \times 20 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Surface area: } a &=20 \times 20 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ &=2 \times 2 \mathrm{cm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Rate of mass removal in the form [latex] \dot{m}=\frac{A I}{Z F}[/latex] Current density with this gap is [latex] J=\frac{K(V-\Delta V)}{y}[/latex] Assume total over voltage to be 0 volt [latex] (\Delta V=0) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} J &=\frac{K V}{y}=\frac{V}{y\left(\frac{1}{K}\right)} \\ &=\frac{12 V}{\left(\frac{0.2}{10} \mathrm{cm}\right)(2 \Omega \mathrm{cm})}=300 \mathrm{amp} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Current: I=(Current Density)[latex] \times [/latex](Surface Area) [latex] \begin{array}{l} =300 \mathrm{Amp} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \times\left(2 \times 2 \mathrm{cm}^{2}\right) \\ =1200 \mathrm{Amp} \end{array}[/latex] Rate of mass removal is [latex] \dot{m}=\frac{A I}{Z F}=\frac{(55.85)(1200)}{2 \times 96540}=0.3471 \mathrm{gm} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question: Question 309 Minimum shear strain in orthogonal turning with a cutting tool of zero rake angle is
solution: During orthogonal machining. Shear strain: [latex]\gamma=\cot \phi+\tan (\phi-\alpha) [/latex] Cutting tool having rake angle: [latex]\alpha=0^{\circ} [/latex] then [latex]\quad \gamma=\cot \phi+\tan \phi[/latex] For minimum value of shea [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d \gamma}{d \phi} &=\frac{d}{d \phi}(\cot \phi+\tan \phi)=0 \\ \frac{d \gamma}{d \phi} &=-\operatorname{cosec}^{2} \phi+\sec ^{2} \phi=0\\ -\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \phi}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \phi} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{\cos ^{2} \phi-\sin ^{2} \phi}{\cos ^{2} \phi \sin ^{2} \phi}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \cos 2 \phi=0=\cos \frac{\pi}{2}&=\cos \frac{3 \pi}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \phi &= \frac{\pi}{4}\\ \frac{d^{2} \gamma}{d \phi^{2}}&=-2 \text{cosec} \phi \cdot(-\operatorname{cosec} \phi \cot \phi) \\ &+2\sec\phi.(\sec\phi\tan\phi)\\ \frac{d^{2} \gamma}{d \phi^{2}}&=2 \text{cosec}^{2} \phi \cot \phi+2 \sec ^{2} \phi\\ \left.\frac{d^{2} \gamma}{d \phi^{2}}\right|_{a+\phi=\frac{\pi}{4}}& \gt 0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore [latex]\gamma [/latex] is minimum at [latex]\phi=\frac{\pi}{4} [/latex] Therefore minimum shear strain [latex]\gamma[/latex] is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \gamma &=\cot \frac{\pi}{4}+\tan \frac{\pi}{4} \\ &=2^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]
