question: Question 311 Two streams of liquid metal, which are not hot enough to fuse properly, result into a casting defect known as
solution: Cold Shut: Two stream of liquid metal which are not hot enough to fuse properly result into a casting defect known as cold shut OR For a casting with gates at its two sides, the misrun may show up at the centre of the casting. When this happens, the defect is called a cold shut. Swell: This defect is found on the vertical surface of a casting if the moulding sand is deformed by the hydrostatic pressure caused by the high moisture content in the sand. Wash: A low projection on the drag surface of a casting commencing near the gate is called a wash. This is caused by erosion of sand due to the high velocity jet of liquid metal in bottom gating. Scab: This refers to the rough thin layer of a metal, protruding above the casting surface on the top of a thin layer of sand. The layer is held on the casting by a metal stringer through the sand. A scab results when the upheaved sand is separated from the mould surface and the liquid metal flows into the space between the mould and the displaced sand.

question: Question 312 Friction at the tool-chip interface can be reduced by
solution: Friction at tool-chip interface can be reduced by increasing the cutting speed.

question: Question 313 The effective number of lattice points in the unit cell of simple cubic, body centered cubic, and face centered cubic space lattices, respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text{Space Lattice }&\text{Effective Number of }\\ &\text{Lattice point in }&\text{unit cell}\\ & \text{Simple Cubic }&1 / 8 \times 8=1\\ &\text{Body Centered Cubic}\\ &\text { (B.C.C.) } &\quad 1 / 8 \times 8+1=2\\ &\text{Face Centered Cubic}\\ &(F.C.C.)&1 / 8 \times 8+1 / 2 \times 6=4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 314 In the feed drive of a Point - to - point open loop CNC drive, a stepper motor rotating at 200 steps/rev drives a table through a gear box and lead screw - nut mechanism (pitch = 4mm, number of starts =1). The [latex]gear \; ratio=(\frac{Output \; Rotational \; Speed}{Input\; Rotational\; Speed})[/latex] is given by U = 1/4. The stepper motor (driven by voltage pulses from a pulse generator) executes 1 step/ pulse of the pulse generator. The frequency of the pulse train from the pulse generator is f = 10,000 pulses per minute. A customer insists on a modification to change the BLU of the CNC drive to 10 microns without changing the table speed. The modification can be accomplished by
solution: Table speed is given by [latex]V=f\times BLU=10,000\frac{pulse}{min}\times 5\frac{pulse}{min}=50,000 \frac{\mu m}{min}[/latex] If U is halved BLU becomes double so frequency must be half for constant speed.

options.A: changing U to 1/2 and  reducing f to f/2
options.B: changing U to 1/8 and  increasing f to 2f
options.C: changing U to 1/2 and  keeping f unchanged
options.D: changing U unchanged and  increasing f to 2f

question: Question 315 In the feed drive of a Point - to - point open loop CNC drive, a stepper motor rotating at 200 steps/rev drives a table through a gear box and lead screw - nut mechanism (pitch = 4mm, number of starts =1). The [latex]gear \; ratio=(\frac{Output \; Rotational \; Speed}{Input\; Rotational\; Speed})[/latex] is given by U = 1/4. The stepper motor (driven by voltage pulses from a pulse generator) executes 1 step/ pulse of the pulse generator. The frequency of the pulse train from the pulse generator is f = 10,000 pulses per minute. The Basic Length Unit (BLU), i.e., the table movement corresponding to 1 pulse of the pulse generator, is
solution: BLU represents the smallest distance traveled Given that stepper motor rotate at 200 steps/rev So, revolution of motor in 1 step  [latex]=\frac{1}{200}\;rev/step[/latex] Output rotational speed or movement of lead screw is given by [latex]=\frac{1}{200}\times\frac{1}{4}=\frac{1}{800}\;rev[/latex] Movement of table after transfer from lead screw is given by [latex]=\frac{1}{800}\times p=\frac{1}{800}\times 4 =0.005mm=5 \; micron[/latex] where , p=pitch of screw

question: Question 316 Orthogonal turning is performed on a cylindrical workpiece with shear strength of 250 MPa. The following conditions are used: cutting velocity is 180 m/min, feed is 0.20 mm/rev, depth of cut is 3 mm, chip thickness ratio = 0.5. The orthogonal rake angle is [latex]7^{\circ}[/latex]. Apply Merchant's theory foranalysis. The cutting and frictional forces, respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{F_{c}}{F_{s}} &=\frac{\cos (\beta-\alpha)}{\cos (\phi+\beta-\alpha)} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad F_{c} &=320 \times \frac{\cos \left(41^{\circ}-7^{\circ}\right)}{\cos \left(28^{\circ}+41^{\circ}-7^{\circ}\right)} \\ &=565.08 \mathrm{N} \\ \tan(\beta-\alpha)&=\frac{F_{T}}{F_{C}}\\ \Rightarrow \qquad F_{T} &=F_{c} \tan (\beta-\alpha) \\ &=565 \tan \left(41^{\circ}-7^{\circ}\right) \\ &=565 \tan 34^{\circ}=381.55 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 317 Orthogonal turning is performed on a cylindrical workpiece with shear strength of 250 MPa. The following conditions are used: cutting velocity is 180 m/min, feed is 0.20 mm/rev, depth of cut is 3 mm, chip thickness ratio = 0.5. The orthogonal rake angle is [latex]7^{\circ}[/latex]. Apply Merchant's theory foranalysis. The shear plane angle (in degrees) and the shear force respectively are
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 \dot{\phi}+\beta-\alpha &=90^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tan \phi &=\frac{\cos \alpha}{\frac{t_{2}}{t_{1}}-\sin \alpha} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tan \phi &=\frac{\cos 7^{\circ}}{2-\sin 7^{\circ}} \\ \phi &=28^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] From Merchant first analysis we know that, [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 \phi+\beta-\alpha &=90^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow\left(2 \times 28^{\circ}\right)+\beta-7^{\circ} &=90^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \beta &=41^{\circ} \\ F_{s} &=\frac{\tau W t_{1}}{\sin \phi} \\ &=\frac{250 \times 3 \times 0.2}{\sin 28^{\circ}} \\&=319.5 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 318 A displacement sensor (a dial indicator) measures the lateral displacement of a mandrel mounted on the taper hole inside a drill spindle. The mandrel axis is an extension of the drill spindle taper hole axis and the protruding portion of the mandrel surface is perfectly cylindrical. Measurements are taken with the sensor placed at two positions P and Q as shown in figure. The readings are recorded as Rx = maximum deflection minus minimum deflection, corresponding to sensor position at X, over one rotation. If [latex]R_P=R_Q \gt 0[/latex], which one of the following would be consistent with the observation?
solution: A dial indicator (gauge) or clock indicator is a very versatile and sensitive instrument. It is used for : (i) determining errors in geometrical form, for example, ovality, out-of roundness, taper etc. (ii) determining positional errors of surface (iii) taking accurate measurements of deformation. Here equal deflections are shown in both the sensor P and sensor Q. So drill spindle rotational axis is parallel to the drill spindle taper hole axis.

options.A: The drill spindle rotational axis is coincident with the drill spindle taper hole axis
options.B: The drill spindle rotational axis intersects the drill spindle taper hole axis at point P
options.C: The drill spindle rotational axis is parallel to the drill spindle taper hole axis
options.D: The drill spindle rotational axis intersects the drill spindle taper hole axis at point Q

question: Question 319 The figure shows an incomplete schematic of a conventional lathe to be used for cutting threads with, different pitches. The speed gear box [latex]U_v[/latex] is shown and the feed gear box [latex]U_s[/latex] is to be placed. P, Q, R and S denote locations and have no other significance. Changes in [latex]U_v[/latex] should NOT affect the pitch of the thread being cut and changes in [latex]U_s[/latex], should NOT affect the cutting speed The correct connections and the correct placement of [latex]U_s[/latex] are given by
solution: The feed drive serves to transmit power from the spindle to the second operative unit of the lathe, that is, the carriage. It, thereby converts the rotary motion of the spindle into linear motion of the carriage. So, S and E are connected and [latex]U_s[/latex] is placed between S and E.

options.A: Q and E are connected. [latex]U_s[/latex] is placed between P and Q.
options.B: S and E are connected. [latex]U_s[/latex] is placed between R and S.
options.C: Q and E are connected. [latex]U_s[/latex] is placed between Q and E.
options.D: S and E are connected. [latex]U_s[/latex] is placed between S and E.

question: Question 320 In the deep drawing of cups, blanks show a tendency to wrinkle up around the periphery (flange). The most likely cause and remedy of the phenomenon are, respectively,
solution: Seamless cylinders and tubes can be made by hot drawing or cupping. The thickness of the cup is reduced and its length increased by drawing it through a series of dies having reduced clearance between the die and the punch. Due to reduction in its thickness, blanks shows a tendency to wrinkle up around the periphery because of buckling due to circumferential compression an due to this compression blank holder pressure increases.

options.A: Buckling due to circumferential compression; Increase blank holder pressure
options.B: High blank holder pressure and high friction; Reduce blank holder pressure and apply lubricant
options.C: High temperature causing increase in circumferential length; Apply coolant to blank
options.D: Buckling due to circumferential compression; decrease blank holder pressure

question: Question 321 In arc welding of a butt joint, the welding speed is to be selected such that highest cooling rate is achieved. Melting efficiency and heat transfer efficiency are 0.5 and 0.7, respectively. The area of the weld cross section is 5 [latex]mm^2[/latex] and the unit energy required to melt the metal is 10 J/[latex]mm^3[/latex]. If the welding power is 2 kW, the welding speed in mm/s is closest to
solution: Let the welding speed is V mm/sec Volume of weld/sec [latex] =5 \mathrm{Vmm}^{3} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex] [latex] (5 V) \times 10=2000 \times 0.5 \times 0.7[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow V=\frac{700}{50}=14 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question: Question 322 In a single pass rolling operation, a 20 mm thick plate with plate width of 100 mm, is reduced to 18 mm. The roller radius is 250 mm and rotational speed is 10 rpm. The average flow stress for the plate material is 300 MPa. The power required for the rolling operation in kW is closest to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h_{1}=20 \mathrm{mm} ; &\; h_{2}=18 \mathrm{mm} ;\; R=250 \mathrm{mm} \\ \quad \text { width }=& 100 \mathrm{mm} \\ N=& 10 \mathrm{rpm} \\ \sigma_{0}=& 300 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \therefore \quad \text { Load }=& \sigma_{0} \times L \times W \\ \text { when } \quad L&=\sqrt{R \Delta h} \\ \text{Load}&=300\times10^{6}\\ &\times \sqrt{0.25 \times(0.02-0.018) \times 0.1} \\ &=670 \mathrm{kN} \\ \text { Power } &=2 T \times \omega\\ \text { Load }&=300 \times 10^{6} & \\ =2 \times 670 \times 0.5 &\times \sqrt{0.25 \times(0.02-0.018)} \times\\ & 2 \pi \times \frac{10}{60}\\ &=15.68\mathrm(kW) \approx15.2\mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 323 A researcher conducts electrochemical machining (ECM) on a binary alloy (density 6000 kg/[latex]m^3[/latex]) of iron (atomic weight 56, valency 2) and metal P (atomic weight 24, valency 4). Faraday's constant = 96500 coulomb/mole. Volumetric material removal rate of the alloy is 50 [latex]mm^3[/latex]/sec at a current of 2000 A. The percentage of the metal P in the alloy is closest to
solution: For iron, atomic weight, [latex] A_{\mathrm{t}_{\mathrm{Fe}}}=56, \text { Valency: } r_{F e}=2[/latex] For metal P, at weight [latex] A_{t_{p}}=24, \text { Valency: } r_{p}=4 [/latex] For Alloy, density, [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho &=6000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ &=6 \mathrm{gm} / \mathrm{cc} \\ \mathrm{MRR}: Q &=50 \mathrm{mm}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ &=50 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{cc} / \mathrm{s} \\ \mathrm{MRR} &=\frac{e I}{F \rho} \\ \Rightarrow 50 \times 10^{-3} &=\frac{e \times 2000}{96500 \times 6} \\ e &=14.475 \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, let % of P in alloy =x [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \qquad \frac{1}{\mathrm{e}}&=\left(\frac{100-x}{100}\right) \frac{V_{F e}}{A_{\mathrm{t}_{\mathrm{Fe}}}}+\frac{x}{100} \times \frac{V_{P}}{A_{tp}} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \frac{1}{14.475}&=\left(\frac{100-x}{100}\right) \frac{2}{56}+\frac{x}{100} \times \frac{4}{24} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad x&=24.48 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 324 In a single point turning tool, the side rake angle and orthogonal rake angle are equal. [latex]\Phi[/latex] is the principle cutting edge angle and its range is [latex]0^{\circ}\leq \Phi \leq 90^{\circ}[/latex]. The chip flows in the orthogonal plane. The value of [latex]\Phi[/latex] is closest to
solution: Interconversion between ASA (American Standards Association) system and ORS (Orthogonal Rake System) is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} \tan\alpha_s&=\sin\lambda\tan\alpha-\cos\lambda\tan i \\ where, \\ \alpha_s &= \text{Side rake angle}\\ \alpha &= \text{orthogonal rake angle}\\ \lambda &= \text{Approach Anlge}=90^{\circ}-\phi \\ i&= 0^{\circ}=\text{inclination angle}\\ \tan\alpha&=\sin\lambda\tan\alpha-\cos\lambda\tan 0 \\ \frac{\tan\alpha}{\tan\alpha}&=\sin\lambda\\ \sin\lambda&=1\\ \lambda&=90^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, principal cutting edge angle is 90.

question: Question 325 While cooling, a cubical casting of side 40 mm undergoes 3%, 4% and 5% volume shrinkage during the liquid state, phase transition and solid state, respectively. The volume of metal compensated from the riser is
solution: The volume of metal compensated by riser does not constitute cooling during solid state. Riser can compensate for volume shrinkage only in liquid stage and transition stage. [latex] \therefore[/latex] Volume compensated by riser [latex] =3+4=7 \%[/latex]

question: Question 326 Internal gear cutting operation can be performed by
solution: Internal gear cutting operation can be performed by shaping with pinion cutter. In the case of "rotating pinion type cutter", such an indexing is not required, therefore, this type is more productive and so common.

question: Question 327 For generating a Coon's surface we require
solution: Coon's surface is obtained by blending four boundary curves. The main advantage of Coon’s surface is its ability to fit a smooth surface through digitized points in space such as those used in reverse engineering.

options.A: a set of grid points on the surface
options.B: a set of grid control points
options.C: four bounding curves defining the surface
options.D: two bounding curves and a set of grid control points

question: Question 328 A low carbon steel bar of 147 mm diameter with a length of 630 mm is being turned with uncoated carbide insert. The observed tool lives are 24 min and 12 min for cutting velocities of 90 m/min and     120 m/min respectively. The feed and depth of cut are 0.2 mm/rev and 2 mm respectively. Use the unmachined diameter to calculate the cutting velocity. Neglect over - travel or approach of the tool. When tool life is 20 min, the machining time in min for a single pass is
solution: Given : [latex]D= 147 \text{ mm}, \; l = 630 \text{ mm}, \;f = 0.2 \text{ mm/rev},\; d = 2 \text{ mm}, \; V3= 97 \text{ m/min}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text{Machining time,}\\ t&=\frac{l}{fN}\\ V&=\pi DN \; m/min\\ t&=\frac{l \times \pi \times D}{fV}\\ t&=\frac{0.63\times 3.14\times 0.147}{0.2\times 10^{-3}\times 97}\\ t&=15 \text{ min} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 329 A low carbon steel bar of 147 mm diameter with a length of 630 mm is being turned with uncoated carbide insert. The observed tool lives are 24 min and 12 min for cutting velocities of 90 m/min and     120 m/min respectively. The feed and depth of cut are 0.2 mm/rev and 2 mm respectively. Use the unmachined diameter to calculate the cutting velocity. When tool life is 20 min, the cutting velocity in m/min is
solution: Given, [latex]T_1=24 min, T_2 =12 min, V_1=90m/min, V_2=120m/min[/latex] We have to calculate velocity, when tool life is 20 minute. First of all we calculate the values of n, From the Taylor's tool life equation, [latex]VT^n=C[/latex] For case 1st and 2nd, we can write, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_1T_1^n &= V_2T_2^n\\ \left ( \frac{T_1}{T_2} \right )^n &= \frac{V_2}{V_1} \\ \left ( \frac{24}{12} \right )^n &=\frac{120}{90} \\ 2^n&= 1.33\\ n \log 2&=\log 1.33 \\ n \times 0.301 &=0.124 \\ n&= 0.412 \end{aligned}[/latex] For [latex]V_3[/latex], we can write from tool life equation, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_1T_1^n &= V_3T_3^n\\ 90 \times (24)^{0.412}&=V_3(20)^{0.412}\\ 333.34 &=V_3 \times 3.435\\ V_3 &=97\; m/min \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 330 Match the most suitable manufacturing processes for the following parts.
solution: (P) Computer chip [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] photochemical machining (Q) Metal forming dies and moulds  [latex] \rightarrow [/latex]   electrodischarge machining (R) Turbine blade [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Electrochemical machining (S) Glass [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Ultrasonic machining

question: Question 331 The force requirement in a blanking operation of low carbon steel sheet is    5.0 kN. The thickness of the sheet is  't' and diameter of the blanked part is 'd'. For the same work material, if the diameter of the blanked part is increased to 1.5 d and thickness is reduced to 0.4 t, the new blanking force in kN is

Question 332 A 200 mm long down sprue has an area of cross-section of 650 [latex]mm^{2}[/latex]
 where the pouring basin meets the down sprue (i.e. at the beginning of the down sprue). A constant head of molten metal is maintained by the pouring basin. The molten metal flow rate is [latex]6.5\times 10^{5} mm^{3}/s[/latex]
. Considering the end of down sprue to be open to atmosphere and an acceleration due to gravity of [latex]10^{4}mm/s^{2}[/latex]
, the area of the down sprue in [latex]mm^{2}[/latex]
 at its end (avoiding aspiration effect) should be
solution: Given; [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Metal flow rate }&=6.5 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{mm}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ \therefore \quad A_{1} \mathrm{v}_{1}&=6.5 \times 10^{5}\\ \therefore \quad v_{1}&=\frac{6.5 \times 10^{5}}{650}=1000 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying Bernoulli's theorem at points A and B we get [latex] \begin{aligned} h+\frac{v_{1}^{2}}{2 g} &=\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{2 g} \\ 200+\frac{(1000)^{2}}{2 \times 10^{4}} &=\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{2 \times 10^{4}}\\ \therefore \qquad v_{2}&=2236.068 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, Area of down sprue at its end, [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{2} &=\frac{Q}{v_{2}}=\frac{6.5 \times 10^{5}}{2236.068} \\ &=290.7 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 333 Match the correct combination for following metal working processes.
solution: (P) Blanking [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Shear (Q) Stretch forming [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Tension (R) Coining [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Compression (S) Deep drawing [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Tension and compression

question: Question 334 The thickness of a metallic sheet is reduced from an initial value of 16 mm to a final value of 10 mm in one single pass rolling with a pair of cylindrical rollers each of diameter of 400 mm. The bite angle in degree will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tan \alpha &=\sqrt{\frac{t_{1}-t_{2}}{R}}=\sqrt{\frac{16-10}{200}} \\ \tan \alpha &=0.173\\ \therefore \text{Bite angle,} \alpha&=\tan ^{-1}(0.173)=9.936^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 335 In open - die forging, a disc of diameter 200 mm and height 60 mm is compressed without any barreling effect. The final diameter of the disc is 400 mm. The true strain is
solution: since volume of disc remains constant during the process, Hence [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\pi D_{1}^{2}}{4} \times l_{1}&=\frac{\pi D_{2}^{2}}{4} l_{2}\\ \text{or}\qquad D_{1}^{2} l_{1} &=D_{2}^{2} l_{2} \\ 200^{2} \times 60 &=400^{2} \times l_{2}\\ \text{or}\qquad l_{2}&=15 \mathrm{mm}\\ \text{Change in length}&=l_{1}-l_{2} \\ &=60-15=45 \mathrm{mm}\\\text{Strain:}\qquad \varepsilon &=\frac{l_{1}-l_{2}}{l_{2}}=\frac{45}{15}=3 \\ \therefore \text { True strain } &=\ln (1+\varepsilon)=\ln (1+3) \\ &=\ln 4=1.386 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 336 Two metallic sheets, each of 2.0 mm thickness, are welded in a lap joint configuration by resistance spot welding at a welding current of 10 kA and welding time of 10 milli second. A spherical fusion zone extending up to the full thickness of each sheet is formed. The properties of the metallic sheets are given as: ambient temperature = 293 K melting temperature = 1793 K density = 7000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex] latent heat of fusion = 300 kJ/kg specific heat = 800 J/kg K Assume:  1) Contact resistance along sheet - sheet interface is 500 micro-ohm and along electrode - sheet interface is zero; 2) No conductive heat loss through the bulk sheet materials; and 3) The complete weld fusion zone is at the melting temperature. The melting efficiency (in %) of the process is
solution: Given Current: [latex]I=10^{4} \mathrm{A}[/latex] Time: [latex]t=10^{-2} \mathrm{s}[/latex] [latex] \text { Resistance: } \quad R=500 \times 10^{-6} \Omega[/latex] Ambient temperature [latex] T_{\infty}=293 \mathrm{K}[/latex] Melting temperature, [latex] T_{m}=1793 \mathrm{K}[/latex] Latent heat of fusion, [latex] \begin{aligned} L&=300 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \text{Density:}\quad\rho&=7000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Specific heat, [latex] c_{p}=800 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK}[/latex] Radius of sphere, [latex] r=2 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}[/latex] Total heat supplied, [latex] \begin{aligned} H_{S} &=I^{2} R t \\ &=\left(10^{4}\right)^{2} \times 500 \times 10^{-6} \times 10^{-2} \\ &=500 \mathrm{J} \\ \text { Mass } &=\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3} \times \rho \\ &=\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(2 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{3} \times 7000 \\ &=2.346 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total heat for melting, [latex] \begin{aligned} H_{\mathrm{i}} &=m L+m c_{p}\left(T_{m}-T_{0}\right) \\ &=2.346 \times 10^{-4}[300 \times 1000+\\ &800(1793-293)] \\ H_{i} &=351.9 \mathrm{J} \\ \text{Efficiency }\quad&= \frac{H_{i}}{H_{s}}\times100\\ &=\frac{351.9}{500} \times 100 \\ &=70.38 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 337 In orthogonal turning of low carbon steel pipe with principle cutting edge angle of 90[latex]^{\circ}[/latex], the main cutting force is 1000 N and the feed force is 800 N. The shear angle is 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] and orthogonal rake angle is zero. Employing Merchant's theory, the ratio of friction force to normal force acting on the cutting tool is
solution: Given, Cutting force: [latex]F_{C}=1000 \mathrm{N} [/latex] Feed force: [latex]\quad F_{T}=800 \mathrm{N}[/latex] Rake angle: [latex]\quad \alpha=0^{\circ} [/latex] Shear angle: [latex] \quad \phi=25^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}& \text{We know that,} \\ \mu&=\frac{F}{N}=\frac{F_{C} \sin \alpha+F_{F} \cos \alpha}{F_{C} \cos \alpha-F_{T} \sin \alpha} \\ &=\frac{1000 \sin 0^{\circ}+800 \cos 0^{\circ}}{1000 \cos 0^{\circ}-800 \sin 0^{\circ}} \\ &=\frac{800}{1000}=0.8 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 338 A hole is specified as [latex]40^{_{0.000}^{0.050}}[/latex]
mm. The mating shaft has a clearance fit with minimum clearance of 0.01 mm. The tolerance on the shaft is 0.04 mm. The maximum clearance in mm between the hole and the shaft is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Low limit of hole &=40.000 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { High limit of hole } &=40.000+0.050 \\ &=40.0 .50 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text{High limit of shaft } &=40.000-0.01 \\ &=39.990 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text{Low limit of shaft} &=39.990-0.04=39.950 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]=40.050-39.950=0.10\mathrm{mm}[/latex]

question: Question 339 A direct current welding machine with a linear power source characteristic provides open circuit voltage of 80 V and short circuit current of 800 A. During welding with the machine, the measured arc current is 500 A corresponding to an arc length of 5.0 mm and the measured arc current is 460 A corresponding to an arc length of 7.0 mm.  The linear voltage (E) - arc length (L) characteristic of the welding arc can be given as (where E is in Volt and L is in mm)
solution: The power source characteristic can be witten  analytically as [latex] E=80-\frac{80}{800}I \qquad(a)[/latex] The arc characteristic is given as [latex] I=a L+b [/latex] where a and b are constant Given, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{when }I&=500 \mathrm{A}\\ \text{then }L&=5.00 \mathrm{mm}\\ \therefore 500&=5 a+b \qquad(i)\\ \text{when }I&=460 \mathrm{A}\\ \text{then }L&=7.00 \mathrm{mm}\\ \therefore 460&=7 a+b \qquad(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} a&=-20 \\ \text{and }b&=600 \end{aligned}[/latex] Then arc characteristic equation [latex] I=-20 L+600 \qquad(a)[/latex] from equation (a) and (b) [latex] \begin{aligned} E &=80-\frac{80}{800}(-20 L+600) \\ &=80-0.1(-20 L+600) \\ &=80+2 L-60 \\ &=20+2 L \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 340 In orthogonal turning of medium carbon steel, the specific machining energy is     2.0 J/[latex]mm^{3}[/latex]
. The cutting velocity, feed and depth of cut are 120 m/min, 0.2 mm/rev and 2 mm respectively. The main cutting force in N is
solution: The energy consumption per unit volume of material removal, commonly known as specific energy. [latex] \text { cutting force }=2 \times 1000 \times 0.2 \times 2=800 \mathrm{N}[/latex]

question: Question 341 In electrodischarge machining (EDM), if the thermal conductivity of tool is high and the specific heat of work piece is low, then the tool wear rate and material removal rate are expected to be respectively
solution: Material removal rate [latex]\propto[/latex] Thermal conductivity of tool [latex]\therefore[/latex]    Tool wear [latex]\propto[/latex] material removal rate

question: Question 342 Volume of a cube of side '[latex]l[/latex]' and volume of a sphere of radius 'r' are equal. Both the cube and the sphere are solid and of same material. They are being cast. The ratio of the solidification time of the cube to the same of the sphere is
solution: Surface area of cube [latex] =6 l^{2} [/latex] Surface area of sphere [latex]=4 \pi r^{2} [/latex] According to Chorinov's relation Solidification time [latex]\propto\left(\frac{\text { volume }}{\text { surface area }}\right)^{2} [/latex] as volume of cube and sphere are equal [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{t_{c}}{t_{s}}&=\left(\frac{A_{s}}{A_{c}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{4 \pi r^{2}}{6 l^{2}}\right)^{2} \\ \frac{t_{c}}{t_{s}}&=\left(\frac{4 \pi}{6}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{r}{l}\right)^{4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 343 Which type of motor is NOT used in axis or spindle drives of CNC machine tools?
solution: In CNC, the most popular motor have two types, stepper motor and servo motor.

question:
Question 344 In orthogonal turning of a low carbon steel bar of diameter 150 mm with uncoated carbide tool, the cutting velocity is 90 m/min. The feed is 0.24 mm/rev and the depth of cut is 2 mm. The chip thickness obtained is 0.48mm. If the orthogonal rake angle is zero and the principle cutting edge angle is [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]
, the shear angle in degree is
solution: Given Feed rate:[latex]f=0.24 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{rev}[/latex] Chip thickness: [latex]t_{2}=0.48 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Principal cutting edge angle, [latex] \Psi=90^{\circ}[/latex] Rake angle: [latex] \quad \alpha=0 [/latex] We know that Uncut chip thickness, [latex] \begin{aligned} t_{1} &=f \sin \Psi \\ &=0.24 \sin 90 \\ t_{1} &=0.24 \mathrm{mm}\\ \text { Cutting ratio: } & r=\frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}=\frac{0.24}{0.48}=0.5 \\ \tan \varphi &=\frac{r \cos \theta}{1-r \sin \alpha} \\ &=\frac{0.5 \cos ^{\circ}}{1-0.5 \sin 0^{\circ}}=0.5 \\ \text { Shear angle: } \phi &=\tan ^{-1}(0.5) \\ &=26.56^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 345 Which one of the following is a solid state joining process?
solution: Friction welding is defined as a solid state welding process wherein coalescence is produced by heat obtained from mechanically induced sliding motion between rubbing surfaces.

question: Question 346 Which of the following engineering materials is the most suitable candidate for hot chamber die casting?
solution: The hot chamber process is used for most of the low melting temperature alloys, such as zinc, lead and tin.

question: Question 347 If a particular Fe-C alloy contains less than 0.83% carbon, it is called
solution: The carbon alloy having less than 2% carbon are called "steels" and those containing over 2% carbon are called cast irons. Now, steel may further be classified into two groups. (i) Steels having less than 0.83% carbon are called "hypoeutectoid steels" (ii) Those having more than 0.83% carbon called "hypereutectoid steels"

question: Question 348 In an orthogonal machining operation: Assume Merchant's theory. The percentage of total energy dissipated due to friction at the tool-chip interface is:
solution: Frictional force [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{R} &=F_{C} \sin \theta+F_{7} \cos \alpha \\ &=1200 \sin \left(15^{\circ}\right)+200 \cos \left(15^{\circ}\right) \\ &=503.8 \end{aligned}[/latex] Velocity of chip, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{C} &=\frac{V \sin \phi}{\cos (\phi-\alpha)} \\ &=\frac{V \sin \left(40.2^{\circ}\right)}{\cos (40.2-15)}=0.713 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total power consumption [latex] F_{C} V=1200 \mathrm{V}[/latex] Power consumption due to friction [latex] \begin{array}{l} =F_{R} V_{C} \\ =503.8 \times 0.713 \mathrm{V} \\ =359.21 \mathrm{V} \end{array}[/latex] Percentage of energy dissipated due friction [latex] =\frac{359.21 \mathrm{V}}{1200 \mathrm{V}} \times 100=30 \%[/latex]

question: Question 349 In an orthogonal machining operation: Assume Merchant's theory. The coefficient of friction at the tool-chip interface is:
solution: We know that [latex] \begin{aligned} \mu &=\frac{F}{N}=\frac{F_{C} \sin \alpha+F_{1} \cos \alpha}{F_{C} \cos \alpha-F_{T} \sin \alpha} \\ &=\frac{1200 \sin 15^{\circ}+200 \cos 15^{\circ}}{1200 \cos 15^{\circ}-200 \sin 15^{\circ}} \\ \mu &=\frac{F}{N}=\frac{F_{C} \sin \alpha+F_{T} \cos \alpha}{F_{C} \cos \alpha-F_{T} \sin \alpha} \\ &=\frac{310.6+193.2}{1159.1-51.76} \\ &=0.46 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 350 In an orthogonal machining operation: Assume Merchant's theory. The values of shear angle and shear strain, respectively, are
solution: Given; Uncut thickness: [latex]t_{1}=0.5 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Cutting speed: [latex]\quad v=20 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} [/latex] Rake angle:[latex]\alpha=15^{\circ}[/latex] Width of cut: [latex]\quad w=5 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Chip thickness: [latex] t_{2}=0.7 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Thrust force: [latex] \quad F_{T}=200 N [/latex] Cutting force: [latex] F_{C}=1200 \mathrm{N} [/latex] Cutting ratio: [latex] \quad r=\frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}=\frac{0.5}{0.7}=0.714[/latex] We know that, [latex] \begin{aligned} \tan \phi &=\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha}=\frac{0.714 \cos 15^{\circ}}{1-0.714 \sin 15^{\circ}} \\ &=0.847 \\ \therefore \quad \phi &=\tan ^{-1}(0.847)=40.2^{\circ} \\ \text{Shear strain} \quad&=\cot\phi + \tan(\phi-\alpha)\\ &=\cot \left(40.2^{\circ}\right)+\tan \left(40.2^{\circ}-15^{\circ}\right) \\ &=1.181+0.4716 \\ &=1.65 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 351 Match the items in columns I and II.
solution: (P) Charpy test--Toughness (Q) Knoop--Microhardness (R) Spiral test--Fluidity (S) Cupping test--Formability

question: Question 352 Arrange the processes in the increasing order of their maximum material removal rate. Electrochemical Machining (ECM) Ultrasonic Machining (USM) Electron Beam Machining (EBM) Laser Beam Machining (LBM) and Electric Discharge Machining (EDM)
Question 353 If each abrasive grain is viewed as a cutting tool, then which of the following represents the cutting parameters in common grinding operations?
solution: In common grinding operation, the average rake angle of the grains is highly negative, such as [latex]-60^{\circ}[/latex] or even lower and smaller the shear angle. From this, grinding chips under go much larger deformation than they do in other cutting process. The cutting speeds are very high, typically 30 m/s.

options.A: Large negative rake angle, low shear angle and high cutting speed
options.B: Large positive rake angle, low shear angle and high cutting speed
options.C: Large negative rake angle, high shear angle and low cutting speed
options.D: Zero rake angle, high shear angle and high cutting speed

question: Question 354 In an arc welding process, the voltage and current are 25 V and 300 A respectively. The arc heat transfer efficiency is 0.85 and welding speed is 8 mm/sec. the net heat input (in J/mm) is:
solution: Given Voltage: V=25 volt Current:I=300amp, Efficiency: [latex]\quad \eta=0.85 [/latex] Weld speed: v=8 mm/sec Power generated due to arc = VI Power utilized as heat [latex]=\eta V l [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.85 \times 25 \times 300=6375 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{s} \\ &=\frac{6375}{\mathrm{v}} \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{mm}=\frac{6375}{8} \\ &=796.8 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 355 Match the items in columns I and II.
solution: (P) Wrinkling – Insufficient blank holding force. In the flange region of the cup, due to compressive stresses, there will be a tendency of wrinkling formation. To suppress wrinkling blank holding pressure is applied. (Q) Orange peel – large grain If the sheet metal is having a coarse grain structure , near the punch corner radius, the surface will be very rough and the defect is called Orange Peeling. (R) Stretch Strains – Yield point elongation Stretch strains are usually seen in yield point elongation  of ductile materials. (S) Earing – Anisotropy. Earing is a result of the non-uniform flow of material  into the die cavity from different anisotropy directions of the sheet.

question: Question 356 In a wire drawing operation, diameter of a steel wire is reduced from 10 mm to 8 mm. the mean flow stress of the material is 400 MPa. The ideal force requied for drawing (ignoring friction and redundant work) is:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given,}\; D_{i}&=10 \mathrm{mm} \\ D_{f}&=8 \mathrm{mm} \\ \sigma_{0}&=400 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Ignoring friction and redundant work means [latex] \begin{aligned} \mu &=0, \beta=0 \\ \text { Hence } \;\;\sigma_{d} &=2 \sigma_{0} \ln \left(\frac{r_{i}}{r_{f}}\right) \\ &=2 \times 400 \ln \left(\frac{5}{4}\right) \\ &=178.51 \mathrm{MPa} \\ &=178.51 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \times \pi r_{f}^{2} \\ &=178.51 \times 10^{6} \times 3.14 \times(0.004)^{2} \\ &=8968 \mathrm{N}=8.97 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 357 A 4 mm thick sheet is rolled with 300 mm diameter rolls to reduce thickness without any change in its width. The friction coefficient at the work-roll interface is 0.1. The minimum possible thickness of the sheet that can be produced in a single pass is:
solution: Given, Initial thickness of sheet, [latex] t_{i}=4 \mathrm{mm}=4 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}[/latex] Diameter of roll, [latex] D=300 \mathrm{mm}=0.3 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Frictional coefficient at work-roll interface, [latex] \mu=0.1[/latex] Let [latex]t_{f}=[/latex] Final thickness of sheet after rolling For single pass without slipping minimum possible thickness, [latex] \begin{aligned} t_{i}-t_{f} &=\mu^{2} R \\ \mu &=\sqrt{\frac{t_{1}-t_{f}}{R}} \\ 0.1 &=\sqrt{\frac{4 \times 10^{-3}-t_{f}}{0.15}} \\ \text{or}\quad t_{f} &=2.5 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 358 In a sand casting operation, the total liquid head is maintained constant such that it is equal to the mould height. The time taken to fill the mould with a top gate is [latex]t_{A}[/latex]. If the same mould is filed with a bottom gate, then the time taken is [latex]t_{B}[/latex]. Ignore the time required to fill the runner and frictional effects. Assume atmospheric pressure at the top molten metal surfaces. The relation between [latex]t_{A}[/latex]
and [latex]t_{B}[/latex]
is:
solution: Time taken to fill the mould with top gate [latex] \begin{aligned} t_{A}&=\frac{A H}{A_{g} \sqrt{2 g h_{m}}} \qquad \cdots(i)\\ \text{where }\quad A&= \text{Area of mould} \\ H&= \text{Height of mould}\\ A_{g}&=\text { Area of Gate } \\ n_{m}&=\text { Gate height } \end{aligned}[/latex] Given that, [latex]h_{m}=H,[/latex] so Eq. (i) become: [latex] t_{A}=\frac{A \sqrt{h_{m}}}{A_{g} \sqrt{2 g}} \qquad \cdots(ii)[/latex] Time taken to fill the mould with bottom gate, [latex] \begin{aligned} t_{B}&=\frac{2 A}{A_{g} \sqrt{2 g}}(\sqrt{h_{m}}-\sqrt{h_{m}-H}) \\ t_{B}&=\frac{2 A}{A_{g} \sqrt{2 g}} \sqrt{h_{m}} \qquad \cdots(iii) \end{aligned}[/latex] From Eqs. (ii) and (iii), we get [latex] \frac{t_{B}}{t_{A}}=2[/latex] [latex] \text { or } \quad t_{B}=2 t_{A}[/latex]

question: Question 359 The ultimate tensile strength of a material is 400 MPa and the elongation up to maximum load is 35%. If the material obeys power law of hardening, then the true stress-true strain relation (stress in MPa) in the plastic deformation range is:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \epsilon &=\ln \left(1+\epsilon_{0}\right) \\ &=\ln (1+0.35)=0.3\\ \text{But at UTS }n&=\epsilon\\ \text { Hence } n&=\epsilon=0.3 \\ \text { Also } \sigma_{f}&=\sigma_{0}\left(1+\epsilon_{0}\right)=400(1+0.35) \\ &=540 \mathrm{MPa}\\ \text{Now,}\quad \sigma_{f}&=K \epsilon^{n}\\ 540 &=K(0.3)^{0.3} \\ \text{or} \quad K &=774.97\\ \text { Hence } \sigma_{f}&=775 \epsilon^{0.3} \\ \text { Where, } \sigma_{f}&=\text { true stress } \\ \epsilon&=\text { true strain } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 360 A ring gauge is used to measure
solution: Ring gauges are used to measure outside diameter and roundness of shaft.

question: Question 361 NC contouring is an example of
solution: NC contouring is a continuous path positioning system. Its function is to synchronize the axes of motion to generate a predetermined path, generally a line or a circular arc.

question: Question 362 The main purpose of spheroidising treatment is to improve
solution:
This heat treatment is given to high carbon and 
air hardening alloy steels to soften and to increase 
machinability.

question: Question 363 An expendable pattern is used in
solution: Investment casting uses an expandable pattern, which is made of wax or of a plastic by molding or rapid prototyping techniques. This pattern is made by injecting molten wax or plastic into a metal die in the shape of the pattern.

question:
Question 364 Two tools P and Q have signatures [latex]5^{\circ}-5^{\circ}-6^{\circ}-8^{\circ}-30^{\circ}-0^{\circ}[/latex]
 and [latex]5^{\circ}-5^{\circ}-7^{\circ}-7^{\circ}-8^{\circ}-15^{\circ}-0^{\circ}[/latex]
 (both ASA) respectively. They are used to turn components under the same machining conditions. If [latex]h_{P}[/latex]
 and [latex]h_{Q}[/latex]
 denote the peakto-valley heights of surfaces produced by the tools P and Q, the ratio [latex]\frac{h_{P}}{h_{Q}}[/latex]
  will be
solution: We know that [latex] h=\frac{f}{\tan (S C E A)+\cot (E C E A)}[/latex] where f-feed rate SCEA-side cutting edge angle ECEA-End cutting edge angle Given [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{p} &=\frac{f}{\tan 30^{\circ}+\cot 8^{\circ}} \\ \text { and } \quad h_{Q} &=\frac{f}{\tan 15^{\circ}+\cot 8^{\circ}} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{h_{\rho}}{h_{O}}&=\frac{\tan 15^{\circ}+\cot 8^{\circ}}{\tan 30^{\circ}+\cot 8^{\circ}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 365 The tool of an NC machine has to move along a circular arc from (5,5) to (10,10) while performing an operation. The center of the arc is at (10,5). Which one of the following NC tool path commands performs the above mentioned operation?

Question 366 A 600 mm x 300 mm flat surface of a plate is to be finish machined on a shaper. The plate has been fixed with the 600 mm side along the tool travel direction. If the tool over-travel at each end of the plate is 20 mm, average cutting speed is 8 m/min, feed rate is 0.3 mm/stroke and the ratio of return time to cutting time of the tool is 1:2, the time required for machining will be
solution: Length travellent in forward stroke [latex] \begin{aligned} &=600+20+20 \\ &=640 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Total strokes }&=\frac{30}{0.3}=100\\ \text{Total trand} &=640 \times 100 \\ &=64000 \mathrm{mm}=64 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \text { Time of strokes }=\frac{64}{8}=8 \text { minutes } \\ \text { Return time }=\frac{\text { cutting time }}{2}=\frac{8}{2}=4 \mathrm{min} \end{array}[/latex] Number of strokes required [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\text { Thickness of flat plate }}{\text { feed rate / stroke }} \\ &=\frac{30}{0.3}=100 \text { strokes } \\ \text { Total time } &=8+4 \min =12 \min \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 367 Spot welding of two 1 mm thick sheets of steel (density = 8000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]
) is carried out successfully by passing a certain amount of current for 0.1 second through the electrodes. The resultant weld nugget formed is 5 mm in diameter and 1.5 mm thick. If the latent heat of fusion of steel is 1400 kJ/kg and the effective resistance in the welding operation is 200 [latex]\mu \Omega[/latex], the current passing through the electrodes is approximately
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Mass } &=\frac{\pi}{4} \times 25 \times 1.5 \times 8000 \times 10^{-9} \\ &=2.356 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{kg} \\ \text { Heat } &=140 \times 8000 \times 2.356 \times 10-4 \\ &=329.8 \mathrm{J} \\ 329.8 &=(A)^{2} \times 200 \times 10^{-6} \times 0.1 \\ A &=4060 \mathrm{amp} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 368 A 2 mm thick metal sheet is to be bent at an angle of one radian with a bend radius of 100 mm. If the stretch factor is 0.5, the bend allowance is
solution: We know that [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Bend allowance }&=\alpha(R+k t) \\ \text { Where } \quad R&=\text { inside radiues of the bend }\\ &=100 \mathrm{mm} \\ \alpha &=\text { bend angle }=1 \;\mathrm{radian} \\ t &=\text { thickness of metal sheet }\\ k&=\text{Location of neutral from the bottom}\\ &=0.33 \text { where } R \lt 2 t \\ &=0.50 \text { where } R \gt 2 t\\ \therefore &\text{Bend allowance}\\ &=1 \times(100+0.5 \times 2) \\ &=101 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 369 A mould has a downsprue whose length is 20 cm and the cross sectional area at the base of the downsprue is 1 [latex]cm^2[/latex]. The downsprue feeds a horizontal runner leading into the mould cavity of volume 1000 [latex]cm^{3}[/latex]. The time required to fill the mould cavity will be
solution: Length of sprue, [latex] h=20 \mathrm{cm}=0.2 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Area of down sprue, [latex] A=1 \mathrm{cm}^{2}=10^{-4} \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] Volume of mould cavity [latex] =1000 \mathrm{cm}^{3}=10^{-3} \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Velocity at base of spruce, [latex] V=\sqrt{2 g h}=\sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.2}=1.98 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] Let t is time of filling the mould then volume of mould Cavity =AVt [latex] \begin{aligned} 10^{-3} &=10^{-4} \times 1 \times 1.98 t \\ \therefore \quad t &=\frac{10^{-3} \times 10^{4}}{1.98}=5.05 \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 370 Which among the NC operations given below are continuous path operations?
solution: Arc welding, Laser cutting of sheet and milling operations are the continuous path operations.

question: Question 371 The figure below shows a graph, which qualitatively relates cutting speed and cost per piece produced. The three curves, 1, 2 and 3 respectively represent
solution: We know, Machining cost = Machining time *  Direct labour cost. If cutting speed increases then machining time decreases and machining cost also decreases and due to increase in cutting speed tool changing cost increases. So, Curve 1 is of Machining cost Curve 2 is of Non-productive cost Curve 3 is of Tool changing cost

options.A: machining cost, non-productive cost, tool changing cost
options.B: non-productive cost, machining cost, tool changing cost
options.C: tool changing cost, machining cost, non-productive cost
options.D: tool changing cost, non-productive cost, machining cost

question: Question 372 When 3-2-1 principle in used to support and locate a three dimensional workpiece during machining, the number of degrees of freedom that are restricted is
solution: According  to 3-2-1 principle, only the minimum locating points should be used to secure location of the work piece in any one plane. (A) The workpiece is resting on three pins A, B, C which are inserted in the base of fixed body. The workpiece cannot rotate about the axis XX and YY and also it cannot move downward. In this case, the five degrees of freedom have been arrested. (B) Two more pins D and E are inserted in the fixed body, in a plane perpendicular to the plane containing, the pins A, B and C . Now the workpiece cannot rotate about the Z -axis and also it cannot move towards the left. Hence the addition of pins D and E restrict three more degrees of freedom. (C) Another pin F in the second vertical face of the fixed body, arrests degree of freedom 9.

question: Question 376 When the temperature of a solid metal increases.
solution: When the temperature of a solid metal increases, its intramolecular bonds are brake and strength of solid metal decreases. Due to decrease its strength, the elongation of the metal increases, when we apply the load i.e. ductility increases.

options.A: strength of the metal decreases but ductility increases
options.B: both strength and ductility of the metal decrease
options.C: both strength and ductility of the metal increase
options.D: strength of the metal increases but ductility decreases

question:
Question 382 In a machining operation, doubling the cutting speed reduces the tool life to [latex]{\frac{1}{8}}^{th}[/latex]
 of the original value. The exponent n in Taylor's tool life equation ,[latex]VT^{n}=C[/latex],
 is
solution: Taylor's tool life equation, [latex] V T^{n}=C \qquad\ldots(i)[/latex] When cutting speed is doubled and tool life reduces to [latex] 1 / 8^{\text {th }},[/latex] then [latex] 2 v \times\left(\frac{1}{8} T\right)^{n}=C \qquad\ldots(ii)[/latex] fom equation (i) and (ii), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 v\left(\frac{T}{8}\right)^{n} &=V T^{n} \\ \left(\frac{1}{8}\right)^{n} &=\frac{1}{2} \\ 3 n &=1 \\ n &=1 / 3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 383 In a rolling process, sheet of 25 mm thickness is rolled to 20 mm thickness. Roll is of diameter 600 mm and it rotates at 100 rpm. The roll strip contact length will be
solution: Given [latex] \begin{aligned} t_{i} &=25 \mathrm{mm} & & t_{f}=20 \mathrm{mm} \\ R &=300 \mathrm{mm} & & N=100 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Angle subtended by the deformation zone at the roll centre [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta&=\sqrt{\frac{t_{1}-t_{f}}{R}}=\sqrt{\frac{25-20}{300}} \\ \therefore \quad \theta&=0.129 \mathrm{rad} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Roll strip contact length [latex]=\theta . R [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =0.129 \times 300 \\ =38.72 \mathrm{mm} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 384 In an orthogonal cutting test on mild steel, the following data were obtained Using Merchant's analysis, the Friction angle during the machining will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mu=\frac{F}{N}&=\frac{F_{c} \sin \alpha+F_{T} \cos \alpha}{F_{c} \cos \alpha-F_{T} \sin \alpha}\\ &=\frac{900 \sin 5^{\circ}+450 \cos 5^{\circ}}{900 \sin 5^{\circ}-450 \cos 5^{\circ}}\\ &=\frac{526.72}{857.35}=0.614\\ \therefore \quad \lambda&=\tan ^{-1}(\mu)=31.5^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 385 Gray cast iron blocks 200 x 100 x 10 mm are to be cast in sand moulds. Shrinkage allowance for pattern making is 1%, The ratio of the volume of pattern to that of the casting will be
solution: castiron expands during cooling from solid at melting point to solid at room temperature [latex] \therefore [/latex]Shrinkage allowance = -1% Hence shrinkage allowance given along length , [latex] =200 \times 0.01=2 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Shrinkage allowance given along breadth [latex] =100 \times 0.01=1 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Shrinkage allowance given along height [latex] =10 \times 0.01=0.1 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]  Volume of pattern, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{p} &=(200+2)(100+1)(10+0.1) \\ &=2.06 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{mm}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Volume of casting, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{C}&=200 \times 100 \times 10=2 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{mm}^{3}\\ \therefore \quad \frac{V_{P}}{V_{C}}&=\frac{2.06 \times 10^{5}}{2 \times 10^{5}}=1.03 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 387 Through holes of 10 mm diameter are to be drilled in a steel plate of 20 mm thickness. Drill spindle speed is 300 rpm, feed 0.2 mm/rev and drill point angle is [latex]120^{\circ}[/latex]
. Assuming drill overtravel of 2 mm, the time for producing a hole will be
solution: Diameter of hole, [latex] d=10 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] thickness of steel plate, [latex] \begin{aligned} t &=20 \mathrm{mm} \\ \alpha &=\frac{120}{2}=60^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Break through distance, [latex] \begin{aligned} A &=\frac{d}{2 \tan \alpha}=\frac{10}{2 \tan 60^{\circ}} \\ &=2.8867 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total lengtt of tool travel, [latex] \begin{aligned} l&=t+A+2 \\ &=20+2.8867+2=24.88 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text{Time for drilling }&= \frac{l}{fN}\\ &=\frac{24.88}{0.2 \times 300}=0.4147 \mathrm{min} \\ &=0.4147 \times 60 \mathrm{s} \\ &=24.882 \mathrm{s} \approx 25 \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 388 10 mm diameter holes are to be punched in a steel sheet of 3 mm thickness. Shear strength of the material is [latex]400 N/mm^{2}[/latex]
 and penetration is 40%. Shear provided on the punch is 2 mm. The blanking force during the operation will be
solution: Shear strength: [latex]\quad \tau=400 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} [/latex] Sheet thickness: [latex]t=3 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Diameter of hole: [latex]d=10 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Shear on punch: [latex]t_{1}=2 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Penetration of punch on fraction, [latex] p=0.4[/latex] Braking force when shear is applied on the punch [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\pi d t\left(\frac{t p}{t_{1}}\right) \tau=\pi \times 10 \times 3 \times\left(\frac{3 \times 0.4}{2}\right) \times 400 \\ &=22.6 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 389 GO and No-GO plug gages are to be designed for a hole [latex]20.000^{_{+0.010}^{+0.050}}[/latex]
 Gage tolerances can be taken as 10% of the hole tolerance. Following ISO system of gage design, sizes of GO and NO-GO gage will be respectively
solution: For ISO system of gauge: [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \text { Hole tolerance } &=20.05-20.01=0.04 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \text { Gauge tolerance } &=10 \% \text { of } 0.04=0.004 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \text { Size of Go gauge } &=20+0.01+0.004 \\ &=20.014 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Size of No-Go } &=20.05-0.004 \\ &=20.046 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 390 The percentage of carbon in gray cast iron is in the range of
solution: Gray cast iron is the most widely used of all cast irons. In fact, it is common to speak of gray cast iron just as cast iron. It contains 3 to 4% C and 2.5 % Si.

question: Question 391 Misrun is a casting defect which occurs due to
solution: If molten metal is too cold, entire mould cavity may not be filled during pouring before the metal Starts solidifying and the result is 'misrun' Causes of Misrun (i) Too cold molten metal. (ii) Too small gates. (iii) Too thin casting section (iv) Too many restrictions in gating system (v) Metal lacking fluidity

options.A: very high pouring temperature of the metal
options.B: insufficient fluidity of the molten metal
options.C: absorption of gases by the liquid metal
options.D: improper alignment of the mould flasks

question: Question 392 Two 1 mm thick steel sheets are to be spot welded at a current of 5000 A. Assuming effective resistance to be 200 micro-ohms and current flow time of 0.2 second, heat generated during the process will be
solution: Heat generated during the process [latex] =I^{2} R \Delta t [/latex] [latex] =(5000)^{2} \times\left(200 \times 10^{-6}\right) \times 0.2=1000[/latex]

question: Question 393 The mechanism of material removal in EDM process is
solution: Material removal takes place due to erosion by repeated spark. After that melting and evaporation takes place.

question: Question 394 During the execution of a CNC part program block NO20  GO2  X45.0  Y25.0  R5.0 the type of tool motion will be
solution: Given:-N020 G02 X45.0 Y25.0 R5.0 Here term X45.0 Y25.0 R5.0 will produce circular motion because radius is consider in this term and G02 will produce clockwise motion of the tool.

question:
Question 395 In an interchangeable assembly, shafts of size [latex]25.000^{ _{-0.0100}^{+0.040}}[/latex]
 mm mate with 
holes of size [latex]25.000^{ _{-0.000}^{+0.020}}[/latex]
 The maximum possible clearance in the assembly will be
solution: Minimum shaft size [latex] =25.000-0.04=24.96 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Maximum hole size [latex] =25.000+0.02=25.02 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] therefore  maximum possible clearance = maximum size of hole - Minimum size of shaft [latex] \begin{aligned} &=25.02-24.96 \\ &=0.060 \mathrm{mm}=60 \mathrm{micron} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 396 A cylinder is turned on a lathe with orthogonal machining principle. Spindle rotates at 200 rpm. The axial feed rate is 0.25 mm per revolution. Depth of cut is 0.4 mm. The rake angle is [latex]10^{\circ}[/latex]
. In the analysis it is found that the shear angle is [latex]27.75^{\circ}[/latex]
. In the above problem, the coefficient of friction at the chip tool interface obtained using Earnest and Merchant theory is
solution: From earnest and merchant theory [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 \phi+\lambda-\alpha &=90^{\circ} \\ \lambda &=90^{\circ}+10-2 \times 27.75^{\circ} \\ \therefore \qquad \lambda &=44.5^{\circ} \\ \mu &=\tan \left(44.5^{\circ}\right)=0.98 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 397 A cylinder is turned on a lathe with orthogonal machining principle. Spindle rotates at 200 rpm. The axial feed rate is 0.25 mm per revolution. Depth of cut is 0.4 mm. The rake angle is [latex]10^{\circ}[/latex]
. In the analysis it is found that the shear angle is [latex]27.75^{\circ}[/latex]
. The thickness of the produced chip is
solution: Given [latex] \begin{aligned} N &=200 \mathrm{rpm} \\ \text { Feed }\left(t_{1}\right) &=\text { uncut chip thickness }=0.25 \\ \text { Depth } &=0.4 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Rake angle, [latex] \alpha=10^{\circ}[/latex] Shear angle, [latex] \phi=27.75^{\circ}[/latex] We Know [latex] \begin{aligned} \tan \phi &=\frac{\cos \alpha}{\frac{t_{2}}{t_{1}}-\sin \alpha} \\ \Rightarrow \quad t_{2} &=t_{1}\left[\frac{\cos \alpha}{\tan \phi}+\sin \alpha\right] \\ &=0.25\left[\frac{\cos 10^{\circ}}{\tan 27.75^{\circ}}+\sin 10^{\circ}\right] \\ &=0.511 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 398 Match the following
solution: (P) Aluminium-Gas tungsten Arc welding (Q) Die steel-Atomic Hydrogen welding (R) Copper wire-Soldering (S) Titanium sheet-Laser Beam welding

question:
Question 399 A part shown in the figure is machined to the sizes given below [latex]P=35.00 \pm 0.08 mm[/latex] [latex]Q=12.00 \pm 0.02 mm[/latex] [latex]R=13.00^{+0.04}_{-0.02}mm[/latex]
With 100% confidence, the resultant dimension W will have the specification
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P&=35+0.08 \mathrm{mm} \\ Q&=12.00+0.02 \mathrm{mm} \\ R&=13.0_{-0.02}^{+0.04}=13.01 \pm 0.03 \end{aligned}[/latex] Now all have same bilateral tolerance, so [latex] P=Q+W+R[/latex] [latex] \therefore P=Q+W+R[/latex] Considering dimension [latex] \Rightarrow \quad 35=12+W+13.01 [/latex] [latex] W=9.99 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Tolerance are probabilities and not the absolute Value on any part, at least one section must be there that treated as sink, and tolerance of sink will be cumulative sum of all tolerances. [latex] \therefore [/latex]Tolerance [latex]=0.08+0.02+0.03=0.13[/latex]

Question 401 A threaded nut of M16, ISO metric type, having 2 mm pitch with a pitch diameter of 14.701 mm is to be checked for its pitch diameter using two or three numbers of balls or rollers of the following sizes
solution: Given Metric thread M 16 In case of threads always rollers (wires) are used. [latex] \text { Pitch: } p=2 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Pitch diameter [latex]=14.701 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] In case of Metric thread [latex]\;2\theta=60^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \theta=30^{\circ}[/latex] For a best size wire [latex] d w=\frac{P}{2} \sec \theta=\frac{2}{2} \sec 30^{\circ}=1.155 \mathrm{mm}[/latex]

question: Question 402 A batch of 10 cutting tools could produce 500 components while working at 50 rpm with a tool feed of 0.25 mm/rev and depth of cut of 1 mm. A similar batch of 10 tools of the same specification could produce 122 components while working at 80 rpm with a feed of 0.25 mm/rev and 1 mm depth of cut. How many components can be produced with one cutting tool at 60 rpm.
solution: Velocity of first cutting tool [latex] V_{1}=50 \times 0.25=12.5 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{min}[/latex] Velocity of second cutting tool [latex] V_{2}=0.25 \times 80=20 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{min}[/latex] since tool life = no. of component produce [latex]\times [/latex] tool constant [latex] \therefore [/latex] Tool life for first tool, [latex] T_{1}=500 \mathrm{K}[/latex] Tool life for second tool, [latex] \begin{aligned} \qquad T_{2}&=122 \mathrm{K} \\ \text { Now, } V_{1} T_{1}^{n}&=V_{2} T_{2}^{n} \\ \Rightarrow(12.5) \times(500 \mathrm{K})^{n}&=20 \times(122 \mathrm{K})^{n}\\ \therefore \qquad\left(\frac{500}{122}\right)^{n}&=1.6 \\ \therefore \qquad n&=0.333 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence number of components produced by one cutting tool at 60 rpm [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow 12.5 \times\left(\frac{500 k}{10}\right)^{0.333}=60 \times 0.25 \times(x k) 0.333 \\ \left(\frac{x}{50}\right)^{0.333}=\frac{12.5}{60 \times 0.25} \\ \left(\frac{x}{50}\right)^{0.333}=\frac{12.5}{60 \times 0.25} \\ \therefore \quad x=29 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 403 A metal disc of 20 mm diameter is to be punched from a sheet of 2 mm thickness. The punch and the die clearance is 3%. The required punch diameter is
solution: Given, Punched diameter [latex] d=20 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Sheet thickness, [latex] t=2 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Clearance: c=3% of t Punch diameter, [latex] \begin{aligned} D &=d-2 c \\ &=20-2 \times \frac{3}{100} \times 2=19.88 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 404 A brass billet is to be extruded from its initial diameter of 100 mm to a final diameter of 50 mm. The working temperature of 700[latex]^{\circ}C[/latex] and the extrusion constant is 250 MPa. The force required for extrusion is
solution: Force required for extrusion [latex] \begin{aligned} &=k A_{1} \ln \left(\frac{A_{i}}{A_{f}}\right)\\ \text{where }\quad k&= \text{ extrusion constant}\\ &=250 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ A_{i} &=\text { initial area } \\ &=\frac{\pi}{4} \times(0.1)^{2}=7.854 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \\ A_{f} &=\text { final area }=\frac{\pi}{4} \times(0.05)^{2} \\ &=1.96 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Extrusion force, [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=250 \times 10^{6} \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(0.1)^{2} \\ & \quad \quad \quad\ln \left( \frac{7.854 \times 10^{-3}}{1.96 \times 10^{-3}}\right) \\ &=2.72 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N} \\ &=2.72 \mathrm{MN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 405 A shell of 100 mm diameter and 100 mm height with the corner radius of 0.4 mm is to be produced by cup drawing. The required blank diameter is
solution: Given, Shell diameter [latex] d=100 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Shell height, [latex] h=100 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Corner radius, [latex] \begin{array}{ll} & r=0.4 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Here } & d>20 \mathrm{r} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Blank diameter, [latex] \begin{aligned} D &=\sqrt{d^{2}+4 h d} \\ &=\sqrt{(100)^{2}+4 \times 100 \times 100}=224 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 406 With a solidification factor of [latex]0.97\times 10^{6} s/m^{2}[/latex]
, the solidification time (in seconds) for a spherical casting of 200 mm diameter is
solution: [latex]\text { Given, } \mathrm{d}=200 \mathrm{mm}, \mathrm{r}=100 \mathrm{mm}=0.1 \mathrm{m}[/latex] According to Caine's relation: Solidification time, [latex] \begin{aligned} t&=Q\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)^{2} \\ t&=0.97 \times 10^{6}\left(\frac{\frac{4}{3} \pi(0.1)^{3}}{4 \pi(0.1)^{2}}\right)^{2} \\ t&=0.97 \times 10^{6}\left(\frac{0.1}{3}\right)^{2}\\ &=1077.78 \;\mathrm{second}\\ &\approx 1078 \;\mathrm{second} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 407 Hardness of steel greatly improves with
solution: Hardness is greatly depend on the carbon content present in the steel. Cyaniding is case-hardening with powered potassium cyanide or potassium ferrocyanide mixed with potassium bichromate, substituted for carbon. Cyaniding produces a thin but very hard case in a very short time.

question: Question 408 The dimensional limits on a shaft of 25h7 are
solution: 25 lines between 18 and 30 since therefore [latex] \Delta=\sqrt{18 \times 30}=23.24[/latex] Now, the tolerance unit i is given by [latex] i=0.45 \sqrt[3]{23.24}+0.001(23.24)[/latex] [latex] =1.31 microns [/latex] For shaft quality '7', fundamental tolerance Tolerance Grade, [latex] \begin{aligned} IT7 &=16 i \\ &=16 \times 1.31=20.96 \text { microns } \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, Shaft tolerance [latex] \begin{aligned} &=25-\left(20.96 \times 10^{-3}\right) \mathrm{mm} \\ &=24.979 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 411 Cold working of steel is defined as working
solution:
Cold forming or cold working can be defined as the plastic deforming of metals
and alloys under conditions of temperature and strain rate. Theoretically, the working temperature for cold working is below the
recrystallization temperature of the metal/alloy (which is about one-half the
absolute melting temperature.)

question: Question 413 Hardness of green sand mould increases with

options.D: increase in both moisture content and permeability
